530.description: Prerequisites, MATH 231, 232, and 233; PHYS 118 and 119. Recommended preparation, MATH 383. Develops explanatory and predictive models of the earth’s climate. The level is introductory and the emphasis is on modeling past climate with the hope of understanding its future.
530.title: Principles of Climate Modeling (3)

562.description: Prerequisite, STOR 155. Introduction to the application of quantitative and statistical methods in environmental science, including environmental monitoring, assessment, threshold exceedance, risk assessment, and environmental decision making.
562.title: Statistics for Environmental Scientists (BIOL 562) (4)

563.title: Statistical Analysis in Ecology and Evolution (BIOL 563) (4)

567.description: This course provides an overview of natural and social science approaches to addressing biodiversity conservation and resource management. Concepts and methods from population biology, evolutionary ecology, community ecology, and conservation biology will be complemented with approaches from common property theory, indigenous resource management, and human evolutionary ecology.
567.title: Ecological Analyses and Application (3)

569.description: Required preparation, previous course work in ecology. Permission of the instructor. Topics vary but focus on interdisciplinary problems facing humans and/or the environment. May be repeated for credit.
569.title: Current Issues in Ecology (3)

580.description: Examines the interplay of science and economics in the design of environmental markets. The first part introduces the principles of environmental economics. The second part considers several case studies that illustrate the critical role that scientific models of natural systems play in the design of environmental markets.
580.title: Environmental Markets: Science and Economics (3)

581.description: Water resources demand-supply relationships, United States water resource and related water quality policy, legal structure for water allocation, planning, project and program evaluation, and pricing. Strategies for coping with floods, droughts, and climate change will be explored. Extensive use of case studies.
581.title: Water Resource Planning and Policy Analysis (3)

586.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101 and MATH 231. Introduction to the management of water quality at the local and basinwide scales. Topics include theory and management frameworks; state and federal statutes and programs; water contaminants, their fate and transport; alternatives for improving and protecting water quality; and the technologies and management practices of selected basinwide comprehensive strategies.
586.title: Water Quality Policies and Planning (3)

593.description: Focuses on the interface between environment and society by examining the relationship between science and management practices. Students receive classroom lecture and then go into the field to see what role the ideas actually have in management practices. Students also learn from an active professional working in the topic area.
593.title: Environmental Practicum (1–3)

602.description: The goal of this course is to help students who intend to become professional ecologists or biologists acquire critical skills and strategies needed for achieving their career goals.
602.title: Professional Development Skills for Ecologists and Biologists (BIOL 602) (3)

675.title: Environmental Communication and the Public Sphere (COMM 675) (3)

685.description: Prerequisite, ECON 310. Theory and methods of environmental economics. Topics covered include cost-benefit analysis and environmental policy analysis, economic concept of sustainability, optimal use of natural resources, nonmarket valuation, and economic instruments.
685.title: Environmental and Resource Economics (3)

686.title: Policy Instruments for Environmental Management (ENVR 686, PLAN 686, PLCY 686) (3)

694H.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Independent project leading to the honors designation. Includes weekly research seminar.
694H.title: Honors Project in Environmental Sciences and Studies (3)

89.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
89.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

100.description: Required for incoming students with SAT I Writing scores of 460 or lower. Provides frequent practice in writing, from short paragraphs to longer papers, focusing on analysis and argument. Workshop format.
100.title: Basic Writing (3)

105.description: This college-level course focuses on written and oral argumentation, composition, research, information literacy, and rhetorical analysis. The course introduces students to the specific disciplinary contexts for written work and oral presentations required in college courses. Students may not receive credit for both ENGL 102 and 105.
105.title: English Composition and Rhetoric (3)

105I.description: This college-level course focuses on written and oral argumentation, composition, research, information literacy, and rhetorical analysis. The course introduces students to one specific disciplinary context for written work and oral presentations required in college courses: natural sciences, social sciences, humanities, law, business, or medicine.
105I.title: English Composition and Rhetoric (Interdisciplinary) (3)

110.description: Students receiving a 4 or 5 on the AP Language and Composition exam receive three hours of elective credit. ENGL 110 does not substitute for the required ENGL 105/105I course.
110.title: Credit for AP English Language and Composition Exam (3)

120.description: Required of English majors. Survey of medieval, Renaissance, and neoclassical periods. Drama, poetry, and prose.
120.title: British Literature, Medieval to 18th Century (3)

122.description: Representative authors from the time of European colonization of the New World through the 20th century.
122.title: Introduction to American Literature (3)

123.description: Novels and shorter fiction by Defoe, Austen, Dickens, Faulkner, Wolfe, Fitzgerald, Joyce, and others.
123.title: Introduction to Fiction (3)

124.description: The literature of the present generation.
124.title: Contemporary Literature (3)

125.description: A course designed to develop basic skills in reading poems from all periods of English and American literature.
125.title: Introduction to Poetry (3)

126.description: Drama of the Greek, Renaissance, and modern periods.
126.title: Introduction to Drama (3)

127.description: Course emphasizes literature, critical thinking, and the writing process. Students learn how thinking, reading, and writing relate to one another by studying poetry, fiction, drama, art, music, and film.
127.title: Writing about Literature (3)

128.description: A study of approximately six major American authors drawn from Emerson, Thoreau, Hawthorne, Melville, Stowe, Whitman, Clemens, Dickinson, Chesnutt, James, Eliot, Stein, Hemingway, O’Neill, Faulkner, Hurston, or others.
128.title: Major American Authors (3)

129.description: Studies in African American, Asian American, Hispanic American, Native American, Anglo-Indian, Caribbean, gay-lesbian, and other literatures written in English.
129.title: Literature and Cultural Diversity (3)

130.description: Sophomores only. A course in reading and writing fiction. Close study of a wide range of short stories; emphasis on technical problems. Class criticism and discussion of student exercises and stories.
130.title: Introduction to Fiction Writing (3)

131.description: Sophomores only. A course in reading and writing poems. Close study of a wide range of published poetry and of poetic terms and techniques. Composition, discussion, and revision of original student poems.
131.title: Introduction to Poetry Writing (3)

132H.description: First-year honors students only. A close study of the craft of the short story and novella through a wide range of reading, with emphasis on technical strategies. Class discussion of student exercises and stories.
132H.title: First-Year Honors: Introduction to Fiction Writing (3)

133H.description: First-year honors students only. A close study of a wide range of published poems and of the basic terms and techniques of poetry. Composition, discussion, and revision of a number of original poems.
133H.title: First-Year Honors: Introduction to Poetry Writing (3)

134H.description: First-year honors students only. This course focuses on women’s life writing, including autobiography, biography, autoethnography, personal essay. Includes theories of life writing. Students will read contemporary works in each genre and write their own versions.
134H.title: First-Year Honors: Women’s Lives (3)

135H.description: First-year honors students only. Study of literary forms (epic, drama, lyric, novel), beginning in the fall term and concluding in the spring, with three hours credit for each term. Students should consult the assistant dean for honors or the Department of English and Comparative Literaturefor offerings.
135H.title: First-Year Honors: Types of Literature (3)

137.description: In this course students learn to study emergent relationships between print and digital literary cultures. In addition to reading and discussion, the course requires that students conduct original research (individual and also collaborative) in both print and digital formats.
137.title: Literature in a Digital Age: Books, E-books, and the Literary Marketplace (3)

138.description: A course in reading and writing creative nonfiction, prose based in fact, but treated in a literary manner, e.g., personal essays, travel narratives, science and nature writing, immersive interviews and profiles, reportage, and belles-lettres. Composition, class discussion, and revision of work written for this class.
138.title: Introduction to Creative Nonfiction (3)

139.description: This course provides a systematic introduction to the field of sexuality studies, using a broad range of disciplinary perspectives to study human sexuality in its various functions and forms.
139.title: Currents in Sexuality Studies (3)

140.description: Introduces students to concepts in queer theory and recent sexuality studies. Topics include queer lit, AIDS, race and sexuality, representations of gays and lesbians in the media, political activism/literature.
140.title: Introduction to Gay and Lesbian Culture and Literature (WMST 140) (3)

141.description: This course will be a basic introduction to literatures in English from Africa, the Caribbean, South Asia, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, and other Anglophone literary traditions.
141.title: World Literatures in English (3)

142.description: This course offers an introduction to the technical, formal, and narrative elements of the cinema.
142.title: Film Analysis (3)

143.description: Examines the ways culture shapes and is shaped by film. This course uses comparative methods to contrast films as historic or contemporary, mainstream or cutting-edge, in English or a foreign language, etc.
143.title: Film and Culture (3)

144.description: Introductory course on popular literary genres. Students will read and discuss works in the area of mystery, romance, westerns, science fiction, children’s literature, and horror fiction.
144.title: Popular Genres (3)

145.description: Studies in genres including drama, poetry, prose fiction, or nonfiction prose, examining form, comparing that genre to others (including popular genres), placing works within a tradition or a critical context.
145.title: Literary Genres (3)

146.description: Readings in and theories of science fiction, utopian and dystopian literatures, and fantasy fiction.
146.title: Science Fiction/Fantasy/Utopia (3)

147.description: Studies in classic and contemporary mystery and detective fiction.
147.title: Mystery Fiction (3)

148.description: From its origins in Gothic and pre-Gothic literatures and arts, this course examines the complexities and pleasures of horror. Topics include psychology, aesthetics, politics, allegory, ideology, and ethics.
148.title: Horror (3)

150.description: Sophomore English majors only. This course (or ENGL 121) is required of English majors. Introduces students to methods of literary study. Students learn to read and interpret a range of literary works, develop written and oral arguments about literature, and conduct literary research.
150.title: Introductory Seminar in Literary Studies (3)

191.description: Introduces students to the field of literary studies while emphasizing a single writer, group, movement, theme, or period. Students conduct research, develop readings, and compose literary interpretations.
191.title: Introduction to Literary Studies (3)

202.description: An introduction to the study of creativity and aesthetic expression in everyday life, considering both traditional genres and contemporary innovations in the material, verbal, and musical arts.
202.title: Introduction to Folklore (ANTH 202, FOLK 202) (3)

206.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 130 or 132H. Permission of the program director. Substantial practice in those techniques employed in introductory course. A workshop devoted to the extensive writing of fiction (at least two short stories), with an emphasis on style, structure, dramatic scene, and revision.
206.title: Intermediate Fiction Writing (3)

207.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 131 or 133H. Permission of the program director. An intensification of the introductory class. A workshop devoted to close examination of selected exemplary poems and the students’ own poetry, with an emphasis on regular writing and revising.
207.title: Intermediate Poetry Writing (3)

208.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 130, 131, 132H, or 133H. Permission of the program director. A course in reading and writing creative nonfiction, focusing on three of its most important forms, including the personal essay, travel writing, and writing on the natural world.
208.title: Reading and Writing Creative Nonfiction (3)

209.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 130, 131, 132H, or 133H. Permission of the program director. A course in reading and writing children’s fiction, focusing on five important forms: folk tale, fairy tale, picture book, young adult, and biography.
209.title: Reading and Writing Children’s Fiction (3)

210.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 130, 131, 132H, or 133H. Permission of the program director. A course in reading and writing young adult fiction, with a focus on the crafting of a novel.
210.title: Writing Young Adult Literature (3)

216.description: Introduction to the study of rhetoric, composition, and digital literacy. Students will survey the history of the discipline of rhetoric and composition, from its roots in ancient rhetoric to its current status, practice different approaches to composing, and/or perform rhetorical criticism and analysis of texts, images, and multimedia.
216.title: Introduction to Rhetoric and Composition (3)

225.description: A survey of representative comedies, tragedies, histories, and romances by William Shakespeare.
225.title: Shakespeare (3)

226.description: A survey of Renaissance drama focusing on contemporaries and successors of Shakespeare during the Elizabethan and Jacobean periods.
226.title: Renaissance Drama (3)

227.description: Poetry and prose of the earlier Renaissance, including More, Wyatt, Sidney, Spenser, Bacon, and Marlowe.
227.title: Literature of the Earlier Renaissance (3)

228.description: Poetry and prose from the late Elizabethan years through the “century of revolution” into the Restoration period after 1660: Donne, Jonson, Bacon, Herbert, Burton, Browne, Marvell, Herrick, and others.
228.title: Literature of the Later Renaissance (3)

229.description: This course introduces students to a variety of Renaissance English texts authored by women. Topics include historical perspectives on women and gender and methodological approaches to Renaissance feminist study.
229.title: Renaissance Women Writers (3)

230.description: A study of Milton’s prose and poetry in the extraordinary context of 17th-century philosophy, politics, religion, science, and poetics, and against the backdrop of the English Civil War.
230.title: Milton (3)

240.description: An introductory exploration of key topics in the literatures of the Caribbean basin, Bermuda, and the Caribbean diaspora.
240.title: Caribbean Literature (3)

246.description: Students will develop a working knowledge of American Indian cultural concepts and historical perspectives utilizing poetry, history, personal account, short stories, films, and novels.
246.title: Introduction to American Indian Literatures (3)

260.description: Practice of “close reading” over a diverse selection of novels, short stories, and lyric poems. Intended for students who have declared, or who will soon declare, the English major.
260.title: Creative Reading (3)

261.description: An introduction to literary criticism in English studies, with an emphasis on historical developments from Plato to the present.
261.title: An Introduction to Literary Criticism (3)

262.description: Studies in the diversity within and between African American, Asian American, Latina/o, Native American, Anglo-Indian, Caribbean, GLBTQ, feminist, proletarian, and other literatures in English. Intended for English majors.
262.title: Literature and Cultural Difference (3)

263.description: Intensive study, focused on gender issues of criticism and writing.
263.title: Literature and Gender (WMST 263) (3)

264.description: A literary and cultural critical examination of the role sex plays within the creation, consumption, and regulation of literature.
264.title: Literature and Sexuality (3)

265.description: Considers texts in a comparative ethnic/race studies framework and examines how these texts explore historical and contemporary connections between groups of people in the United States and the Americas.
265.title: Literature and Race, Literature and Ethnicity (3)

266.description: Introductory exploration of the relation between science and literature, as well as the place and value of both in the contemporary world.
266.title: Science and Literature (3)

267.description: This interdisciplinary course will examine what it means to grow up Latina/o through an exploration of childhood narratives, linguistic debates, education policies and legislation, and censored books.
267.title: Growing Up Latina/o (3)

268.description: An introduction to key topics that focus on questions of representation at the intersections of medicine, literature, and culture.
268.title: Medicine, Literature, and Culture (3)

269.description: This course will introduce students to the key critical concepts, debates, and questions of practice in the emerging scholarly field of disability studies.
269.title: Introduction to Disability Studies (3)

270.description: This course introduces students to the study of Asian American literature and culture. The focus of the course may include examining coming-of-age novels, immigration narratives, or other genre explorations.
270.title: Studies in Asian American Literature (3)

271.description: This service-learning course is partnered with a charter school, and together UNC–Chapel Hill and high school students will explore issues of race in American literature and culture.
271.title: Mixed-Race America: Race in Contemporary American Literature and Culture (3)

278.description: This course introduces major texts and current themes, from Joyce to the postcolonial, in Irish writing from 1800 to 2000.
278.title: Irish Writing, 1800–2000 (3)

281.description: This course investigates the rich and complex relationship between literature and other mass media.
281.title: Literature and Media (3)

282.description: Students will analyze various types of travel literature, such as voyage, pilgrimage, and tour, in terms of literary conventions, historical conditions, and considerations of gender, ethnicity, economics, empire, and religion.
282.title: Travel Literature (3)

283.description: Exploration of different forms of life writing such as autobiography, biography, and autoethnography. Readings will include theories of autobiography and selected literature.
283.title: Life Writing (3)

284.description: An overview of the tradition of children’s literature, considering the ways those books point to our basic assumptions about meaning, culture, self, society, gender, economics.
284.title: Reading Children’s Literature (3)

285.description: A survey of Greek and Roman epic and lyric poetry, literary criticism and philosophy designed for the undergraduate English major.
285.title: Classical Backgrounds in English Literature (3)

286.description: Introduction to the field of nature writing surveys historical periods, authors, and a variety of genres; cross-cultural and multidisciplinary; study of classics in the field.
286.title: Nature Writing (AMST 286) (3)

287.description: This course will examine themes of homoeroticism, gender identity, class relations, and the changes in cultural norms precipitated by World War I in literary works by British men.
287.title: Another Country: Homoeroticism in British Literature (3)

288.description: In this course students will read early 20th-century poetry, fiction, films, and criticism, and consider the ways these works constituted, defined, and challenged the phenomenon known as literary modernism.
288.title: Literary Modernism (3)

289.description: Through readings in a wide range of genres, this course will examine major factors and influences shaping Jewish American literature and culture in the 20th century.
289.title: Jewish American Literature and Culture of the 20th Century (JWST 289) (3)

291.description: An investigation of children’s picture books within the context of illustrated texts in Britain and America.
291.title: Children’s Picture Books: Texts and Illustration (3)

300.description: Advanced practice with critical, argumentative, and analytic writing, including forms of theessay. Special attention to style, voice, and genre.
300.title: Advanced Expository Writing (3)

300I.description: Advanced practice with critical, argumentative, and analytic writing, including the essay. Special attention to writing in the disciplines of life and applied sciences, social sciences (including business), and humanities.
300I.title: Advanced Expository Writing (Interdisciplinary) (3)

301.description: Advanced practice with the oral and written discourse of the humanities. Special attention to disciplinary rhetoric, style, genre, format, and citation.
301.title: Advanced Expository Writing for the Humanities (3)

302.description: Advanced practice with the oral and written discourse of the social sciences. Special attention to disciplinary rhetoric, style, genre, format, and citation.
302.title: Advanced Expository Writing for the Social Sciences (3)

303.description: Advanced practice with the oral and written discourse of the natural sciences. Special attention to disciplinary rhetoric, style, genre, format, and citation.
303.title: Advanced Expository Writing for the Natural Sciences (3)

304.description: Advanced practice with business and professional oral and written discourse. Special attention to disciplinary rhetoric, style, genre, format, and citation.
304.title: Advanced Expository Writing for Business (3)

305.description: Advanced practice with legal oral and written discourse. Special attention to disciplinary rhetoric, style, genre, format, and citation.
305.title: Advanced Expository Writing for Law (3)

306.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 130, 131, 132H, or 133H. Permission of the program director. A workshop for people interested in writing plays, focusing on elements that make them work on stage, such as characterization, climax, dialogue, exposition, momentum, setting, and visual effects.
306.title: Playwriting (3)

307.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 130, 131, 132H, or 133H. Permission of the program director. Creative writing minors only. An occasional intermediate course that may focus on such topics as living writers, poetic forms, and imitation, but which is offered every fall as Gram-o-Rama, the study of language and grammar as stylistic tools.
307.title: Studies in Fiction and Poetry: Stylistics (3)

313.description: An introductory course in descriptive English linguistics that studies the sounds, word-building processes, and sentence structures of current English as well as general notions of correctness and variation.
313.title: Grammar of Current English (3)

314.description: A study of the development of English from its Proto-Indo-European origins to modern English, with emphasis on how events and contacts with other languages influenced the vocabulary of English.
314.title: History of the English Language (3)

315.description: (3). A historical and critical examination of regional, social, and stylistic variation in English in the United States, including correctness, legal and educational issues, and the influence of mass media.
315.title: English in the U

316.description: Examines histories of rhetorical theory and practice. Students will develop original research projects that expand our understanding of rhetorical traditions. Historical periods, critical perspectives, genres, and topics will vary.
316.title: Rhetorical Traditions (3)

317.description: This class explores writing in contemporary networked composing spaces. The course focuses on developing writing projects that study and participate in online social networks. Topics include the rhetoric of the Internet; collaboration online; information ethics; amateur content creation; networks and social interaction; networks and literacy; and remix composition.
317.title: Networked Composition (3)

318.description: This class studies composing in a variety of modes, including visuals, moving images, gestures, sounds, and words. Students develop projects using image, audio, and video editors, examining how multimedia fits within the history of rhetoric and writing and relates with concerns such as purposes, audiences, contexts, arguments, genres, and mediums.
318.title: Multimodal Composition (3)

319.description: An introduction to English literature from the eighth to the 15th century, focusing on the primary works of Old English and Middle English literature.
319.title: Introduction to Medieval English Literature, excluding Chaucer (3)

320.description: An introduction to Chaucer’s major poetry: Troilus and Criseyde, the “dream” poems (e.g., Parliament of Fowls) and The Canterbury Tales.
320.title: Chaucer (3)

321.description: Representative examples of Arthurian literature from the Middle Ages and 19th and 20th centuries, with some attention to film, art, and music.
321.title: Medieval and Modern Arthurian Romance (CMPL 321) (3)

322.description: A study of the external literary influences which shaped Old and Middle English, notably the vernacular literatures of England’s Celtic neighbors (Wales, Brittany, Scotland, and Ireland) and/or France.
322.title: Medieval England and Its Literary Neighbors (3)

325.description: This course explores the wide range of drama produced in England between the 1570s and 1640s, including work by Shakespeare and his many rivals.
325.title: Shakespeare and His Contemporaries (3)

326.description: This course traces the historical evolution/devolution of Renaissance literary genres. Each offering will focus on a single generic kind or set of kinds.
326.title: Renaissance Genres (3)

327.description: A focused study of one or two intellectual movements of the Renaissance through the literary and nonliterary texts of the period.
327.title: Renaissance Literature and Its Intellectual Contexts (3)

328.description: This course involves the detailed study of a substantial author of the English Renaissance, such as Sidney, Spenser, Marlowe, Raleigh, Bacon, Jonson, Donne, Browne, or Herbert.
328.title: Renaissance Authors (3)

330.description: Students will study Renaissance literature while assessing the usefulness and status of a theoretical approach, such as feminist theory, queer theory, cultural materialism, new historicism, or psychoanalytic theory.
330.title: Perspectives on the Renaissance (3)

331.description: A survey of British literature from Dryden to Paine.
331.title: 18th-Century Literature (3)

332.description: A survey of Restoration and 18thcentury drama from Etheredge to Sheridan.
332.title: 18th-Century Drama (3)

333.description: A survey of 18th-century fiction from Behn to Austen.
333.title: 18th-Century Fiction (3)

337.description: This course examines the technical and aesthetic revolutions in the fine arts of the English Romantic Period, focusing on lyrical poetry, landscape painting, and original printmaking and works by Wordsworth, Turner, and Blake.
337.title: The Romantic Revolution in the Arts (3)

338.description: Important novelists in the tradition, from Austen to Wilde.
338.title: 19th-Century British Novel (3)

339.description: Covers the history of the British theater, 1780 to 1840, with representative plays and closet dramas by playwrights such as Holcroft, Cowley, Inchbald, Baillie, Coleridge, P.B. Shelley, and Byron.
339.title: English Romantic-Period Drama (3)

340.description: This course focuses on both the novels of Jane Austen and their fate since publication in the early 19th century. They have inspired countless imitations, over 150 sequels and continuations, and more than 30 full-length films. We will trace the transmission and transformation of the original texts across time and cultures.
340.title: Studies in Jane Austen (3)

343.description: Selected topics or authors in American literature from the period of European colonization of the New World through the onset of the Civil War.
343.title: American Literature before 1860 (3)

344.description: Instructors choose authors or topics from the period 1860 to 1900. The course may be organized chronologically or thematically but is not intended as a survey.
344.title: American Literature, 1860–1900 (3)

345.description: Instructors choose authors or topics from the period 1900 to 2000. The course may be organized chronologically or thematically but is not intended as a survey.
345.title: American Literature, 1900–2000 (3)

347.description: The development of the American novel from the late 18th century through the 20th century. May proceed chronologically or thematically.
347.title: The American Novel (3)

348.description: Content of course varies with instructor, but students are given a sense of the chronological, stylistic, and thematic development of American poetry over two centuries.
348.title: American Poetry (3)

350.description: Poetry in English from the middle of the 19th century to the present, approached historically, thematically, technically, politically, and aesthetically; concentration on analysis, comparison, and synthesis.
350.title: 20th-Century British and American Poetry (3)

351.description: The course focuses on modern drama in English. Most of the plays will come from the British and American theaters, though a few may exemplify the European background of modern drama or the colonial reach of the English language.
351.title: British and American Drama of the 20th Century (3)

353.description: This course will examine literature written in English by women, focusing on issues of style and genre and their relation to gender.
353.title: Modern Women’s Literature (3)

355.description: Students will read novels in English, including Joyce, Woolf, and Proust, to explore how writers from across cultures created new strategies to represent the late 19thand 20th-century worlds of imperialism, science, and experiment.
355.title: The British Novel from 1870 to World War II (3)

356.description: Course studies contemporary British and American fiction through representative works. Intellectual and aesthetic, historical and cultural emphases. May include works from the Anglophone diaspora.
356.title: British and American Fiction since World War II (3)

357.description: This course examines factors shaping British/Commonwealth literature in the 20th century, especially the world wars and the dismantling of the British Empire. We will investigate themes of both nostalgia and anticipation: ways of remembering the past of England and the Empire, and of describing the future of British culture(s).
357.title: 20th-Century British Literature and Culture (3)

359.description: This course introduces students to United States Latina feminist theories, literatures, and cultures. Through a blend of genres, students explore historical foundations of Latina feminisms, examining the relationship between Latina feminisms and United States Third World feminisms, and analyze literary and cultural representations of feminist praxis.
359.title: Latina Feminisms (3)

360.description: This course will explore contemporary Asian American literature and theory and will examine how Asian American literature fits into, yet extends beyond, the canon of American literature.
360.title: Contemporary Asian American Literature and Theory (ASIA 360) (3)

361.description: This course covers writings by Asian American women and examines issues of gender, race, and sexuality.
361.title: Asian American Women’s Writing (3)

363.description: Theories of feminist criticism in relation to general theory and women’s writing.
363.title: Feminist Literary Theory (WMST 363) (3)

364.description: Introduction to the major questions within Latina/o studies in terms of transnationalism, transculturation, ethnicity, race, class, gender, sexuality, systems of value, and aesthetics.
364.title: Introduction to Latina/o Studies (3)

365.description: Covers literary works associated with one or more of the major historical migrations, forced and voluntary, and present-day works engaged with globalization.
365.title: Migration and Globalization (3)

366.description: Course examines relationship of literature to the other arts, especially music and the visual arts, in terms of similar period characteristics, distinct material, and formal constraints.
366.title: Literature and the Other Arts (3)

367.description: Survey of writers and literary and cultural traditions from the beginning of African American literature to 1930.
367.title: African American Literature to 1930 (3)

368.description: Survey of writers and literary and cultural traditions from 1930 to 1970.
368.title: African American Literature, 1930–1970 (3)

369.description: Survey of writers and literary and cultural traditions from 1970 to the present.
369.title: African American Literature, 1970 to the Present (3)

370.description: This interdisciplinary course explores how issues of health, medicine, and illness are impacted by questions of race in 20th-century American literature and popular culture. Specific areas covered include pain, death, the family and society, reproduction, mental illness, aging, human subject experimentation, the doctor-patient relationship, pesticides, and bioethics.
370.title: Race, Health, and Narrative (3)

371.description: This course will consider the themes of globalization and regionalismthrough an examination of narratives featuring Asians/Asian Americans in the American South.
371.title: The Place of Asian Americans in Southern Literature (3)

373.description: An introduction to Southern literature, with emphasis on 20th-century fiction, poetry, drama, and essays. Representative authors include Faulkner, Wolfe, Williams, Warren, Hurston, Wright, Ransom, Tate, Welty, Chappell, McCullers, O’Connor.
373.title: Southern American Literature (3)

374.description: The study of fiction, poetry, plays, and essays by Southern American women writers of the past 200 years, continuing to the present.
374.title: Southern Women Writers (WMST 374) (3)

375.description: A study of the novels, short stories, and poems produced by North Carolina writers during the literary renaissance of recent decades.
375.title: Contemporary North Carolina Literature (3)

376.description: This course considers a range of texts, including children’s literature, to focus on the aesthetic, historical, and social factors grounding depictions of childhood. Other material includes literature and visual texts in various forms. The course stresses original student research.
376.title: Depictions of Childhood in Literature and the Visual Arts (3)

377.description: A broad survey of the cultures of the Celtic-speaking areas, notably Ireland, Wales, Scotland, and Brittany, with special emphasis on language and literature.
377.title: Introduction to the Celtic Cultures (3)

379.description: Twentieth-century Irish prose is committed to experiment in form, language and representation, gauging cultural pressure from James Joyce to Roddy Doyle.
379.title: Irish Prose from Joyce to Doyle (3)

380.description: The course offers an introduction to the history of cinema and, in particular, to a period of film history.
380.title: Film History (3)

381.description: The course introduces students to the complex narrative and rhetorical relationship between literature and cinema.
381.title: Literature and Cinema (3)

383.description: An introduction to the many forms of creative nonfiction by contemporary writers. Will include nonfiction literature as well as theoretical and critical responses to such literature.
383.title: Literary Nonfiction (3)

384.description: In this course students will discuss the formation and evolution of lesbian identities as manifested in novels in English in the 20th century.
384.title: The Lesbian Novel (3)

385.description: Explores various connections of literature and law, including literary depictions of crime, lawyers, and trials; literary conventions of legal documents; and/or shared problems in interpretation of law and literature.
385.title: Literature and Law (3)

387.description: A study of Canadian literature in English from the late 18th century to the present, with emphasis on 20th-century writing and on the novel.
387.title: Canadian Literature (3)

388.description: What was modernism? When was modernism? Where was modernism? Reading literature and visual art from 1890 to 1940 in Europe, America, and Africa will be key to finding answers.
388.title: Modernism: Movements and Moments (3)

389.description: This course introduces students to the aims and concerns of authorship study in film through discussion of a major filmmaker’s body of work. The course may focus predominantly on a single figure or may compare two or more figures who share certain affinities of theme or style.
389.title: Major Film Directors (3)

390.description: An intensive study of a single writer, group, movement, theme, or period.
390.title: Studies in Literary Topics (3)

396.description: Permission of the department. Intensive reading on a particular topic under the supervision of a member of the staff.
396.title: Directed Readings in English or Creative Writing (3)

400.description: This course combines frequent writing practice with discussions of rhetorical theories and strategies for teaching writing. The course examines ways to design effective writing courses, assignments, and instructional materials.
400.title: Advanced Composition for Teachers (3)

401.description: This course combines frequent writing practice with an introduction to teaching writing and reading in the elementary grades. Students explore composition theory and learn about effective practices for improving writing.
401.title: Advanced Composition for Elementary Teachers (3)

402.description: This course considers learning to write from three vantage points: personal, social, and contextual. Emphasis on theory, reflective practice, and pedagogy for peer tutoring.
402.title: Investigations in Academic Writing (3)

405.description: Focuses on producing writing in a particular genre or form such as personal essay, autobiography, or creative nonfiction.
405.title: Writing Literary Genres (3)

406.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 206. Permission of the program director. A continuation of the intermediate workshop with emphasis on the short story, novella, and novel. Extensive discussion of student work in class and in conferences with instructor.
406.title: Advanced Fiction Writing (3)

407.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 207. Permission of the program director. A continuation of the intermediate workshop, with increased writing and revising of poems. Extensive discussion of student poetry in class and in conferences with instructor.
407.title: Advanced Poetry Writing (3)

410.description: This course provides a history of documentary cinema since the beginnings of the medium and surveys different modes and theoretical definitions; or the course may focus largely on a certain mode (such as ethnographic, observational, firstperson, cinema vérité, politically activist, found footage compilation, or journalistic investigation).
410.title: Documentary Film (3)

418.description: Focused study of a specific subfield or issue of current or historical English linguistics not covered in depth in other courses, e.g., dictionaries, North Carolina dialects, language of advertising.
418.title: The English Language—Contemporary Issues (3)

423.description: This course investigates themes or issues in Old English literature, thought, and culture.
423.title: Old English Literature—Contemporary Issues (3)

424.description: This course investigates themes or issues in Middle English literature, thought, and culture.
424.title: Middle English Literature—Contemporary Issues (3)

430.description: This course investigates cultural themes or problems across a wide spectrum of Renaissance authors.
430.title: Renaissance Literature—Contemporary Issues (3)

436.description: Focuses on particular forms, authors, or issues in the period.
436.title: Contemporary Approaches to 18th-Century Literature and Culture (3)

437.description: Survey of works by Blake, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Byron, Percy and Mary Shelley, Keats, and others.
437.title: Chief British Romantic Writers (3)

438.description: An investigation of important texts by 19th-century women writers that considers issues of gender in relation to other important considerations—tradition, form, culture—with an introduction to the chief scholarly and critical problems of this period.
438.title: 19th-Century Women Writers (3)

439.description: Poetry and prose of the Victorian period, including such writers as Tennyson, the Brownings, Arnold, the Brontës, Dickens, G. Eliot.
439.title: English Literature, 1832–1890 (3)

440.description: The Pre-Raphaelites, Wilde, Conrad, Shaw, and Yeats.
440.title: English Literature, 1850–1910 (3)

441.description: Devoted to British Romantic-period literature’s engagement with a literary mode (such as the Gothic) or a historical theme (such as war or abolition) or to an individual author.
441.title: Romantic Literature—Contemporary Issues (3)

442.description: The study of an individual Victorian writer, a group (such as the Pre-Raphaelites), a theme (such as imperialism), or genre (such as Victorian epic or the serialized novel).
442.title: Victorian Literature—Contemporary Issues (3)

443.description: A junioror senior-level course devoted to in-depth exploration of an author, group of authors, or topic in American literature to 1860.
443.title: American Literature before 1860—Contemporary Issues (3)

444.description: Intensive study of one or more authors or a topic in American literature from the Civil War through 1900.
444.title: American Literature, 1860–1900—Contemporary Issues (3)

445.description: A junioror senior-level course devoted to in-depth exploration of an author, group of authors, or a topic in American literature from 1900 to 2000.
445.title: American Literature, 1900–2000—Contemporary Issues (3)

446.description: American women authors from the beginnings to the present.
446.title: American Women Authors (WMST 446) (3)

447.description: This course brings together theories of collective and individual memory with questions of aesthetics and narrative while exploring global connections between memory and literature.
447.title: Memory and Literature (3)

462.description: This course introduces the student to historical and contemporary thinking about poetry and poetic language. Examines the place of poetry in theoretical thinking and theoretical thinking about poetry.
462.title: Contemporary Poetry and Theory (3)

463.description: This course is a multigenre introduction to postcolonial literatures. Topics will include postcolonial Englishes, nationalism, anti-imperialism, postcolonial education, and the intersections between national and gender identities in literature.
463.title: Postcolonial Literature (3)

464.description: The literary and cultural critical arts of gay, lesbian, bisexual, transvestite, and other communities of sexual dissidents of the contemporary United states, United Kingdom, and other Anglophone cultures.
464.title: Queer Texts, Queer Cultures (3)

465.description: Examines interrelations between cultural difference, aesthetic form, and the representation, production, and conveyance of subjectivity (in particular affect or states of feeling) in texts, other media, and material culture.
465.title: Difference, Aesthetics, and Affect (3)

466.description: Examines current issues in literary theory such as the question of authorship, the relation of literary texts to cultural beliefs and values, and to the formation of identities.
466.title: Literary Theory—Contemporary Issues (3)

472.description: Study of particular aspects of African American literature, such as the work of a major writer or group of writers, an important theme, a key tradition, or a literary period.
472.title: African American Literature—Contemporary Issues (3)

475.description: The study of a particular topic or genre in the literature of the United States South, more focused than students will find in ENGL 373.
475.title: Southern Literature—Contemporary Issues (3)

481.description: This course investigates the ramifications of the development of mass media and popular culture, paying special attention to the transformation of literature.
481.title: Media Theory (3)

486.description: Multidisciplinary, thematic investigations into topics in literature and environment that cut across boundaries of history, genre, and culture. Junior/senior level.
486.title: Literature and Environment (3)

487.description: The study of three genres of folk narrative (fairytale, personal narrative, and legend) and their distinctive roles in contemporary life.
487.title: Folk Narrative (FOLK 487) (3)

489.description: The student will have an opportunity to concentrate on topics and texts central to the study of culture and theory.
489.title: Cultural Studies—Contemporary Issues (3)

490.description: Permission of the program director. Creative writing minors only. An occasional advanced course, which may focus on such topics as advanced creative nonfiction, editing and publishing, the lyric in song and collaboration between lyricists and composers, the one-act play, and short-short fiction.
490.title: Creative Writing Special Topics (3)

496.description: Permission of the department. Recommended for students in junior or senior year of study. Intensive mentored research, service learning, field work, creative work, or internship. Requires 30 hours of research, writing, or experiential activities, or 100 hours of internship work, culminating in a written project.
496.title: Independent Research (1–3)

50.description: Each student will complete a service-learning internship and compose a multimedia documentary about the experience using original text, photos, audio, and video.
50.title: First-Year Seminar: Multimedia North Carolina (3)

52.description: How do computers change the study of literature? How do images tell stories? How is writing evolving through photo essays, collages, and digital video? Students investigate these and related questions.
52.title: First-Year Seminar: Computers and English Studies (3)

525.description: Seniors only. Senior-level survey of one or two key themes or issues in the literature of the English Renaissance.
525.title: Senior Seminar in Renaissance Literature (3)

53.description: The seminar’s purpose is to explore the African American slave narrative tradition from its 19th-century origins in autobiography to its present manifestations in prize-winning fiction and film.
53.title: First-Year Seminar: Slavery and Freedom in African American Literature and Film (3)

54.description: Examination of literary and cinematic works that expose the cultural impact World War I had on contemporary and future generations.
54.title: First-Year Seminar: The War to End All Wars? The First World War and the Modern World (3)

55.description: This first-year seminar emphasizes contemporary autobiographical writing by and about women. Students investigate questions of self and identity by reading and writing four genres of life writing: autobiography, autoethnography, biography, and personal essay. Both traditional written and new media composing formats will be practiced.
55.title: First-Year Seminar: Reading and Writing Women’s Lives (3)

56.description: The course covers a range of fictions about colonialism and its aftermath, exploring both narrative and filmic depictions of empire and its legacies.
56.title: First-Year Seminar: Projections of Empire: Colonial and Postcolonial Fiction and Film (3)

57.description: This class will investigate the forms and cultural functions of science fiction using films, books, and computer-based fictional spaces (Internet, video games, etc.).
57.title: First-Year Seminar: Future Perfect: Science Fictions and Social Form (3)

58.description: Latina/o Short Fiction (3). Course will examine the aesthetic and cultural functions and implications of textual images of photography and photographs in United States Latina/o short stories from the 1960s to the present.
58.title: First-Year Seminar: The Doubled Image: Photography in U

580.description: This course is designed to introduce students to a particular historical or cultural aspect of the cinema.
580.title: Film—Contemporary Issues (3)

583.description: Offered as part of summer study abroad programs in Oxford, London, and Stratford-on-Avon. Students experience plays in performance and as texts, and discuss their literary, dramatic, cultural, and historical aspects.
583.title: Drama on Location (3)

600.description: The course, restricted to graduate students in English, offers students practice writing vitae and job application letters, grant or conference proposals, dissertation or thesis chapters, book reviews, or journal articles.
600.title: Advanced Expository Writing (3)

601.description: Designed to help international graduate students improve skills in academic writing. Attention to organization, flow, and presentation of an academic paper.
601.title: Academic Writing for International Students (3)

603.description: Designed to help international graduate students refine oral communication skills in academic contexts. Attention to pronunciation, participating in group discussions, and making presentations.
603.title: Oral Communication for International Students (1–3)

605.description: A survey of major figures in the history of rhetoric, beginning with classical rhetoric, but emphasizing contemporary rhetorical theory.
605.title: History of Rhetoric and Composition (3)

606.description: A study of rhetorical theories and practices from classical to modern times. Emphasis is on translation of theories into instructional practice for teaching in the college writing classroom.
606.title: Rhetorical Theory and Practice (3)

607.description: Introduction to theories of teaching writing in the disciplines for graduate instructors. Students will study discipline-specific conventions of argumentation, genre, and style with attention to pedagogical techniques, assignments, and activities.
607.title: Theory and Practice of Writing in the Disciplines (1–3)

610.description: The goal of this course is to develop skills in analyzing the rhetorical construction of scientific claims, with a focus on health and medicine as scientific discourse communities. Topics include the structure, argument, and style of scientific genres; visual and digital rhetorics; and the circulation of scientific rhetoric among publics.
610.title: Science as Literature: Rhetorics of Science and Medicine (3)

611.description: Sociologist Arthur Frank asserts that “whether ill people want to tell stories or not, illness calls for stories.” This seminar explores narrative approaches to suffering, healing, and medicine’s roles in these processes. Students learn literary and anthropological approaches to examine medically themed works from a range of genres.
611.title: Narrative, Literature, and Medicine: Advanced Interdisciplinary Seminar (3)

613.description: A study of current English structure and usage using a traditional approach modified by appropriate contributions from structural and generative grammar, with some attention to the application of linguistics to literary analysis.
613.title: Modern English Grammar (LING 613) (3)

619.description: An introduction to English literature from the eighth to the 15th century, focusing on the primary works of Old English and Middle English literature.
619.title: Survey of Old and Middle English Literature (3)

621.description: British and continental Arthurian literature in translation from the early Middle Ages to Sir Thomas Malory.
621.title: Arthurian Romance (CMPL 621) (3)

625.description: A study of selected plays and poetry by Shakespeare and some of the key critical and theoretical approaches to his work.
625.title: Shakespeare (3)

626.description: A study of a representative group of plays by dramatists writing between the establishment of the permanent theaters in the 1570s and the closing of those theaters in 1642.
626.title: Renaissance Drama (3)

627.description: A graduate-level survey of the literature of the earlier Renaissance in England.
627.title: Literature of the Earlier Renaissance (3)

628.description: In this course, students will interrogate the social, historical, and representational dimensions of 17th-century literature and culture in England.
628.title: Literature of the Later Renaissance (3)

629.description: A study of Milton’s prose and poetry in the extraordinary context of 17th-century philosophy, politics, religion, science, and poetics, and against the backdrop of the English Civil War.
629.title: Milton (3)

63.description: This course will focus on issues of intellectual freedom and censorship, with particular attention to the ways in which these issues are racialized.
63.title: First-Year Seminar: Banned Books (3)

630.description: This course will examine drama written and performed in England from 1570 to 1640, situating Shakespeare’s plays in relation to others in his generation.
630.title: Shakespeare and His Contemporaries (3)

631.description: Studies in a variety of British writers from Rochester to Cowper.
631.title: 18th-Century Literature (3)

637.description: A survey of the major British Romantic writers, including Blake, Wordsworth, Coleridge, Byron, Percy and Mary Shelley, Keats, with an introduction to the chief scholarly and critical problems of this period.
637.title: Chief British Romantic Writers (3)

638.description: An investigation of important texts by 19th-century women writers that considers issues of gender in relation to other important considerations—tradition, form, culture—with an introduction to the chief scholarly and critical problems of this period.
638.title: 19th-Century Women Writers (3)

639.description: Survey of major Victorian writers such as Tennyson, the Brownings, Arnold, Dickens, the Brontës, G. Eliot, Mill, Ruskin.
639.title: Victorian Literature (3)

64.description: An investigation of how the tradition of children’s books addresses and negotiates central questions of existence and conduct, focusing on the ways ethical problems are formed in such literature.
64.title: First-Year Seminar: Ethics and Children’s Literature (3)

643.description: A graduatelevel survey of American literature from the European settlement of the New World through 1860. Consideration of authors in their aesthetic, historical, and contemporary critical contexts.
643.title: Introduction to American Literature to 1860 (3)

644.description: A graduate-level introduction to the range of American writing from the Civil War through 1900. Attention given to major critical concerns, e.g., the cultural force of realism, etc.
644.title: Introduction to American Literature, 1860–1900 (3)

65.description: Students will read more than 100 sonnets, learn the sonnet’s different forms, and relate them to the cultural environments in which they were written over the past four centuries.
65.title: First-Year Seminar: The Sonnet (3)

651.description: A survey of British and American drama, poetry, fiction, and criticism.
651.title: British and American Drama of the 20th Century (3)

657.description: A survey of 20th-century English and American drama, poetry, fiction, and criticism.
657.title: English and American Literature of the 20th Century (3)

659.description: A study of literary works written in English concerning World War I, or the Spanish Civil War and World War II, or the Vietnam War.
659.title: War in 20th-Century Literature (PWAD 659) (3)

660.description: The focus is on Shakespeare’s various treatments of war in his plays: all his Roman histories, most of his English histories, all his tragedies, even some of his comedies.
660.title: War in Shakespeare’s Plays (PWAD 660) (3)

661.description: Examines contemporary theoretical issues and critical approaches relevant to the study of literature.
661.title: Introduction to Literary Theory (3)

662.description: A history of literary criticism from the Greeks to mid-20th century, focusing on recurrent concerns and classic texts that are indispensable for understanding the practice of literary criticism today.
662.title: History of Literary Criticism (3)

663.description: This course covers major works of and topics in postcolonial theory.
663.title: Postcolonial Theory (3)

664.description: An advanced-level investigation of queer theory’s challenges to literary criticism, cultural studies, and questions of critical methodology in the humanities. Cutting-edge research and just-published articles will be used.
664.title: The Challenge of Queer Theory to Literary Studies, Cultural Studies, and the Humanities (3)

665.description: This course explores literature, performance art, film, and photography by Latinas and Latinos whose works may be described as “queer” and that question terms and norms of cultural dominance.
665.title: Queer Latina/o Literature, Performance, and Visual Art (WMST 665) (3)

666.description: This course explores Latina/o literature about photography in relation to photography by “queer” Latina/o artists and through this double focus poses certain questions about identity, subjectivity, and culture.
666.title: Queer Latina/o Photography and Literature (WMST 666) (3)

67.description: Students will read examples of several kinds of travel literature, e.g., voyage, pilgrimage, exploration, tour, and mission. Special attention to North Carolina as a tourist venue.
67.title: First-Year Seminar: Travel Literature (3)

670.description: An examination of phenomenology, the “philosophy of experience.” Taking the perspective that literature helps clarify our experience, we will engage in readings of various genres—poetry, autobiography, fiction, and drama—as we examine how literature not only records experience, but also shapes it through a distinct method of reasoning.
670.title: Being and Race in African American Literature (3)

673.description: A study of the literature of the United States South, in most cases focusing on 20thcentury Southern literature and on prose fiction.
673.title: Literature of the United States South (3)

674.description: Digital literature explores how literary works are composed for, shaped by, and studied in electronic environments. Course texts range from books to electronic fiction and poetry to video games. Hands-on activities give students a chance to develop their own literary projects—either as electronic literary works or as digital scholarship.
674.title: Digital Literature (3)

675.description: This course explores issues and methodologies related to the integration of digital technologies into teaching. Topics include instructor-student dynamics in the technologyassisted classroom, the role of social media in education, emerging forms of digital composing, and opportunities for extending the classroom through online platforms.
675.title: Digital Teaching (3)

676.description: Students will investigate theories and practices of editing in multi-media, digital environments. Students will explore histories of textual editing, research major humanities projects, examine trends and toolsets related to developing scholarly digital materials, and collaborate with one another and with campus entities to develop an online digital humanities project.
676.title: Digital Editing and Curation (3)

68.description: The evolution of leftist American literature from the Depression through the early Cold War. Authors include Mary McCarthy, Clifford Odets, Arthur Miller, Saul Bellow, and others.
68.title: First-Year Seminar: Radical American Writers, 1930–1960 (3)

680.description: This course offers a rigorous introduction to the various theories (aesthetic, narratological, historiographic, ideological, feminist, poststructuralist) inspired by the cinema.
680.title: Film Theory (3)

685.description: Two years of college-level Spanish or the equivalent strongly recommended. Multidisciplinary examination of texts and other media of the Americas, in English and Spanish, from a variety of genres.
685.title: Literature of the Americas (AMST 685, CMPL 685) (3)

686.description: Readings course selects an author, genre, or method as a means of deepening awareness of the politics, poetics, and paradoxes in the field of literature and environment.
686.title: Readings in Literature and Environment (3)

69.description: This course explores trends in online communication, emphasizing composition for the Web. The study of these writing activities is linked with a focus on innovation and on entrepreneurship.
69.title: First-Year Seminar: Entrepreneurial Writing on the Web (3)

690.description: Selected topics in literary studies, composition, digital media, and related fields. Topic varies by semester.
690.title: Special Topics (3)

691H.description: Restricted to senior honors candidates. First semester of senior honors thesis. Independent research under the direction of an English department faculty member.
691H.title: English Senior Honors Thesis, Part I (3)

692H.description: Restricted to senior honors candidates. Second semester of senior honors thesis. Essay preparation under the direction of an English department faculty member.
692H.title: English Senior Honors Thesis, Part II (3)

693H.description: Prerequisites, ENGL 130, 131, 132H, or 133H; ENGL 206 or 207; and ENGL 406 or 407. Permission of the program director. Restricted to senior honors candidates. The first half of a two-semester seminar. Each student begins a book of fiction (25,000 words) or poetry (1,000 lines). Extensive discussion of student work in class and in conferences.
693H.title: Creative Writing Senior Honors Thesis, Part I (3)

70.description: Study of the medieval concept of courtly love, tracing its classical antecedents, its expression in Renaissance literature (especially Shakespeare), and its influence in modern culture.
70.title: First-Year Seminar: Courtly Love, Then and Now (3)

701.description: introduction to medieval studies for graduate students in any department. intended to expose students to research problems, tools and techniques in fields other than their own.
701.title: Introduction to Medieval Studies (3)

71.description: This course explores the human struggle to make sense of suffering and debility. Texts are drawn from literature, anthropology, film, art history, philosophy, and biology.
71.title: First-Year Seminar: Doctors and Patients (3)

719.description: An introduction to old english language and literature that also attempts to relate that language to Modern english and to the larger context of the history of the english language.
719.title: Old English Grammar and Readings (3)

72.description: This first-year seminar will introduce students to college-level critical analysis, writing, and oral communication by exploring representations of the 9/11 attacks and the “war on terrorism” in literature and popular culture.
72.title: First-Year Seminar: Literature of 9/11 (3)

720.description: required preparation, a working knowledge of old english. The translation and interpretation of old english poetry including works such as The wanderer, The seafarer, deor, The dream of the rood, and beowulf.
720.title: Old English Poetry (3)

721.description: An introduction to early Middle english, its varieties and genres from ca. 1150 (The Peterborough Chronicle) to ca. 1330 (the Harley lyrics).
721.title: Early Middle English Literature (3)

722.description: required preparation, a working knowledge of Middle english. An exploration of the Middle english poetry of the 14th-century alliterative “revival,” including the works of the Gawain/Pearl poet of the langland.
722.title: Middle English Alliterative Poetry (3)

723.description: english literature of the late 14th and 15th centuries, including Gower, the english and scottish Chaucerians, and sir Thomas Malory.
723.title: Later Middle English Literature (3)

724.description: A study of Chaucer’s major poetry, including troilus and Criseyde, at least some of the “dream” poems such as Parliament of fowls, and most of The Canterbury tales.
724.title: Chaucer (3)

74.description: In this course, students will study epic and anti-epic strains in Western literature, reading key texts in the epic tradition from Homer and Virgil through the 20th century in light of various challenges to that tradition and tensions within it.
74.title: First-Year Seminar: Epic/Anti-Epic in Western Literature (3)

747.description: A wide-ranging, graduate-level survey of the American novel from the late 18th century through the 20th century.
747.title: Studies in the American Novel (3)

748.description: A wide-ranging, graduate-level survey of American poetry from the late 18th century through the 20th century.
748.title: Studies in American Poetry (3)

75.description: The aim of the course is to give beginning university students the requisite research skills to allow them to appreciate and to contribute to an understanding of the past by directly experiencing and interpreting records from the past. Students will work with historical documents, some more than 200 years old.
75.title: First-Year Seminar: Interpreting the South from Manuscripts (3)

76.description: This course will explore four writers of this period in order to examine a range of responses to what each writer saw as a crisis in the West’s ability to provide both a prosperous and a meaningful life for all people.
76.title: First-Year Seminar: Decadence, Nihilism, and Aestheticism: 1870–1910 (3)

776.description: The main emphasis of the course will be on mastering the basic grammar of the language. There will be some readings from selected old irish glosses and from Aislinge oenguso.
776.title: Old Irish I (3)

777.description: Prerequisite, enGl 776. readings from a variety of genres of old irish literature: stories from the tain, Crith Gablach, Cambrai Homily, early irish lyrics, scela Mucce Meic datho.
777.title: Old Irish II (3)

778.description: An introduction to Medieval welsh language and literature.
778.title: Medieval Welsh I (3)

779.description: Prerequisite, enGl 778. readings in old and Middle welsh literature.
779.title: Medieval Welsh II (3)

780.description: 781 Proseminar in British Literature, 1500–1660 (3). 782 Proseminar in British Literature, 1660–1770 (3). 783 Proseminar in British Literature, 1770–1870 (3).
780.title: Proseminar in British Literature, 800–1500 (3)

784.title: Proseminar in American Literature, Prior to the Civil War (3)

786.description: This course introduces students to the field of literary studies in english and comparative literature. students will survey a range of approaches, methods, and controversies that have emerged from the field. The focus on critical and institutional histories will provide a foundation for graduate work and for developing professional objectives.
786.title: Introduction to Graduate Study in English and Comparative Literature (3)

79.description: This course will explore the concept of globalization by focusing on the Asian diaspora, particularly the artistic and cultural productions that document, represent, and express Global Asians.
79.title: First-Year Seminar: Globalization/Global Asians (3)

80.description: Narratives of women spies, social reformers, missionaries, teachers, blockade runners, and escapees from slavery help uncover persuasive strategies used to challenge the limited roles to which women were assigned.
80.title: First-Year Seminar: The Politics of Persuasion: Southern Women’s Rhetoric (3)

800.description: Course explores the impacts of information technology on teaching and scholarship in the humanities. students critique and learn to integrate emerging technologies into their pedagogy and research interests.
800.title: Technology and the Humanities (3)

801.description: Course introduces graduate students to methodologies of research in the field of rhetoric and Composition. emphasis is on theoretical and practical concerns that improve teaching and help develop research agendas.
801.title: Research Methods in Composition and Rhetoric (3)

805.description: focus varies by semester, but generally investigates intersections of literacy, pedagogy, and rhetorical theory. Courses range from explorations of technology and literacy, to investigations of forms of writing and pedagogy.
805.title: Studies in Rhetoric and Composition (3)

814.description: study of english from its Proto-indo-european origins through the 18th century focusing on historic events and the major changes to the structure and usage of english they occasioned.
814.title: History of the English Language (LING 814) (3)

819.description: topics in old english poetry and prose that vary with each seminar and instructor.
819.title: Seminar in Old English Language and Literature (3)

821.description: intensive studyof major Middle english authors or genres or of medieval cultural influences. topics have included Malory, Piers Plowman and its tradition, drama, and intellectual backgrounds of medieval literature.
821.title: Seminar in Middle English Literature (3)

825.description: A study of select works of renaissance literature, both dramatic and nondramatic, in its intellectual, social, political, or religious context.
825.title: Renaissance Literature in Context (3)

827.description: Concentrated studies of single authors, groups of authors thematically linked, or authors in their families or coteries.
827.title: Studies in Renaissance Authors (3)

828.description: students will study renaissance literature while assessing the usefulness and status of a theoretical approach, such as feminist theory, queer theory, cultural materialism, new historicism or psychoanalytic theory.
828.title: Perspectives on Renaissance Literature and Culture (3)

829.description: A study of renaissance drama linked thematically, or framed by select cultural practices and historical issues.
829.title: Studies in Renaissance Literature: Drama (3)

830.description: A focused examination of an aesthetic, historical, or theoretical problem in the study of renaissance literature.
830.title: Studies in Renaissance Literature: Primarily Nondramatic (3)

832.description: studies in restoration and 18th-century drama from etherege to sheridan.
832.title: Restoration and 18th-Century Drama (3)

833.description: studies in restoration and Augustan writers from dryden to Haywood.
833.title: Studies in English Literature, 1660–1740 (3)

834.description: studies in later 18th-century writers from Gray to wollstonecraft.
834.title: Later 18th-Century Writers (3)

835.description: studies in 18th-century fiction from behn to Austen.
835.title: 18th-Century Fiction (3)

836.description: behn, Haywood, Manley, Montague, burney, wollstonecraft, and Austen.
836.title: Studies in 18th-Century Women Writers (3)

837.description: sections: 1) blake, wordsworth, Coleridge, 2) byron, shelley, Keats. examination of the major romantic poets, supplemented by readings in other romantic authors.
837.title: Studies in English Literature, 1780–1832 (3)

838.description: examination of important 19thcentury british novels, such as those by Austen, scott, dickens, the brontës, sensation novelists, Gaskell, Carroll, Thackeray, eliot, trollope, doyle, Hardy, Meredith.
838.title: 19th-Century British Novel (3)

839.description: examination of victorian critics, travel writers, feminists, scientists, and historians in relation to the controversies of the period.
839.title: Victorian Nonfictional Prose (3)

84.description: This course explores fiction as a particular form of cultural narrative and thinks about its deployment in the construction of a core American identity—the cowboy.
84.title: First-Year Seminar: Into the West (3)

840.description: study of victorian poets, focused on a group or a topic, including figures such as tennyson, the brownings, Arnold, and the Pre-raphaelites.
840.title: Studies in Victorian Literature: Poetry (3)

841.description: topics concerning major authors and issues of the romantic period.
841.title: Seminar in 19th-Century Romanticism in England (3)

842.description: topics concerning major authors and issues of the victorian period.
842.title: Seminar in Victorian Literature (3)

843.description: topics vary: e.g., new england Puritanism, new england response to American literary nationalism; emerson; irving, Hawthorne, and Poe and the development of the American short story.
843.title: Seminar in American Literature to 1860 (3)

844.description: in-depth exploration for doctoral students of selected topics or authors in American literature from 1860 to 1900.
844.title: Seminar in American Literature, 1860–1900 (3)

847.description: doctoral-level seminar in the selected topics or authors.
847.title: Seminar in the American Novel (3)

85.description: Our objective throughout will be to analyze how literary art simultaneously demonizes and celebrates the “miracle of the marketplace” and those financial pioneers that perform its magic.
85.title: First-Year Seminar: Economic Saints and Villains (3)

850.description: Usually taught as a survey of major poets: yeats, frost, stevens, williams, Pound, eliot, Auden, with some more recent poets.
850.title: Studies in English and American Poetry of the 20th Century (3)

851.description: Usually taught as a survey of major playwrights of the modern era, from the continental influences (ibsen and strindberg) to such contemporary figures as Pinter and stoppard.
851.title: Studies in English and American Drama of the 20th Century (3)

852.description: explores representative works of contemporary playwrights.
852.title: Seminar in Modern Drama (3)

857.title: Studies in 20th-Century English and American Literature (3)

858.description: Usually taught as a survey of major writers: Joyce, lawrence, woolf, Hemingway, faulkner, with some other writers.
858.title: Studies in English and American Fiction of the 20th Century (3)

86.description: This course is a cross-cultural and intermedial exploration of the imagery of the Great City in high modernist works of literature, art, and film.
86.title: First-Year Seminar: The Cities of Modernism (3)

860.title: Seminar in 20th-Century Literature, English and American (3)

861.description: seminar with varying topics, focusing on recent developments in literary and cultural theory, including narratology, feminism, psychoanalysis, and postcolonial and materialist theory.
861.title: Seminar in Literary and Cultural Theory (3)

863.description: Course examines the shifting meanings of postcoloniality in 20thand 21st-century literature from formerly colonized countries.
863.title: Seminar in Postcolonial Literature (3)

864.title: Studies in Latina/o Literature, Culture, and Criticism (3)

867.description: representative writers and literary and cultural traditions from the beginning of African American literature to 1930.
867.title: African American and African Diasporan Literature to 1930 (3)

868.description: Key writers within the context of selected literary, cultural, and critical traditions from 1930 to 1970.
868.title: African American and African Diasporan Literature, 1930–1970 (3)

869.description: representative writers and literary, cultural, and critical traditions from 1970 to the present.
869.title: African American and African Diasporan Literature, 1970 to the Present (3)

87.description: This course focuses on the fiction of Jane Austen and its representations in film.
87.title: First-Year Seminar: Jane Austen, Then and Now (3)

871.description: An intensive study of a major writer or text, a group of writers or texts, or an important trend, tradition, or literary period.
871.title: Seminar in African American Literature (3)

872.description: An intensive study of a particular aspect of African American literature, such as speculative fiction, subject formation, comparative diasporan literatures, gender issues, theoretical and critical approaches, or formal innovations.
872.title: Studies in African American and African Diasporan Literature (3)

873.description: South (3). An in-depth treatment of selected writers of the U.s. south, focusing on a single genre or historical period.
873.title: Seminar in the Literature of the U

874.description: South: Special Topics (3). An in-depth treatment of selected topics (e.g., the southern renaissance, postmodern southern fiction, the racial conversion narrative) in southern literature.
874.title: Literature of the U

876.description: An introduction to modern irish grammar.
876.title: Introduction to Modern Irish I (3)

877.description: Prerequisite, enGl 876. readings in modern irish literature.
877.title: Introduction to Modern Irish II (3)

878.description: This course explores the creation of irish culture in literature and history through the medium of 20th-century critical texts.
878.title: Critical Ireland (3)

879.description: This course examines literature’s response to “the troubles” in northern ireland, that outbreak of civil violence which has taken place, most recently, since 1968.
879.title: Writing the Northern Irish Troubles (3)

88.description: This course will explore stories about the Japanese American internment from first-person memoirs to contemporary fiction. We will also examine the ramifications, historic and legal, of the internment post-9/11.
88.title: First-Year Seminar: The Legacy of the Japanese American Internment from WWII to 9/11 (3)

880.description: This course will examine the relationships between irish writing, culture, and modernism, in the context of international developments in literature and art.
880.title: Ireland in Modernity (3)
