306.title: History of Britain in the 19th Century (3)

308.description: The Renaissance (1300–1600) is known as a time of great artistic, scientific, and political renewal. But did Jews, the only religious minority in Europe, get an opportunity to benefit from and participate in that progress? This class studies the history of the Jews at a time of great cultural change.
308.title: European Renaissance and the Jews (JWST 308) (3)

309.description: This course focuses on the period in French history between the ascendancy of absolute monarchy in the middle of the 17th century and the collapse of absolutism at the onset of the French Revolution.
309.title: Old Regime France, 1661–1787 (3)

310.description: The French Revolution was a source of much that the modern world recognizes as its own: nationalism, human rights, class conflict, ideology, communism, conservatism, show trials, citizen armies, terrorism, and the concept of revolution itself. This course probes issues that underlie the continuing relevance of the French Revolution today.
310.title: The French Revolution (3)

325.description: An examination of how food, its production, distribution, and consumption have shaped the history of the United States, the United Kingdom, and the world at large. The course will study how these nations and their empires have been intertwined but remained distinctive from colonial times to the present.
325.title: Food and History: The Local and Global, the United Kingdom and the United States (3)

331.description: Which of the following would you consider potentially political issues: celibacy; semen retention; bodybuilding; depiction of gods/goddesses; or bomb making? Well, they all are. This course examines debates over sex, religion, and violence that constituted a key part of revolutionary thought and anti-colonial struggles in modern South Asia.
331.title: Sex, Religion, and Violence: Revolutionary Thought in Modern South Asia (3)

345.description: This team-taught course compares premodern empires, inquiring into rulers’ strategies and subject peoples’ experiences. Empires studied will depend on instructors’ areas of expertise, but may include Greeks, Romans, Chinese, Incas, West Africans, Mughals, and Ottomans, among others. We anticipate comparing three premodern empires in any given semester.
345.title: Comparative Strategies of Empire (3)

351.description: The history of warfare from its prehistoric origins to the present. The focus is on interactions between peoples around the world and particularly on the problems of innovation and adaptation.
351.title: Global History of Warfare (3)

355.description: This course will explore women’s experiences in America from 1500 to 1865. Topics will include the ways in which women have shaped American politics, economy, society, and culture.
355.title: American Women’s History to 1865 (3)

356.description: This course will examine the changing lives of women in the United States after 1865: their contribution to the economy, society, cultural change, and political struggles.
356.title: American Women’s History: 1865 to the Present (3)

357.description: An examination of the changing history of childhood (emphasizing preadolescence) from the colonial times through slavery, homeless news boys, and the Great Depression to the present. Materials will include a variety of primary documents (novels, letters, slave narratives, prints and drawings, films) as well as recent scholarship.
357.title: Childhood in America (3)

358.description: An introduction to the history of sexuality in North America from the colonial period to the sexual revolution, this course critically examines such issues as regulation, reproduction, reform, and identity.
358.title: American Sexualities (3)

359.description: This is a survey of evangelical Christianity from 1600 to the present. We will trace the roots of evangelicalism in post–Reformation Europe, its diverse expressions and political influence in modern Western culture, and its recent spread throughout the Global South.
359.title: Global Evangelicalism since 1600 (3)

360.description: This course surveys questions that have preoccupied leading thinkers and shaped intellectual culture in America since 1870. Themes include the problem of defining American identity, the clash between faith and reason, social injustice, the meaning of “modernity,” the power and pitfalls of ideology, conceptions of human nature.
360.title: Modern American Intellectual History (3)

362.description: Course explores the historical significance of baseball in American life, using the history of the game to investigate topics such as industrialization, urbanization, and immigration; conflicts between labor and capital; racial prejudice and integration; patriotism and American identity; evolving gender ideals; and the role of myth in American culture.
362.title: Baseball and American History (3)

363.description: Study of the popular arts and entertainments of the 19th and 20th centuries and the ways in which they illuminate the values, assumptions, aspirations, and fears of American society.
363.title: Popular Culture and American History (3)

364.description: A survey of the rise and development of the major financial, commercial, manufacturing, and transportation enterprises that transformed the United States from an agricultural into a leading industrial nation.
364.title: History of American Business (MNGT 364) (3)

365.description: From the experience of colonial artisans to contemporary factory and office workers, organized and unorganized, this course examines the effect of the industrial revolution on the American social and political landscape.
365.title: The Worker and American Life (MNGT 365) (3)

366.description: The history of North Carolina from the original Indian cultures to the end of the Civil War. Important topics include colonization, the American Revolution, evangelical religion, slavery, economic and political reform, the rise of sectionalism, and the Civil War.
366.title: North Carolina History before 1865 (3)

367.description: The history of North Carolina from the end of the Civil War to the present. Important topics include Reconstruction, agrarian protests, disfranchisement and segregation, industrialization and workers’ experience, the civil rights movement, and 20th-century politics.
367.title: North Carolina History since 1865 (3)

369.description: Survey of America’s military experience in the 20th century, focusing on national security policy, military institutions, World Wars I and II, the Cold War, the Korean and Vietnam Wars, and recent interventions.
369.title: War and American Society, 1903 to the Present (PWAD 369) (3)

370.description: Students will study the impact of culture on the lives of women in Britain and the United States in the 19th and early 20th centuries.
370.title: Women in the Age of Victoria (3)

371.description: Will examine the way that the process of emancipation unfolded in Haiti, Jamaica, and Cuba, with major emphasis on emancipation in the United States.
371.title: Emancipation in the New World (AAAD 385) (3)

372.description: Diverse developments as interpreted within the framework of certain broad and open-ended themes, particularly individual freedom, social welfare, mass culture, and community.
372.title: Politics and Society since the New Deal (3)

373.description: A history of the United States in World War II (1941–1945): home front and military front.
373.title: The United States in World War II (PWAD 373) (3)

374.description: A survey and interpretation of the American West in the 19th and 20th centuries, emphasizing the special role of the West in the evolution of American history and the development of contemporary American society.
374.title: The American West, 1800 to the Present (3)

376.description: Survey of African American history to abolition of slavery in North America with some attention to experiences of people of African descent in Latin America and the Caribbean.
376.title: History of African Americans to 1865 (3)

377.description: Survey of African American history since emancipation in North America with some attention to experiences of people of African descent in Latin America and the Caribbean.
377.title: History of African Americans, 1865 to Present (3)

378.description: This Maymester three-week course will examine slavery in the American South by focusing on slavery in South Carolina both on large plantations and in the urban setting of Charleston.
378.title: Slavery and Place: The South Carolina Case (3)

379.description: This course explores the origins, consolidation, and unmaking of segregationist social orders in the American South and South Africa from the colonial era up to the 20th century.
379.title: Race, Segregation, and Political Protest in South Africa and the United States (3)

380.description: Examines methods African American people used to create the family as an institution once they became free. Looks at families under segregation and Jim Crow, through the civil rights movement, to the growth of a black middle and underclass. Also explores nontraditional African American families, including interracial and gay families.
380.title: Quilting African American Family History (3)

381.description: The struggle for freedom has been a pivotal theme in African American history. This course turns to music toexplore the shifting contours and permutations of that struggle between the 1940s and 1990s.
381.title: Bebop to Hip-Hop: The Modern Black Freedom Struggle through Music (3)

390.description: Subject matter will vary with instructor but will focus on some particular topic or historical approach. Course description available from departmental office. Closed to graduate students. Repeatable for credit.
390.title: Special Topics in History (3)

398.description: Permission of the department. The course is in general limited to 15 students. The subject matter will vary with the instructor. Each course will concern itself with a study in depth of some historical problem. Students will write a substantial research paper.
398.title: Undergraduate Seminar in History (3)

420.description: This course deals with ancient Greek religious practices and seeks to place them in their legal, political, and cultural contexts, and thus integrate them into the study of Greek history.
420.title: Politics and Religion in Ancient Greece (3)

421.description: The rise of Macedonia; the careers of Philip II and Alexander (with emphasis on the latter’s campaigns); the emerging Hellenistic Age. The course integrates computer (including Web site) and audiovisual materials throughout.
421.title: Alexander (PWAD 421) (3)

422.description: War and the warrior in the archaic and classical Greek world, seventh to the fourth centuries BCE.
422.title: Ancient Greek Warfare (PWAD 422) (3)

423.description: HIST 225 strongly recommended. Topical approach to the social and cultural history of the ancient Greek city states, ca. 800–336 BCE.
423.title: Archaic Greece, 800–480 BCE (3)

424.description: HIST 225 strongly recommended. The life and times of the ancient Athenians from the sixth to fourth centuries BCE.
424.title: Classical Greece (Sixth–Fourth Centuries BCE) (3)

425.description: Explores the transformation from Republic to Principate. Conducted in considerable part by student reports and classroom discussions.
425.title: Roman History, 154 BCE–14 CE (3)

427.description: Focuses upon administrative, social, and economic themes. Conducted in considerable part by student reports and classroom discussions.
427.title: The Early Roman Empire, 14 CE–193 CE (3)

428.description: Focuses upon administrative, social, and economic themes. Conducted in considerable part by student reports and classroom discussions.
428.title: The Later Roman Empire, 193 CE–378 CE (3)

431.description: The nature and workings of the Western church between roughly 600 and 1300. Emphasis on the church “from within,” organization, missionary strategies, liturgy, monasticism, popular religion.
431.title: The Medieval Church (3)

432.description: Students in this course will examine Christian attitudes toward holy war, crusading, and other forms of coercive violence from the 11th until the 15th centuries, with a focus on the major crusades to the Holy Land.
432.title: The Crusades (3)

433.description: Examines critical issues in the development of English society and economy in the centuries before industrialization.
433.title: English Society, 1200–1700 (3)

434.description: A consideration of England’s origins, unification, and development as a national monarchy. Primary emphasis is on political, ecclesiastical, and cultural aspects.
434.title: Medieval England (3)

435.description: The origins and development of the university during the period 1100 to 1400; types of organization, curricula and degrees, intellectual life, town-gown and studentmaster relationships.
435.title: The Medieval University (3)

436.description: This course will explore notions of male and female sanctity from Late Antiquity to the High Middle Ages. Topics will include martyrdom, the cult of relics, and bodily resurrection.
436.title: Medieval Theology, Gender, and the Body (3)

437.description: This course has as its theme the lives of aristocratic men and women in western Europe between about 850 and 1200 CE. Discusses the nature of aristocratic identity, the trends that shaped the lives of aristocratic men and women, and the different roles of men and women within aristocratic culture.
437.title: Aristocratic Culture in the Central Middle Ages (3)

438.description: This course examines the multifaceted constructions of masculinity found in narrative texts produced in medieval western Europe. Focuses on topics such as gender relations, male self-fashioning, homosocial bonding, family structures. Sources studied range from epic and romance to chronicles and visual records.
438.title: Medieval Masculinities, 500–1200 (3)

451.description: The largest and most prosperous Jewry of Europe lived in medieval Spain. The 1492 expulsion, driven by the Inquisition and Catholic monarchy, not only ended Spanish Jewish life but also forced a traumatic redefinition of Jewish identity. This course focuses on the causes and consequences of the expulsion of 1492.
451.title: 1492: The Expulsion of the Jews from Spain (JWST 451) (3)

452.description: (3). A study of the people, culture, and intellectual achievements of the Italian Renaissance with emphasis on the interaction between culture and society.
452.title: The Renaissance: Italy, Birthplace of the Renaissance, 1300– 1550

453.description: A picture of Mediterranean social and economic life 1300 to 1600, with special focus on rural and urban society, family structure, patronage, work and wages, public and private finance.
453.title: Mediterranean Societies and Economics in the Renaissance World (3)

454.description: Examines a movement of religious reform that shattered Latin Christendom and contributed many of the conditions of early modern Europe. Emphases: religious, political, social.
454.title: The Reformation (RELI 454) (3)

455.description: The century marks the watershed in European development. Emphases: statecraft, the emerging state-system, the new scientific world view, the evolution of European society.
455.title: Europe in the 17th Century (3)

458.description: Europe and the experience of total war, with special focus on national conflicts; ideological conflicts among fascism, communism, and liberalism; and the dictatorships of Hitler and Stalin.
458.title: Europe and the World Wars, 1914–1945 (3)

460.description: Examines the major late medieval religious, social, and political developments plus the Reformation and Counter-Reformation. Topics include Luther’s theology, the German Peasant’s War, Jewish-Christian relations, witch-hunting, and family life.
460.title: Late Medieval and Reformation Germany (3)

461.description: Examines major political, social, and cultural developments. Topics include the growthof absolutist government, Prussia’s militarism and rivalry with Austria, German Jewry, Baroque music, the Enlightenment, and the Napoleonic wars.
461.title: Early Modern Germany, 1600–1815 (3)

462.description: This course examines the changes in German politics, culture, and society during the long 19th century, with a focus on the Anti-Napoleonic Wars and the following era of restoration, the Vormärz and the Democratic Revolution of 1848 to1849, the German Unification of 1871 and the Wilhelmine Empire, and finally World War I.
462.title: Germany, 1806–1918: Politics, Society, and Culture (3)

463.description: This course examines the changes in German politics, culture, and society during the 20th century, with a focus on the Weimar Republic, the Third Reich and World War II, the reshaping of East and West Germany since the post-war era, and the unification in 1989.
463.title: Germany since 1918: Politics, Society, and Culture (3)

464.description: A survey of Spanish history from the Islamic invasion to Napoleon. Particular attention will be given to the period of the Hapsburgs, 1516 to 1700.
464.title: History of Spain (3)

465.description: The course examines the gradual erosion of and criticism within the classical Christian tradition that led to the emergence of a new mentality by the end of the 17th century. Two lectures, one discussion per week.
465.title: Intellectual History of Europe, Early Period (3)

466.description: The main developments in European thought from the Enlightenment to the 20th century, with some attention to social context. Readings include Voltaire, Rousseau, Hegel, Marx, Tocqueville, Sand, Flaubert, Nietzsche, Freud.
466.title: Modern European Intellectual History (3)

467.description: A survey of changes in social organization, family life, courtship practices, sexual behavior, and the relations between the economy and population that occurred in preindustrial Europe, 1500–1815.
467.title: Society and Family in Early Modern Europe (3)

468.title: Art, Politics, and Society in France, 1850–1914 (ARTH 483) (3)

469.description: The social transformation of Europe from agrarian through postindustrial society, discussing population growth, family history, spread of education, class structure, social conflict, group ideologies, and mass politics, as well as everyday lives and popular lifestyles.
469.title: European Social History, 1815–1970 (3)

470.description: Traces the creation of scientific thought 1500 to 1700, from Leonardo to Newton, examining the various strands—Greek science, art, engineering, experimentation, occultism, etc.—woven into it.
470.title: The Scientific Revolution (3)

471.description: A survey of the development since 1700 of the various branches of physical and biological science, culminating in the 20th-century revolution in physics.
471.title: History of Science from Newton to Einstein (3)

472.description: Shows how the age of Shakespeare and Newton (16thto 17th-century England) fused old and new ideas about medicine and health, anticipating some of our own beliefs and practices.
472.title: Medicine and Health in Early Modern Europe (3)

473.description: A lecture course, open to juniors, seniors, and graduate students.
473.title: Tudor and Stuart England, 1485–1660 (3)

477.description: A close study of Russia’s age of revolution from the reign of the last tsar to the turbulent Stalin Revolution of 1929, with emphasis on the revolutions of 1917.
477.title: Revolution in Russia, 1900–1930 (3)

478.description: An in-depth examination of Soviet and post-Soviet history from 1929 to the present.
478.title: Stalin and After: The USSR, 1929–Present (3)

479.description: Spanning the ancient, medieval, and modern West, this course explores normative and non-normative female sexualities, ideas about female bodies, and the regulation of female sexuality by families, religions, and states.
479.title: History of Female Sexualities in the West (WMST 479) (3)

480.description: The diplomatic, military, and ideological confrontations with the West; the decline and fall of the Russian autocracy; the evolution of reform thought; and revolutionary opposition.
480.title: Russia, 1796–1917 (3)

481.description: An examination of the countries of Eastern Europe, their origins and development since World War II, their cohesion and conflict.
481.title: Eastern Europe since World War II (3)

482.description: This course examines the development of the Russian Empire, from the Mongol conquest in the 13th century to the transformation of Imperial Russia in the Soviet Union after 1917.
482.title: Russia, Eurasian Empire (3)

483.description: This course explores the role of nation and religion in shaping political, cultural, and social experience and change in Tsarist and Soviet Russia through the prism of Christianity, Islam, and Judaism.
483.title: Nation and Religion in Tsarist and Soviet Russia (3)

484.description: This course examines the role that Islam has played in the history of the Russian sphere— interior Russia, Siberia, the Caucasus, and Central Asia—from the 18th century to the present. Topics include methods of rule, social change, Islamic institutions, attempts to bureaucratize religion, and resistance.
484.title: Islam in Tsarist and Soviet Russia (3)

485.description: Eastern Europe was one of the largest centers of Jewish civilization from premodern times to the Second World War, giving rise to important religious, cultural, and political developments in Jewish modernity. This course examines main developments of Jewish society from the late 18th century until the aftermath of the Holocaust.
485.title: Modern East European Jewish History (JWST 485) (3)

490.description: Subject matter will vary with instructor but will focus on some particular topic or historical approach. Course description available from the departmental office.
490.title: Special Topics in History (3)

493.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. A supervised internship at an organization or institution engaged in the promotion of historical studies or the collection and preservation of historical documents and artifacts.
493.title: Internship in History (1–3)

496.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Special reading and research, supervised by a member of the department, in a selected field of history. Prior coursework in the selected field is recommended.
496.title: Independent Studies in History (1–3)

500.description: This course explores the growing body of research on gender, empire, and nation/nationalism inmodern European history by focusing on problems of national belongings and citizenship, state and nation building and empire formation, and the gendered discourses and representations of nation and empire.
500.title: Gender, Empire, and Nation in Europe and Beyond, 18th to the 20th Century (WMST 500)

501.description: This course explores the growing body of research on gender and welfare in a comparative perspective by focusing on the sexual division of labor in the workforce and the family, related social and family policies, including child care, and social citizenship in a comparative perspective.
501.title: The Gender of Welfare: Comparative Perspectives, 19th and 20th Century (WMST 501) (3)

51.description: This course explores the problem of revolutionary upheaval in Latin American history, from the revolutionary wars of the independence era (1810 to 1825) to revolutionary episodes of the 20th century.
51.title: First-Year Seminar: Latin American Revolutions (3)

513.description: This course explores the processes by which 19th-century imperialism set the contours of the modern world, establishing relations among societies and reconfiguring both colonial cultures and European cultures.
513.title: Imperialism and the Third World (3)

514.description: Museums and monuments have played a key role in the formation of cultural memory and identity, both nationally and globally. This course explores the relation between museums and monuments historically and theoretically, and relates them to national and international developments in the 19th and 20th centuries.
514.title: Monuments and Memory (3)

516.description: This course explores the ways in which Western historians and other students of the past from Adam Ferguson to Stephen Jay Gould have conceptualized and packaged historical time.
516.title: Historical Time (3)

517.description: This course introduces students to new research on the history of gender, the military and war in a comparative perspective. It explores the interrelations between changing military systems, types of warfare, the gender order as well as political, social and cultural currents with a focus on the 19th and/or 20th century.
517.title: Military, War, and Gender in Comparative Perspective (PWAD 517, WMST 517) (3)

52.description: This course will familiarize students with the background of this ongoing conflict. It will begin with the growth of political Zionism in Europe, continue through early Zionist settlement, the United Nations partition and resulting war, and the history of the conflict through the present.
52.title: First-Year Seminar: Conflicts over Israel/Palestine (3)

526.description: This course offers a survey of the history of the Andean region. The primary focus will be either the pre-Inca, Inca, and colonial periods or the 19th and 20th centuries, depending on the instructor.
526.title: History of the Andes (3)

527.description: This course surveys the history of Latin American indigenous peoples from the conquest to the present. Focus is on indigenous struggles and survival strategies.
527.title: Latin American Indigenous Peoples (3)

528.description: This course examines the leftist guerrilla movements that swept Latin America and the Caribbean during the latter half of the 20th century. Students will analyze the origins, trajectories, and legacies of these insurgencies, paying particular attention to the roles of race, class, and gender.
528.title: Guerrillas and Counterinsurgencies in Latin America (3)

529.description: This upper-division course focuses on the major issues, debates, and conflicts that arose over citizenship in a multiethnic society, tensions between church and state, and the definition of national territory in Mexico as a new and modernizing nation.
529.title: Mexico, 1750–1870: War, Independence, and Reforms: Citizenship and Conflict in a New Nation

53.description: This course examines the experiences of American writers who traveled and lived in European cities during the era between 1830 and 1930 with the goal of developing historical insights into these writers’ fascination with famous European cities and the experience of travel.
53.title: First-Year Seminar: Traveling to European Cities: American Writers/Cultural Identities, 1830–1930 (3)

531.description: Thematic approach to the history of the West Indies, with emphasis on the period from Europeanconquest through the 20th century. Topics include colonialism, slavery, monoculture, United States-Caribbean relations, and decolonization.
531.title: History of the Caribbean (3)

532.description: Thematic approach to Cuban history, from conquest to the revolution. Attention is given to socioeconomic developments, slavery and race relations, the 19th-century independence process, and the 20th-century republic.
532.title: History of Cuba (3)

533.description: This course is concerned primarily with the creation of a new society through race mixture and culture change, and with the political and economic development of Brazil.
533.title: History of Brazil (3)

534.description: A comparative examination of the movements, experiences, and contributions of Africans and people of African descent from the period of the Atlantic slave trade to the present.
534.title: The African Diaspora (3)

535.description: Analysis of historical transformations in Africa and their effects on women’s lives and gender relations. Particular themes include precolonial societies, colonialism, religious change, urban labor, nationalism, and sexuality.
535.title: Women and Gender in African History (3)

536.description: This course will focus on revolutionary change in the Middle East during the last century, emphasizing internal social, economic, and political conditions as well as international contexts.
536.title: Revolution in the Modern Middle East (ASIA 536) (3)

537.description: Explores the lives of women in the Middle East and how they have changed over time. Focus will change each year.
537.title: Women in the Middle East (ASIA 537, WMST 537) (3)

538.description: This course explores changing interactions between the Middle East and the West, including trade, warfare, scientific exchange, and imperialism, and ends with an analysis of contemporary relations in light of the legacy of the past.
538.title: The Middle East and the West (ASIA 538) (3)

539.description: This course is intended as a broad overview of Southeast Asian economic history from premodern times to the present day.
539.title: The Economic History of Southeast Asia (ASIA 539) (3)

54.description: In this course, students will learn about the dominant interpretations of the French Revolution, elaborated over the course of the 20th century, and they will come to appreciate and criticize the work of those historians who have interpreted the evidence from the French Revolution over the past 60 years.
54.title: First-Year Seminar: Interpreting the French Revolution, 1789–1815 (3)

540.description: This course traces Africa’s modern intellectual history, exploring such topics as Africa’s place in history, African nationalism, pan-Africanism, the problem of colonialism, and the meaning of progress.
540.title: African Intellectual History: Discourse, Knowledge, Politics (3)

541.description: This course addresses the major themes of the environmental history of Africa with an emphasis on issues of local ecology, land use, and labor and the struggles over these issues.
541.title: African Environmental History: Ecology, Economy, Politics (3)

542.description: This course examines the changing meanings of the idea of development in Africa and the role that Africans have played in shaping these meanings from the late 19th century.
542.title: Development in Africa and Its Discontents (3)

543.description: This course focuses on the historical, social, medical, cultural, policy, and economic aspects of health and health crises in Africa.
543.title: Histories of Health and Healing in Africa (3)

550.description: This course is designed to introduce undergraduates to recent historical scholarship in the field of Chinese gender studies. Topics include family and kinship, the body and bodily practices, social space, writing, sexuality, work, andlaw, covering both the premodern and modern periods. No prior coursework required.
550.title: Gender in Chinese History (3)

56.description: This seminar will read and discuss powerful examples of literature (poetry, memoirs, and novels) produced during and after World War I that sought to come to terms with the trauma of this cataclysmic event in European history, the first experience of total war fought by modern, industrialized nations.
56.title: First-Year Seminar: World War I: History and Literature (3)

561.description: Major topics: European reconnaissance; founding of new societies; character and structure of institutions; thought and feeling from Cotton to Franklin; privilege and cost of empire.
561.title: The American Colonial Experience (3)

562.title: Oral History and Performance (COMM 562, FOLK 562, WMST 562) (3)

564.description: Major topics: constitutional conflict in the British empire; independence and war; Confederation and Constitution; growth of political parties and nationality in a period of domestic change and international conflict.
564.title: Revolution and Nation Making in America, 1763–1815 (PWAD 564) (3)

565.description: Focus is on causes, nature, and consequences of the Civil War.
565.title: Civil War and Reconstruction, 1848–1900 (PWAD 565) (3)

566.description: A history of the sexual practices, desires, and understandings of Americans, from earliest colonial encounters to the late 20th century.
566.title: The History of Sexuality in America (3)

568.description: An exploration of the distinctive themes in Southern women’s lives, using the evidence of history and literature.
568.title: Women in the South (WMST 568) (3)

569.description: The course covers the history of black women in the United States from the 18th century to the present. It deals with such themes as work, family, community, sexuality, politics, religion, and culture.
569.title: African American Women’s History (WMST 569) (3)

57.description: This course is organized around reading about and discussing the theme of history, memory, and popular culture in the post–Civil War South.
57.title: First-Year Seminar: History and Memory in the Modern South, 1865 to the Present (3)

570.description: A wide-ranging exploration of America’s longest war, from 19th-century origins to 1990s legacies, from village battlegrounds to the Cold War context, from national leadership to popular participation and impact.
570.title: The Vietnam War (ASIA 570, PWAD 570) (3)

571.description: Explores the history of music in the American South from its roots to 20th-century musical forms, revealing how music serves as a window on the region’s history and culture.
571.title: Southern Music (FOLK 571) (3)

574.description: The history of the Spanish colonial experience north of Mexico, to 1820.
574.title: Spanish Borderlands in North America (3)

576.description: Introduces students to the study of Native American women through the perspectives of anthropology, history, and autobiography.
576.title: The Ethnohistory of Native American Women (WMST 576) (3)

577.description: How the United States came to occupy a leading role in world affairs as a diplomatic, military, economic, and cultural power and what that role has meant to Americans and to other peoples, especially during the Cold War.
577.title: United States Foreign Relations in the 20th Century (PWAD 577) (3)

581.description: in a classroom environment characterized by discussion, simulation, and interaction, the antecedents, formation, and interpretation of the Constitution are confronted in a broad historical matrix.
581.title: American Constitutional History to 1876 (3)

582.description: Using a classroom environment similar to HIST 581, constitutional adjustments and change are related to psychological, political, social, and economic factors, and to Supreme Court members.
582.title: American Constitutional History since 1876 (3)

584.description: A survey of the development of American cities since 1815 and their influence upon American history.
584.title: The Promise of Urbanization: American Cities in the 19th and 20th Centuries (3)

586.description: Economic, cultural, and social history of the antebellum South. The region’s political history will serve as a supporting part of the study.
586.title: The Old South (3)

587.description: This course explores the transformation of the South from the time of the Civil War and emancipation to the contemporary rise of the Sunbelt.
587.title: The New South (3)

589.description: This course will historically and critically examine the changing legal status of people of color in the United States. Within a broad historical matrix from the colonial era to the present, it will focus on African Americans, Native Americans, Asian Americans, Latina/os, and United States law.
589.title: Race, Racism, and America: (United States) Law in Historical Perspective (3)

61.description: The course will examine some of the principal themes that have informed Southeast Asian history and continue to shape the area today. Students will focus on the relationship between material forces—environmental and economic primarily—as well as social, political, and cultural developments.
61.title: First-Year Seminar: Southeast Asia in Global Prospective (3)

62.description: This seminar will explore the ways people have identified themselves in relation to specific places, nation-states, and foreign “others.” Examples may include the Kurdish nationalists, Islamist political parties, the Eritrean independence movement, and the Basque separatists.
62.title: First-Year Seminar: Nations, Borders, and Identities (3)

622.description: A survey of major developments in the history of American medicine. Emphasis will be placed upon setting the practice of medicine as well as the experience of health and disease into broad social, cultural, and political contexts.
622.title: Medicine and Society in America (3)

624.description: Examines African American intellectuals in North America with some attention to black writers in the Caribbean. Emphasizes American Negro Academy, black scholars, scholar-activists, writers, and public intellectuals.
624.title: Intellectual History of African Americans (3)

625.description: Technology’s impact on American thought and society and the response it has engendered. Topics will include the factory town, search for utopia, impact of Henry Ford, war, and depersonalization.
625.title: Technology and American Culture (3)

64.description: Examines Mikhail Gorbachev and the astonishing transformations that occurred while he governed the Soviet Union between 1985 and 1991. Students will explore post–Soviet Russia’s efforts at negotiating a new set of relations with the rest of the world and how Russia continues to shape our own destiny.
64.title: First-Year Seminar: Gorbachev: The Collapse of the Soviet Empire and the Rise of the New Russia (3)

66.description: This course will examine major films in Europe and America from 1908 to 1968 in terms of how they shaped the medium and reflected important social trends.
66.title: First-Year Seminar: Film and History in Europe and the United States, 1908–1968 (3)

670.description: Introduces students to the uses of interviews in historical research. Questions of ethics, interpretation, and the construction of memory will be explored, and interviewing skills will be developed through field work.
670.title: Introduction to Oral History (FOLK 670) (3)

671.description: Introduces the theory, politics, and practice of historical work conducted in public venues (museums, historic sites, national parks, government agencies, archives), directed at public audiences, or addressed to public issues.
671.title: Introduction to Public History (3)

674.description: This course will introduce many techniques employed by archaeologists and historians in locating and excavating sites of past human activity. It will involve field work at an active archeological site.
674.title: Field Methods in Archaeology and History (3)

68.description: In this seminar, through systematic discussion and dialogue, students will explore dreams, visions, and apparitions in American history from the early years of colonial contact to the emergence of modern psychology around 1900.
68.title: First-Year Seminar: American Dreams: Histories of Experience and Explanation, 1620–1900 (3)

691H.description: Permission of the instructor. Introduction to the methods of historical research; designed to lead to the completion of an honors essay.
691H.title: Honors in History (3)

692H.description: Permission of the instructor. Introduction to the methods of historical research; designed to lead to the completion of an honors essay.
692H.title: Honors in History (3)

70.description: Course explores the concept of cultural landscapes as a way of studying history and its legacies. Through a combination of field work, historical research, and analysis, students use maps, photographs, GIS resources, and archival documents to understand how—and why—people in the past shaped our surroundings today.
70.title: First-Year Seminar: Exploring Cultural Landscapes: Chapel Hill as a Case Study (3)

700.description: introduces students to the intellectual currents and schools of thought that have characterized the historical profession over time. by examining such diverse conceptual frameworks, students will prepare themselves to tackle more confidently the research projects they will design and execute in Hist 900 and 901.
700.title: Thinking Historically (3)

701.description: This is an interdisciplinary course to introduce graduate students to the sources, methods, and approaches of medieval studies.
701.title: Introduction to Medieval Studies (3)

702.description: Provides an introduction to teaching history. topics include the history of historical education, planning a course, the role of the teacher, goals and methods, using new technologies and evaluating students.
702.title: Introduction to Historical Education (3)

711.title: Introductory Colloquium on Early Modern Europe (3)

712.description: directed readings on modern european history, from britain through european russia.
712.title: Introductory Colloquium on Modern Europe (3)

713.description: directed readings on latin American history from preconquest to 1810; required for students entering the field.
713.title: Introductory Colloquium in Latin American History before 1810 (3)

714.description: directed readings on latin American history in the national Period; required for students entering the field.
714.title: Introductory Colloquium in the History of Latin America since 1810

715.title: Introductory Colloquium in United States History to 1865 (3)

716.description: directed readings on American history from the Civil war to the present; required for students entering the field.
716.title: Introductory Colloquium in United States History since 1865 (3)

717.description: An introduction to the methods, issues, and literature of military history, including classic works and scholarship representative of a variety of approaches from history and other disciplines.
717.title: Introduction to Military History (3)

718.description: reading colloquium in world military history, emphasizing europe, focusing on the most significant issues, methods, and approaches in the field today.
718.title: Colloquium in World Military History (3)

72.description: The course examines 20th-century European history through the lenses of women’s autobiographical writings. It explores women’s voices from different generational, social, and national backgrounds and asks what formed their memories.
72.title: First-Year Seminar: Women’s Voices: 20th-Century European History in Female Memory (3)

720.description: An introduction to major works and themes in the history of Asia with an emphasis on the history of China, Japan, and south Asia.
720.title: Introduction to Asian History (3)

721.description: examines the dynamics of cross-cultural contacts and exchange between europe and other civilizations in the context of a growing global interconnectedness.
721.title: Readings in European Expansion and Global Interaction, 1400–1800 (3)

722.description: focus on the 19th and 20th centuries. Mixing theory, case studies, and comparisons, the readings reflect disciplinary diversity.
722.title: Readings in Contemporary Global History (3)

725.description: readings in the history of women and gender in a comparative, global, or transnational perspective.
725.title: Selected Readings in the Comparative or Global History of Women and Gender (WMST 725) (3)

73.description: Beginning with a close reading of Wolfgang Schivelbusch’s The Railway Journey: The Industrialization of Time and Space in the 19th Century, this course will examine how railway travel impacted American and European culture.
73.title: First-Year Seminar: On the Train: Time, Space, and the Modern World (3)

735.description: readings on the historical study of gender and sexuality and on definitions of femininity and masculinity in different historical contexts.
735.title: Readings in the History of Sexuality and Gender (WMST 735) (3)

741.description: examines the principal historiographical problems in the history of science and medicine, focusing on a different topic each year.
741.title: Readings in the History of Science and Medicine (3)

746.description: The relationship of the social sciences to history, logic of inquiry, use of quantitative methods, and introduction to the computer.
746.title: History and the Social Sciences (3)

75.description: This course will explore intersections of faith and violence in the Christian tradition from the period from 300 to 1300. It will examine mainstream Christian attitudes toward non-Christians (pagans, Jews, Muslims) and nonorthodox groups (heretics).
75.title: First-Year Seminar: Faith and Violence in the Middle Ages (3)

751.description: Permission of the instructor. This course introduces graduate students to problems in the use of literary, epigraphic, and archaeological sources for a range of issues, including religion, law, and warfare.
751.title: Problems in Greek History, 600–323 BCE (3)

752.description: readings, reports, and discussions on selected topics of current importance for the field. topics to be announced n advance.
752.title: History of Rome, 27 BCE–180 CE (3)

755.description: A readings course on the history of women, gender, and sexuality in Medieval europe.
755.title: Readings in Medieval and Early Modern Women’s History (WMST 755) (3)

757.description: Prerequisite, Hist 433 or 434. readings in english history, ca. 1300–1500, with a focus on social, economic, political, and legal topics.
757.title: Late Medieval England (3)

76.description: This seminar will examine one of the most challenging topics in American and Latin American history: how to understand the conquest (la conquista) of Latin America by the Spaniards after the arrival of Columbus in 1492.
76.title: First-Year Seminar: Understanding 1492 (3)

760.description: A survey of the best historical literature emphasizing churches, varieties of secular power, and religious practice.
760.title: Europe in the 16th Century (3)

761.description: selected readings and discussion of topics and relevant historiography in early modern europe.
761.title: Readings in Early Modern European History (3)

763.description: A topical survey of the political, social, and economic history of early modern Germany.
763.title: Early Modern Germany (3)

765.description: readings, reports, and discussion on aspects of the french revolutionary upheaval in europe.
765.title: Problems in the History of the French Revolution (3)

770.description: A readings course in the history of women in europe since 1500.
770.title: Readings in Modern European Women’s and Gender History (WMST 220) (3)

771.description: This course examines particular themes, events, and historiographical debates of Modern european History in a seminar setting.
771.title: Topics in Modern European History (3)

772.description: A readings course on specific themes and debates in modern european intellectual life.
772.title: Readings in the Intellectual History of Europe (3)

773.description: This graduate readings course discusses classic works as well as recent landmark books about the development of european society in the 19th and 20th centuries.
773.title: Readings in European Social History (3)

774.description: directed readings, varying from year to year, selected from historiographical classics as well as the most recent scholarly publications.
774.title: Readings in Modern European History, 1918–1945 (3)

775.description: directed readings in 19thand 20th-century english history. topics vary from year to year.
775.title: Studies in Modern English History (3)

776.description: open to graduate students from all departments. This course examines one period or one set of problems within french history since the renaissance. topics determined by instructor.
776.title: Topics in French History (3)

781.description: selected readings and discussion of various topics in the history of russia from the late 18th century to the russian revolution.
781.title: Readings in Russian History, 1796–1917 (3)

782.description: A historiographical reading colloquium covering soviet and post-soviet russian history, 1917-present. The course familiarizes students with western, soviet, and post-soviet literature on the most important issues in soviet history.
782.title: Readings in Soviet History (3)

79.description: We will employ coming of age autobiographies to explore developments in the United States during the 20th century. In these autobiographies the authors focus primarily on the periods of childhood and adolescence into young adulthood. We will consider many issues including race, racism, immigration, religion, social class, and gender.
79.title: First-Year Seminar: Coming of Age in 20th-Century America (3)

816.description: instructors use this course to focus on particular topics or historical approaches related to Asian history.
816.title: Topics in Asian History (3)

82.description: This course explores diverse experiences of modernity among Jewish populations from the mid-18th century to the present under the influence of political, cultural, and socioeconomic changes. Diaries, memoirs, literature, and film challenge students to develop their own analyses while becoming familiar with arguments among scholars of Jewish life.
82.title: First-Year Seminar: The Search for Modern Jewish Identity (3)

820.description: instructors use this course to focus on particular topics or approaches in latin American history. topics to be announced in advance.
820.title: Problems in Latin American History (3)

83.description: Examines popular music as a way of understanding African history from the 1930s to the present. We will read background materials on African historical developments and musical styles, do a lot of listening, and try to learn what African musicians tell us about their societies.
83.title: First-Year Seminar: African History through Popular Music (3)

831.description: selected readings and research in United states history and its multicultural dimensions up to the American revolution.
831.title: Readings in Early American History (3)

833.title: The United States in the Federal Period, 1789–1820 (3)

834.description: An analysis of the material and ideological transformations within the antebellum republic, which climaxed in the sectional crisis of the 1850s.
834.title: The United States in the Middle Period, 1815–1860 (3)

835.description: A review of traditional and modern literature on the pre-Civil war south, focusing on the interrelationships of its economy, society, culture, and politics.
835.title: Readings in the Antebellum South (3)

84.description: Explores the distinctive features of microhistorical approaches to the past and the attractions of microhistory for the practicing historian. Students will read a rich sampling of recent work (much of it featuring monsters, murder, and mayhem) and try their hand at writing their own microhistories.
84.title: First-Year Seminar: Monsters, Murders, and Mayhem in Microhistorical Analysis: French Case Studies (3)

840.description: An intensive readings course on key works comprising the core historiography for Civil war-reconstruction America. discussions, short papers, and a 20page historiographical paper comprise the bulk of the assignments.
840.title: Civil War and Reconstruction, 1860–1876 (3)

841.description: readings, reports, and discussions on selected topics with a view to gaining familiarity with the literature of the field.
841.title: Readings in the South since Reconstruction (3)

842.description: A course of readings for advanced students that relate social history to the history of the state in America in the period from the Great depression and the new deal to the present.
842.title: Political and Social History of Modern America (3)

845.description: A graduate reading seminar on the history of America’s workers from the 20th century to the present. The struggle of American workers to achieve a measure of dignity and security is examined from social, economic, and political perspectives. The course critically evaluates recent scholarship in the field of labor history.
845.title: Readings in United States Labor History (3)

860.description: reading colloquium in United states military history focusing on the most significant issues, methods, and approaches in the field today.
860.title: Colloquium in United States Military History (3)

861.description: readings and research exploring various topics in modern American foreign relations and diplomacy.
861.title: History of United States Foreign Relations (3)

863.description: A readings course to introduce students to the main topics in urban history.
863.title: Readings in Urban History (3)

864.description: Graduate reading seminar in American labor history intended for students doing research as well as those writing M.A. and doctoral theses. Graduate students from fields other than United states history welcome. students will read texts and articles by scholars in a wide variety of fields of American labor history.
864.title: 19th and 20th Century American Labor History (3)

865.description: A readings course on the history of women and gender in the United states.
865.title: Readings in United States Women’s and Gender History (WMST 865) (3)

870.description: Graduate students compile bibliographies and read important contributions to various aspects of African American history, stressing shifts in African American historiography and including very recent works.
870.title: Readings in African American History (3)

875.description: research seminar exploring various topics in United states cultural history to be announced in advance.
875.title: Topics in American Cultural History (3)

878.description: readings in and discussions of the major works in native American history.
878.title: Readings in Native American History (AMST 878) (3)

89.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
89.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

890.description: instructors use this course to focus on particular topics or historical approaches. specific course descriptions are available each semester on the departmental web site (www.unc.edu/depts/history).
890.title: Topics in History for Graduates (3)

899.description: Permission of the instructor. independent reading programs for graduate students whose needs are covered by no course immediately available. for students resident in Chapel Hill or vicinity.
899.title: Independent Study for Graduate Students (3)

900.description: intended to help students develop a plan of research and writing, select a bibliography, develop an understanding of the literature available for their topic, and articulatea problem or facet of the topic to which they can contribute original research in their M.A. thesis.
900.title: Crafting a Historical Project (3)

901.description: Research Seminar (3). A seminar for those preparing the M.A. thesis. Pursuing original research in primary sources, students prepare full drafts of their theses.
901.title: M

902.description: doctoral students focus intensively on the writing process to produce an article-length piece of work suitable for publication. topics include quotation, translation, narrative technique, structuring argument, and addressing a wide audience.
902.title: Writing for Historians: A Seminar on the Craft of Historical Writing (3)

905.description: required of all doctoral candidates in the last semester of coursework, this practicum helps students refine a dissertation topic and produce a prospectus.
905.title: Dissertation Practicum (3)

906.description: A seminar for A.b.d. students, offered as demand and resources permit.
906.title: Dissertation Seminar (3)

910.description: research seminar on selected topics of current importance for the field. topics to be announced in advance.
910.title: Ancient History (3)

911.description: This course complements Hist 905, focusing on specific skills, sources, and methods for designing a dissertation prospectus in the field of medieval european history.
911.title: Medieval Dissertation Design (3)

924.description: This writing seminar explores the process of working with primary sources, creating a narrative, and shaping an interpretation based on examples from the last two centuries of european history.
924.title: Seminar in Modern European History (3)

925.description: A multipurpose writing seminar on russian and soviet history in which students may write a seminar paper, M.A. thesis, dissertation prospectus, or dissertation chapter.
925.title: Seminar in Russian and East European History (3)

930.description: research seminar exploring various topics related to United states history in the late 18th century around the time of the American revolution.
930.title: American Revolution, 1763–1789 (3)

948.description: This course introduces graduate students to research methods in native American history, including the methodology of ethnohistory and the techniques of compiling a source base, taking notes, and outlining.
948.title: Research in Native American History (AMST 948) (3)

951.description: introduction to research that should result in a major research product. students will alternate reading classic texts in military history with discussions of project conceptualization and research strategies.
951.title: Introductory Seminar in Military History (3)

952.description: A research seminar designed to bring major projects (usually an M.A. thesis) to completion.
952.title: Advanced Seminar in Military History (3)

971.description: All students will be required to complete an original research paper based on use of primary sources on a latin American topic corresponding to the theme of the seminar to be announced in advance.
971.title: Seminar in Latin American History (3)

975.title: Seminar in Women’s and Gender History (WMST 975) (3)

990.description: Given on demand and as resources permit, this seminar allows faculty to respond to student interest in particular topics.
990.title: Seminar in History (3)

993.description: individual work on the M.A. thesis, pursued under the supervision of the M.A. advisor.
993.title: Master’s Thesis (3)

743.title: Topics in Motor Control and Motor Learning: Therapeutic Implications (3)

780.title: Introduction to Outcomes Research in Health Care (3)

782L.title: Laboratory in Infant and Family Assessment (0

877.title: Independent Study in Human Movement Science (1–21)

881.title: The Neural Basis of Motor Control (3)

885.description: Human movement seminar held at the beach.
885.title: Beach Course (1–3)

904I.title: Aging and Health (DENT 604I , EPID 620I, MEDI 604I, NURS 782I, PHCY 604I, PHYT 904I, PSYC 904I, SOCI 824, SOWO 604I) (3)

951I.title: Aging and Public Policy (DENT 607I, FMME 607I, HPM 961I, MEDI 607I, NURS 783I, PHCY 607I, PSYC 907I, SOWO 607I) (3)

101.description: Introduction to modern spoken and written Hindi-Urdu. Speaking and listening practice, basic sentence pattern exercises, grammar fundamentals, the writing system, and creative applications exploring South Asian culture are included.
101.title: Elementary Hindi-Urdu I (4)

102.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 101. Continued instruction in modern spoken and written Hindi-Urdu. Sessions include speaking and listening drills, skits, role-play, and discussion of video and audio materials.
102.title: Elementary Hindi-Urdu II (4)

203.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 102. Second year of instruction in modern spoken and written HindiUrdu, including situational speaking and listening practice, complex sentence pattern exercises and idioms, vocabulary building, intermediate grammar topics, and reading exercises.
203.title: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu I (4)

204.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 203. Continued second year of instruction in modern spoken and written Hindi-Urdu. Students practice writing short essays and letters and continue to develop mature oral competency in Hindi-Urdu.
204.title: Intermediate Hindi-Urdu II (4)

220.description: In this course, students will master the Hindi alphabet, the Sanskrit-based Devanagari writing system. This course complements the regular Hindi-Urdu language sequence. Prior knowledge of spoken Hindi or Urdu is required; entry to this class is by placement only.
220.title: Introduction to the Hindi Script (Devanagari) (1)

221.description: This course introduces the Urdu alphabet (Nastaliq). Prior knowledge of spoken Urdu or Hindi is required; entry to this class is by placement only.
221.title: Introduction to the Urdu Script (Nastaliq) (1)

305.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 204. Third year of instruction in spoken and written Hindi-Urdu with an emphasis on the reading and discussion of short stories, prose articles, and interviews.
305.title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu I (3)

306.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 305. Third year of instruction in spoken and written Hindi-Urdu with an emphasis on the reading and analysis of poetry.
306.title: Advanced Hindi-Urdu II (3)

408.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 306. Introduces the range of Hindi-Urdu prose genres: the short story, the romance, the novel, and the autobiography.
408.title: Readings in Hindi-Urdu Prose (3)

410.description: Prerequisite, HNUR 306. Ghazal is the most important genre of Urdu-Hindi poetry from the 18th century to the present. This course, taught in Hindi-Urdu, concerns the analysis and interpretation of ghazals.
410.title: Seminar on the Urdu-Hindi Ghazal (3)

490.description: Directed readings in Hindi-Urdu literature and language on topics not covered by scheduled classes. Possible areas of study include Indian film and literature, Hindi-English translations, the Indian diaspora, Hindi journalism, and readings in comparative religions.
490.title: Topics in Hindi-Urdu Literature and Language (3)

496.description: Permission of the department. For the student who wishes to create and pursue an independent project in Hindi-Urdu under the supervision of a selected instructor. Maximum three credit hours per semester.
496.title: Independent Readings in Hindi-Urdu (1–3)

592.description: Historical causes of violence between Hindus and Muslims in modern India. Short stories, poetry, and novels in translation are used to explore how conflicts over religious sites, religious conversion, image worship, and language contributed to a sense of conflicting religious identity.
592.title: Religious Conflict and Literature in India (RELI 592) (3)

220.description: Focuses on communication skills development, with an emphasis on clarity, conciseness, and effectiveness of writing memoranda, reports, proposals, letters.
220.title: Writing for Health Administrators (3)

230.description: Introduction to the field of human resource management in health organizations in the United States. Detailed treatment of selected topics with a view to help develop operational skills.
230.title: Management of Human Resources (3)

249.description: Explores the practical role of clinical informatics skills and tools in health care organizational performance improvement and how this role is currently evolving in hospitals, group practices, and provider organizations.
249.title: Clinical Informatics for Outcomes Management (3)

310.description: Prerequisite, HPM 350. An introduction to health law and ethics for health administration undergraduate seniors.
310.title: Introduction to Law and Ethics in Health Management (3)

320.description: This course will provide students with a working knowledge of the various forms of health care consulting, including internal consulting. Students will enhance their analytical, presentation, teamwork, and project management skills.
320.title: Introduction to Strategic Planning and Marketing (3)

330.description: Using team-based service learning, the course develops skills in leading teams, organizations, and community and global health initiatives. Topics such as leadership, quality improvement, organizational structure, conflict management, and human resources are addressed.
330.title: Introduction to Organization Leadership, Management, and Behavior (3)

340.description: Prerequisite, BUSI 100. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Basic methods and techniques in financial management of health care programs, including financial statement analysis, cost determination and allocation, pricing of services, and budgeting.
340.title: Foundations of Health Care Financial Management (3)

341.description: The purpose of this course is to enhance students’ understanding of information systems and technology in health care, specifically focusing on the limitations of such technology. Students will be introduced to MS Excel and MS Access and shown how tools within these programs can help to mitigate some of the limitations.
341.title: Information Systems, Technology, and Tools (3)

350.description: Restricted to HPM B.S.P.H. students. An introduction to the current organization, financing, emerging trends, practices, and issues in the delivery of health services.
350.title: Introduction to Health Services Systems (3)

352.description: HPM 352, in conjunction with HPM 350, provides an overview of the U.S. health services system, including such topics as quality of care and managed care. The course also introduces students to careers in the field of health policy and management and helps students develop necessary communication skills.
352.title: Introduction to Health Services Systems II (3)

360.description: Participants in this one-week experiential short course explore the structures, policies, challenges, and future directions of England’s National Health Service and compare this model with the United States. Class time is balanced with time in the field visiting London-area health facilities and historical sites and meeting with area experts.
360.title: Health Systems around the World: Understanding England’s National Health Service (1)

380.description: Handson introduction to the design and implementation of relational databases to manage and analyze health care data (using Microsoft Access). Includes design of fully automated databases as well as the use of Access as an analysis tool in conjunction with Microsoft Excel.
380.title: Database Design for Health Care Applications (3)

393.description: Restricted to HPM B.S.P.H. students. Required of all B.S.P.H. students in HPM. The first six weeks of a supervised 12-week administrative internship in a health care organization.
393.title: Field Training in Health Policy and Management (2)

396.description: Permission of the instructor. For undergraduates enrolled in the department’s bachelor’s degree program. Directed readings or research; written reports are required.
396.title: Readings in Health Policy and Management (1–3)

420.description: This course examines systems for emergency management at federal, state, and local levels. The roles of emergency management, health services, and public health in disaster management are also reviewed. Every other week, evening online sessions required with instructors.
420.title: Community and Public Health Security: Disasters, Terrorism, and Emergency Management (3)

421.description: Permission of the instructor. This course covers biological, chemical, nuclear, and environmental agents that threaten public health. Offered to students in CPDM program only.
421.title: Community and Public Health Disasters: Agents of Action and Public Health Hazards (3)

422.description: Introduction of analytical tools to assess, evaluate, map, and investigate disasters (including biological outbreaks). These tools will be used to improve planning and evaluation of disaster management programs. Every other week, evening online sessions required with instructors.
422.title: Emergency Management I Analytic Methods (3)

423.description: Explores issues of preparedness, response, recovery, mitigation, and research in disaster management. Students will participate in evacuation decision-making, volunteer management, and the development of a disaster exercise. Every other week, evening online sessions required with instructors.
423.title: Emergency Management II Disaster Management (3)

435.description: Permission of the instructor. Application of basic principles of marketing and marketing decision models to problems in health care and other notfor-profit organizations.
435.title: Marketing for Not-for-Profit Organizations (3)

440.description: Conceptual and practical aspects in the analysis, development, and utilization of computer-based information and control systems with emphasis on application to the health care environment.
440.title: Introduction to Management Information Systems in Health Care (3)

466.description: Examines alternative approaches to containing health care costs adapted by public and private payers.
466.title: Competition, Regulation, and Insurance (3)

470.description: Introduction of linear model approach to analysis of data in health care settings. Topics include probability distributions, estimation tests of hypotheses, methods in multiple regression, and analysis of variance and covariance.
470.title: Statistical Methods for Health Policy and Management (3)

472.description: Concepts and methods of the program evaluation paradigm as applied in health administration.
472.title: Program Evaluation (3)

496.description: Directed readings or research. Written reports are required.
496.title: Readings in Health Policy and Management (1–3)

510.description: This course will address the ethical issues of health policy and management, with particular attention to the global perspectives on these issues. These global perspectives are both comparative and transnational.
510.title: Global Perspectives on Ethical Issues in Health Policy and Management (3)

522.description: Current issues pertaining to the health and wellbeing of older Americans, and how such issues influence family dynamics and choices about long-term care. Critical topics on chronic illness, family and community caregiving, ethnicity/culture, and socioeconomic status will be covered in the course.
522.title: Aging, Family, and Long-Term Care: Cultural, Ethnic, and Racial Issues (3)

531.description: Permission of the instructor. Restricted to seniors. Course targets students interested in a health care career. Topics include structure of group practices, governance/ownership, risk management, malpractice, physician compensation, operational and financial management.
531.title: Physician Practice Management (3)

532.description: This course will provide students with a working knowledge of the various forms of health care consulting, including internal consulting. Students will enhance their analytical, presentation, teamwork, and project management skills.
532.title: Health Care Consulting (3)

551.title: Medical and Science Video Storytelling (HBEH 561, JOMC 561) (3)

560.description: Introduces students to news media organizations and their role in health policy development. Students will learn how to evaluate media content and strategies and to communicate effectively via mass media.
560.title: Media and Health Policy (3)

564.description: Restricted to HPM majors. An overview of key health services issues including quality, access, financing, insurance, ethics, and delivery systems plus an introduction to health care policy and politics.
564.title: Health Care in the United States: Administrative and Policy Issues (3)

600.description: Permission of the instructor. restricted to seniors. does not qualify as a core course or elective for HPM undergraduate majors. Provides an overview of the United states health system, emphasizing role of policy development and administrative decision making through case examples.
600.title: Introduction to Health Policy and Management (2)

601.description: Lectures on current topics in health care.
601.title: Issues in Health Care (1)

602.description: Permission of the program director. Supervised activities in an approved health organization, to include one or more specific projects, approved by HPM faculty member and directed by an approved preceptor/mentor in the organization.
602.title: Concurrent Practice (1–3)

605.description: This course is the first of six field-based journal practica in which students monitor their learning processes, identify where knowledge and skills learned in courses are helpful and relevant to areas of their professional responsibility, and apply that knowledge and those skills to actual work situations.
605.title: Practice Application Journaling I (0

606.description: Prerequisite, HPM 605. This course is the second of six field-based journal practica in which students monitor their learning processes, identify where knowledge and skills learned in courses are helpful and relevant to areas of their professional responsibility, and apply that knowledge and those skills to actual work situations.
606.title: Practice Application Journaling II (0

607.description: This course is the third of six field-based journal practica in which students monitor their learning processes, identify where knowledge and skills learned in courses are helpful and relevant to areas of their professional responsibility, and apply that knowledge and those skills to actual work situations.
607.title: Practice Application Journaling III (0

608.description: This course is the fourth of six field-based journal practica in which students monitor their learning processes, identify where knowledge and skills learned in courses are helpful and relevant to areas of their professional responsibility, and apply that knowledge and those skills to actual work situations.
608.title: Practice Application Journaling IV (0

609.description: This course is the fifth of six field-based journal practica in which students monitor their learning processes, identify where knowledge and skills learned in courses are helpful and relevant to areas of their professional responsibility, and apply that knowledge and those skills to actual work situations.
609.title: Practice Application Journaling V (0

610.description: This course is the sixth and final of six field-based journal practica in which students monitor their learning processes, identify where knowledge and skills learned in courses are helpful and relevant to areas of their professional responsibility, and apply that knowledge and those skills to actual work situations.
610.title: Practice Application Journaling VI (0

611.description: This course develops systems reasoning in health policy and management students through the application of systems techniques and systems thinking to core public health concepts in health policy and management, environmental health, epidemiology, and health behavior.
611.title: Public Health Concepts in a Systems Context (3)

620.description: Focuses on implementing informatics programs and projects in health organizations. Informatics initiatives aim to facilitate effective information use for the purpose of improving the quality of health services and/or efficiency of processes. Therefore, these initiatives have implicationsfor various stakeholder groups, including consumers, practitioners, administrators, and policy makers.
620.title: Implementing Health Informatics Initiatives (3)

634.description: Examines conventional public health constructs of community preparedness and disaster management. Includes a review of traditional and emerging literature. Emphasizes conceptual development and application of adaptive leadership strategies.
634.title: Public Health Issues in Community Preparedness and Disaster Management (PWAD 634) (3)

652.description: Focus is on determination of costs and benefits associated with alternative resource allocation schemes. Crucial economic concepts (e.g., utility valuation of health states and marginal analysis) are presented.
652.title: Economic Evaluation of Health Care Technology (DPOP 802) (3)

660.description: Methods of comparing health systems, examinations of related national health systems, and analysis of related high prevalence health issues.
660.title: International and Comparative Health Systems (3)

664.description: Globalization— its economic, environmental, political, technological, institutional, and sociocultural dimensions—historically and currently contributes to beneficial and adverse effects on population, community, and family and individual health.
664.title: Globalization and Health (MHCH 664) (3)

670.description: Course will prepare students to simulate health services using the MedModel simulation software. Basic concepts of discrete event simulation.
670.title: Systems Simulation for Health Services (3)

690.description: Special topics course for health policy and management undergraduate students.
690.title: Special Topics in Health Policy and Management (0

691H.description: Required preparation, approved cumulative grade point average by the end of the junior year. Readings and seminars for undergraduates showing potential and talent for research. Students will design an independent research project, write a proposal, and complete an IRB application as partial completion of an honors thesis.
691H.title: Honors Research (3)

692H.description: Prerequisite, HPM 691H. Permission of the instructor. Students collect data, analyze and report findings, and make recommendations to complete an honor thesis and present findings in presentation/poster format.
692H.title: Independent Honors Research (3)

697.description: The capstone course is an “integrative exercise” for BSPH students prior to graduation. It is intended to simulate the integration of various disciplines—finance, human resources, ethics, policy, operations, and information technology—into a comprehensive and practical framework. Students work with health care organizations to solve financial or operational problems.
697.title: BSPH Capstone (3)

701.description: restricted to HPM majors. supervised professional training (fee is $550).
701.title: Professional Training I (1)

702.description: restricted to HPM majors. supervised professional training (fee is $500).
702.title: Professional Training II (1)

703.description: restricted to HPM majors. supervised professional training (fee is $500).
703.title: Professional Training III (1–21)

705.description: This course is the first of two workshops for students in the executive Master’s Program. These workshops are designed to provide students exposure to key cross cutting skills that will be used in the program. These skills also are essential for effective healthcare management.
705.title: Healthcare Management Skills Development Workshop I (0

706.description: Prerequisite, HPM 705. This course is the second of two workshops for students in the executive Master’s Program. These workshops are designed to provide students exposure to key cross cutting skills that will be used in the program. These skills also are essential for effective healthcare management.
706.title: Healthcare Management Skills Development Workshop II (0

710.description: An introduction to law and the legal system as it relates to the delivery and financing of health care.
710.title: Health Law (3)

711.description: This course is aimed at doctoral and M.s.P.H. students with interests in research management and ethics. Using cases and examples, the first part of the course focuses on major management and leadership issues, while the second part deals with ethically relevant matters.
711.title: Research Management and Ethics in Health Policy (1)
