402.description: Prerequisite, LGLA 101. Continues the introduction of the essential elements of Lingala structure and vocabulary and aspects of African cultures. Aural comprehension, reading, speaking, and writing are stressed.
402.title: Elementary Lingala II (3)

403.description: This course increases language learning ability, communicative proficiency, and proficiency in the cultures of the Lingala-speaking people.
403.title: Intermediate Lingala III (3)

404.description: This course reinforces language learning ability, communicative proficiency in the culture of the Lingala-speaking people through gradual exposure to more challenging tasks, with emphasis on poetry and prose reading, and creative writing.
404.title: Intermediate Lingala IV (3)

101.description: Introduction to the formal analysis of human language, including sounds, words, sentences, and language meaning, plus child language acquisition, language change over time, social attitudes toward language, and similarities and differences among languages. Other topics may include writing systems, animal communication, and language analysis by computers.
101.title: Introduction to Language (3)

200.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Description and analysis of sound patterns from languages around the world. Introduction to formal phonological models, written argumentation, and hypothesis testing.
200.title: Phonology (3)

201.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Introduction to the goals and methods of transformational analysis, using English primarily, but examining how these techniques can be used to describe syntactic processes in other languages.
201.title: Syntax (3)

202.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Introduction to the analysis and description of language change, relationships among languages, and types of linguistic structure.
202.title: Linguistic Variation and Language Change (3)

203.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Provides an introduction to first-language acquisition, focusing on the acquisition of phonology, morphology, syntax, and semantics, as well as on the social context of language acquisition and issues of atypical language development.
203.title: Language Acquisition and Development (3)

222.description: An examination of the differences between natural human languages and other communication systems. Includes a philosophical inquiry into how languages relate to the world and the mind.
222.title: Language and Communication (3)

290.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Indepth treatment of a selected issue or topic in linguistics. Topic will vary with the instructor. Course may be taken more than once when the topic varies.
290.title: Special Topics in Linguistics (3)

302.description: This course provides an overview of language and power studies. Issues: sexist and sex-neutral language; languages of subcultures defined by gender, sexual orientation, ethnicity; hate speech; “politically correct” language.
302.title: Language and Power (ANTH 302, WMST 302) (3)

303.description: This course is an introduction to languages indigenous to the Americas. The course touches on the linguistic structure and classification of Native American languages as well as on social issues.
303.title: Native Languages of the Americas (ANTH 303) (3)

304.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Focuses on the use of linguistic forms to express communicative intentions. How language is used for the purposes of persuasion, manipulation, irony, humor, poetry, propaganda, and attitudes.
304.title: Introduction to Discourse (3)

310.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. This course treats the structural properties of African American English. Students will learn to use sentence data to test hypotheses about language structure by investigating the syntax and semantics of African American English.
310.title: Formal Perspectives on African American English (3)

333.description: Comparative study of human language alongside selected nonhuman communication systems. Anatomy, acoustics, combinatorial structure, innateness and acquisition, evolution. Sizable lab and field component.
333.title: Human Language and Animal Communication Systems (3)

383.description: Linguistic structuralism as a background for modern theories of language.
383.title: Linguistic Structuralism: Sources and Influences (3)

400.description: An introduction to the scientific study of language. The nature of language structure. How languages are alike and how they differ.
400.title: Introduction to General Linguistics (ANTH 400) (3)

401.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Uses simple linguistic problems to introduce students to the use of programming languages especially suited to analyze and process natural language on the computer. No prior programming knowledge is presupposed.
401.title: Language and Computers (3)

409.description: Development of and present state of research in cognitive linguistics. Readings discuss various language phenomena and are drawn from linguistics, psychology, philosophy, artificial intelligence, and literary analysis of metaphor.
409.title: Cognitive Linguistics (3)

422.description: Prerequisite, LING 200, 520, 523, or SPHS 540. Focuses on the practical skills required to carry out basic experiments in speech production or perception. Includes training in a general-purpose programming language (such as Perl) for automating repetitive tasks, experiment-control software, audio stimulus manufacture and editing, palatography, aerodynamic measurements, and other laboratory techniques relevant to student interests.
422.title: Research Methods in Phonetics and Laboratory Phonology (3)

484.title: Discourse and Dialogue in Ethnographic Research (ANTH 484, FOLK 484) (3)

490.description: Directed readings on linguistic topics not covered in specific courses.
490.title: Advanced Topics in Linguistics (3)

496.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. LING 101 and additional coursework in linguistics strongly recommended. An intensive mentored project; topic to be determined in a learning contract between student and instructor.
496.title: Independent Study in Linguistics (1–3)

50.description: (3). The linguistic landscape of the United States in historical and contemporary perspective: American English dialects, language maintenance and shift among Native American and immigrant groups, language politics and policy.
50.title: First-Year Seminar: Language in the U

520.description: Introduction to the general principles of linguistic phonetics; anatomy of vocal tract, physiology of speech production, universal phonetic theory. Practice in the recognition and transcription of speech sounds.
520.title: Linguistic Phonetics (ANTH 520) (3)

522.description: Prerequisites, LING 520, and 200 or 523. This course relates linguistic theory to experimental findings. Students design and carry out experiments to test theoretical issues of current theoretical importance.
522.title: Experimental Phonetics and Laboratory Phonology (3)

523.description: Prerequisite, LING 520, or SPHS 530 or 540. Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. Introduction to the principles of modern generative phonology. Methods and theory of phonological analysis.
523.title: Phonological Theory I (ANTH 523) (3)

524.description: Prerequisite, LING 200 or 523. Intermediate phonological theory and analysis.
524.title: Phonological Theory II (3)

525.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. Theories and methods of historical and comparative linguistics, with emphasis upon the Indo-European family.
525.title: Introduction to Historical and Comparative Linguistics (3)

527.description: Prerequisite, LING 101 or 400. Cross-linguistic investigation of internal word structure: inflection and derivation, word formation rules versus affixation, autosegmental morphology, morpholexical and morphophonemic rules, and the interaction of morphology with phonology and syntax.
527.title: Morphology (3)

528.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. One course in phonology or syntax recommended. Child language from a theoretical perspective. Topics include segmentation problems, acquisition of phonology, morphology and syntax, lexical acquisition, and language development in blind and deaf children and in bilinguals.
528.title: Language Acquisition I (3)

529.description: Prerequisites, LING 203 or 528, and LING 201 or 530. This course focuses on the development of syntax in first-language acquisition in children. Topics will include parameter setting, null subjects, root infinitives, aspect, A-movement, binding theory, and control.
529.title: Language Acquisition II (3)

530.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. Methods and theory of grammatical analysis within the transformational generative framework. Special emphasis on analyzing syntactic and semantic structures of English.
530.title: Syntactic Theory I (3)

533.description: Prerequisite, LING 530. Methods and theory of grammatical analysis, with special reference to transformational grammar.
533.title: Syntactic Theory II (3)

537.description: Prerequisite, LING 101 or 400. Semantics as a part of linguistic theory: coand disjoint reference among nominals, “crossover” phenomena, quantifier scope, lexical semantics, Montague grammar and compositional semantics, and explanatory universals in semantic theory.
537.title: Semantic Theory I (3)

538.description: Prerequisite, LING 537. A continuation of LING 537 (Semantic Theory I), this course prepares the student to read the formal semantic literature and to do original research in the field.
538.title: Semantic Theory II (3)

539.description: Prerequisite, LING 101 or 400. The representation of time and temporal relations in natural languages. Cross-linguistic study of tense and aspect distinctions, modality, temporal adverbials, temporal anaphora, and sequences of tenses.
539.title: Language of Time (3)

540.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Introduction to topics in logic, set theory, and modern algebra with emphasis on linguistic application. Automata theory and the formal theory of grammar with special reference to transformational grammars. No previous mathematics assumed.
540.title: Mathematical Linguistics (3)

541.description: Prerequisite, LING 101 or 400. Introduction to the study of language in relation to society; variation as it correlates with socioeconomic status, region, gender; the social motivation of change; language and equality; language maintenance, planning, shift.
541.title: Sociolinguistics (ANTH 541) (3)

542.description: Prerequisite, LING 101 or 400. Examination of the social contexts of language contact and their linguistic outcomes, with particular emphasis on the formation of pidgins and creoles. The course investigates the structural properties of these new contact languages and evaluates the conflicting theories that explain their genesis.
542.title: Pidgins and Creoles (ANTH 542) (3)

543.description: Examines language as a political issue in the 19th and 20th centuries. Emphasis placed on American and British politics but attention to one other national context as well.
543.title: Language in Politics (3)

545.description: Prerequisite, ENGL 313, or LING 101 or 400, or PHIL 145. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. The course treats the relationship among linguistics, artificial intelligence, neurobiology, cognitive psychology, and the philosophies of mind, language, and science.
545.title: Language and Mind: Linguistics and the Brain (3)

547.description: Prerequisite, LING 101 or 400. Survey of the linguistic properties associated with aphasia, autism, Williams syndrome, dyslexia, and schizophrenia. Emphasis on the implications of these conditions for theories of mind.
547.title: Language Deficits and Cognition (3)

550.description: A survey of the phonological systems of the major Indo-European languages and their development from Proto-Indo-European.
550.title: Introduction to Indo-European: Phonology (3)

551.description: Prerequisite, LING 550. Introduction to the major morphological categories in the Indo-European languages and their development from the proto-language.
551.title: Introduction to Indo-European: Morphology (3)

558.description: This course is an introduction to the ancient scripts of pre-Columbian Mexico and Central America. It focuses on the following scripts: Mayan, Epi-Olmec, Zapotec, and Mixtec.
558.title: Mesoamerican Writing Systems (3)

560.description: Surveys the basic characteristics that unify Mesoamerica as a cultural and linguistic area (e.g., sound systems, word order, color systems, diffused vocabulary, etc.), the basic sources of cultural and linguistic information available (e.g., ancient hieroglyphs, colonial manuscripts, contemporary documents, linguistic fieldwork), and the consequences of ancient and modern cross-cultural interaction.
560.title: Mesoamerican Languages and Linguistics (3)

561.description: Prerequisite, LING 101 or 400. This course explores the phonological and morphological structure of selected Amerindian languages indigenous to the Americas. Emphasis is on the linguistic analysis of original as well as published primary data.
561.title: Native Languages of the Americas (3)

562.description: Prerequisite, LING 101 or RUSS 102. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Examines Russian from the perspective of linguistic analysis. How do sounds, words, and sentences pattern in Russian? How do these compare with patterns in other languages? Also considers the influence of evidence from Russian on the development of linguistic theory.
562.title: Structure of Russian (3)

563.description: Prerequisite, JAPN 102 or LING 101. Introductory linguistic description of modern Japanese. For students of linguistics with no knowledge of Japanese and students of Japanese with no knowledge of linguistics.
563.title: Structure of Japanese (JAPN 563) (3)

573.description: Analysis and description of a language unknown to the class from data solicited from a native-speaker consultant.
573.title: Linguistic Field Methods I (ANTH 793) (3)

583.description: Prerequisite, LING 101. Linguistic theories from classical times to the present with special emphasis on the origins of contemporary theories.
583.title: History and Philosophy of Linguistics (3)

678.title: Cultural and Linguistic History of the Spanish Language (SPAN 678) (3)

691H.description: See the program for honors in the College of Arts and Sciences and the department honors advisor.
691H.title: Senior Honors Thesis (3)

692H.description: See the program for honors in the College of Arts and Sciences and the department honors advisor.
692H.title: Senior Honors Thesis (3)

712.title: Advanced Studies in Philosophy of Language (PHIL 745) (3)

715.description: Prerequisite, linG 524. Methods of theoretical argumentation in generative phonology with emphasis on recent proposals in the published literature.
715.title: Advanced Methods in Phonology (3)

716.description: Prerequisite, linG 533. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. examination of recent developments in the theory and methods of syntactic analysis.
716.title: Advanced Methods in Syntax (3)

730.description: introductory and advanced work in the earlier stages of extant languages and in extinct languages.
730.title: Comparative Grammar of Ancient Languages (3)

793.description: Analysis and description of a language unknown to the class from data solicited from a native-speaker consultant.
793.title: Linguistic Field Work I (ANTH 793) (3)

814.description: Prerequisite, enGl 719 or permission of the instructor. see enGl 814 for description.
814.title: History of the English Language (ENGL 814) (3)

860.description: topics vary to include specialized areas of linguistics study.
860.title: Seminar (3)

861.description: seminar in phonological theory. 862 Seminar (3). seminar in grammatical theory.
861.title: Seminar (3)

89.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
89.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

893.description: This course explores relations of linguistics with neighboring fields and theoretical problems of current relevance within linguistics itself; some attention given to pedagogical methodology.
893.title: Current Problems in Linguistics (3)

897.description: readings in linguistic topics that are not covered in the existing courses.
897.title: Special Readings (3)

101.description: A broad interdisciplinary introduction to the field of Latin American studies.
101.title: Introduction to Latin American Studies (3)

291.description: This is a reading and discussion seminar that will introduce students to topics in the history of Latinos in the United States from the 19th century to the present.
291.title: The Latino Experience in the United States (3)

396.description: Independent project to be arranged with an instructor.
396.title: Independent Study (1–3)

411.description: A three-part intensive introduction to spoken and written modern Yucatec Maya, including classroom instruction; culture, history, and linguistics workshops; and a four-week field study in Yucatán, Mexico.
411.title: Summer Intensive Introductory Course in Yucatec Maya (6)

512.description: Prerequisite, LTAM 411. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Continuing instruction in spoken and written Yucatec Maya. Classroom instruction; culture, history, and linguistics workshops; and field study. Taught in Yucatán, Mexico.
512.title: Summer Intensive Continuing Course in Yucatec Maya (6)

691H.description: Directed independent research leading to the preparation of an honors thesis.
691H.title: Honors in Latin American Studies (3)

692H.description: Completion of the honors thesis and an oral examination of the thesis.
692H.title: Honors in Latin American Studies (3)

89.description: Special topics course\. Content will vary each semester.
89.title: First Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

401.description: Pronunciation, structure of language, and reading in modern Macedonian.
401.title: Elementary Macedonian (3)

402.description: Pronunciation, structure of language, and reading in modern Macedonian, continued.
402.title: Elementary Macedonian (3)

403.description: Continuation of the proficiency-based instruction begun in Elementary Macedonian.
403.title: Intermediate Macedonian (3)

404.description: Continuation of the proficiency-based instruction begun in Elementary Macedonian, continued.
404.title: Intermediate Macedonian (3)

405.description: Advanced reading and discussion in Macedonian in humanities and social science topics.
405.title: Advanced Macedonian (3)

406.description: Advanced reading and discussion in Macedonian in humanities and social science topics, continued.
406.title: Advanced Macedonian (3)

108.description: Students quantify global depletion of energy resources and accompanying environmental degradation, discovering the profound changes in attitudes and behavior required to adjust to diminished fossil fuels and modified climate.
108.title: Our Energy and Environmental Crises: Challenges and Opportunities (4)

190.description: An undergraduate seminar course that is designed to be a participatory intellectual adventure on an advanced, emergent, and stimulating topic within a selected discipline in marine sciences.
190.title: Special Topics in Marine Sciences (3)

220.description: Natural processes and human impacts on estuarine systems using the Neuse River estuary as a case study. Course includes one week of intensive field work based at the Institute of Marine Sciences. A student may not receive credit for this course after receiving credit for ENEC 222.
220.title: North Carolina Estuaries: Environmental Processes and Problems (3)

310.description: An overview of the scientific basis for global warming, current and future impacts on society, options for mitigation and adaptation, and the role of politics and the media.
310.title: Our Changing Planet: Science, Social Impacts, Solutions (3)

312.description: Case studies in environmental change, highlighting human and environmental dynamics in terrestrial and marine ecosystems on multiple spatial and temporal scales. Includes active-learning modules, group presentations, writing assignments.
312.title: From the Equator to the Poles: Case Studies in Global Environmental Change (3)

314.description: This course presents an integrated view of our planet, how it evolved during the past, why it has changed (and continues to change) and what makes earth a habitable planet.
314.title: Earth Systems in a Changing World (3)

390.description: Special topics in marine sciences for undergraduate students.
390.title: Special Topics in Marine Sciences (1–4)

395.description: Permission of a faculty research director. Directed readings with laboratory study on a selected topic.
395.title: Undergraduate Research in Marine Sciences (2–4)

396.description: Permission of the instructor. Directed readings on a selected topic.
396.title: Independent Study in Marine Sciences (1–3)

401.description: Required preparation, major in a natural science or two courses in natural sciences. Studies origin of ocean basins, seawater chemistry and dynamics, biological communities, sedimentary record, andoceanographic history. Term paper. Students lacking science background should see MASC 101. No credit for MASC 401 after receiving credit for MASC 101.
401.title: Oceanography (BIOL 350, ENVR 417, GEOL 403) (3)

410.description: See ENEC 410 for description.
410.title: Earth Processes in Environmental Systems (ENEC 410, GEOL 410) (4)

411.description: See ENEC 411 for description.
411.title: Oceanic Processes in Environmental Systems (ENEC 411, GEOL 411) (4)

432.description: What are the linkages between rivers and global change? This course examines the hydrological, geological, and biogeochemical processes that control material flux from land to the oceans via rivers.
432.title: Major Rivers and Global Change: Mountains to the Sea (3)

436.description: An interdisciplinary description and analysis of environmental processes that form and maintain coastal habitats. Coastal aspects of geology, fluid dynamics, chemistry, and biology are considered. two lectures per week and two coastal field trips.
436.title: Coastal Processes (4)

441.description: This course introduces students to the physiological, morphological, and behavioral factors employed by marine organisms to cope with their physical environment. Emphasis will be placed on the response of marine organisms to environmental factors such as seawater temperature, light, water salinity, ocean acidification, etc.
441.title: Marine Physiological Ecology (3)

442.description: Recommended preparation, BIOL 201 or 475. A survey of plants and animals that live in the sea: characteristics of marine habitats, organisms, and the ecosystems will be emphasized. Marine environment, the organisms involved, and the ecological systems that sustain them.
442.title: Marine Biology (BIOL 457) (3)

443.description: Restricted to junior or senior science majors or graduate students, with permission of the instructor. Seminar class focuses on the primary research literature. Physiology of marine microorganisms, microbial diversity and ecology of the marine environment, biogeochemical processes catalyzed by marine microorganisms.
443.title: Marine Microbiology (3)

444.description: Permission of the instructor. For junior and senior science majors or graduate students. Biology of marine photosynthetic protists and cyanobacteria. Phytoplankton evolution, biodiversity, structure, function, biogeochemical cycles and genomics. Harmful algal blooms, commercial products, and climate change. Three lecture/practical session hours per week.
444.title: Marine Phytoplankton (3)

448.description: Prerequisites, CHEM 102 and MATH 231. A field-intensive study of the ecology of marine organisms and their interactions with their environment, including commercially important organisms. Laboratory/ recitation/field work is included and contributes two credit hours to the course.
448.title: Coastal and Estuarine Ecology (ENEC 448) (4)

450.description: See ENEC 450 for description.
450.title: Biogeochemical Processes (ENEC 450, GEOL 450) (4)

460.description: Prerequisite, MATH 232. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Principles and applications of fluid dynamics to flows of air and water in the natural environment. Conservation of momentum, mass, and energy applied to lakes, rivers, estuaries, and the coastal ocean. Dimensional analysis and scaling emphasized to promote problem-solving skills.
460.title: Fluid Dynamics of the Environment (3)

470.description: For graduate students; undergraduate students should take ENEC 222 or have permission of the instructor. Introduction to estuarine environments: geomorphology, physical circulation, nutrient loading, primary and secondary production, carbon and nitrogen cycling, benthic processes and sedimentation. Considers human impacts on coastal systems, emphasizing North Carolina estuaries. Three lecture hours and one recitation hour per week.
470.title: Estuarine and Coastal Marine Science (4)

471.description: See ENEC 471 for description.
471.title: Human Impacts on Estuarine Ecosystems (ENEC 471) (4)

472.description: Recommended preparation, one introductory geology course. An integration of barrier island plant and animal ecology within the context of physical processes and geomorphological change. Emphasis on management and impact of human interference with natural processes.
472.title: Barrier Island Ecology and Geology (6)

480.description: Prerequisite, MATH 232. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Mathematical modeling of dynamic systems, linear and nonlinear. The fundamental budget equation. Case studies in modeling transport, biogeochemical processes, population dynamics. Analytical and numerical techniques; chaos theory; fractal geometry.
480.title: Modeling of Marine and Earth Systems (ENVR 480, GEOL 480) (3)

483.title: Geologic and Oceanographic Applications of Geographical Information Systems (GEOL 483) (4)

490.description: Directed readings, laboratory, and/or field study of marine science topics not covered in scheduled courses.
490.title: Special Topics in Marine Sciences for Undergraduates and Graduates (1–3)

503.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Investigates formation of ocean basins, coastal and fluvial processes, sediment transport, plate tectonics, petrography of marine rocks, evolution of ocean chemistry, oceanic biogeochemical cycles, application of geochemical proxies in paleoceanographic reconstructions, macroevolutionary patterns of marine biota, and global oceanic change. Mandatory weekend fieldtrip.
503.title: Marine Geology (GEOL 503) (4)

504.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Marine ecosystem processes pertaining to the structure, function, and ecological interactions of biological communities; management of biological resources; taxonomy and natural history of pelagic and benthic marine organisms. Three lecture and one recitation hours per week. Two mandatory weekend fieldtrips.
504.title: Biological Oceanography (BIOL 657, ENVR 520) (4)

505.description: Graduate students only; undergraduates must have permission of the instructor. Overview of chemical processes in the ocean. Topics include physical chemistry of seawater, major element cycles, hydrothermal vents, geochemical tracers, air-sea gas exchange, particle transport, sedimentary processes, and marine organic geochemistry. Three lecture and two recitation hours per week.
505.title: Chemical Oceanography (ENVR 505, GEOL 505) (4)

506.description: For graduate students; undergraduates need permission of the instructor. Descriptive oceanography, large-scale wind-driven and thermohaline circulations, ocean dynamics, regional and nearshore/estuarine physical processes, waves, tides. Three lecture and one recitation hour per week.
506.title: Physical Oceanography (GEOL 506) (4)

51.description: Students will examine evidence that human activity has caused global warming, investigate scientists’ ability to predict climate change, and discuss the political and social dimensions of global climate change.
51.title: First-Year Seminar: Global Warming: Serious Threat or Hot Air? (3)

52.description: Modern theories of changing weather, severe weather events, oceanic hazards, interactions between the oceans and atmosphere, and changes that are linked to human activity.
52.title: First-Year Seminar: Living with Our Oceans and Atmosphere (3)

53.description: What explains the “pull of the poles”? This seminar combines a modern survey of polar oceanography with historical views of early polar explorations, as reported by the explorers themselves.
53.title: First-Year Seminar: The Ends of the Earth: Polar Oceanography and Exploration (3)

55.description: This course provides an opportunity to explore changes in marine and closely linked terrestrial environments caused by the interactions of fascinating oceanographic processes. Introductory presentations and discussions will focus on published works of active marine scientists who combine disciplinary training with knowledge and skills from other fields.
55.title: First-Year Seminar: Change in the Coastal Ocean (3)

550.description: Recommended preparation, four ENVR, GEOL, or MASC courses above 400. This course explores interfaces of marine, aquatic, atmospheric, and geological sciences emphasizing processes controlling chemical distributions in sediments, fresh and salt water, the atmosphere, and fluxes among these reservoirs.
550.title: Biogeochemical Cycling (GEOL 550) (3)

552.description: Recommended preparation, CHEM 261 or MASC 505, and one additional ENVR, GEOL, or MASC course above 400. Sources, transformations, and fate of natural organic matter in marine environments. Emphasis on interplay of chemical, biological, and physical processes that affect organic matter composition, distribution, and turnover.
552.title: Organic Geochemistry (GEOL 552) (3)

560.description: Prerequisite, PHYS 301. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. The physical properties of fluids, kinematics, governing equations, viscous incompressible flow, vorticity dynamics, boundary layers, irrotational incompressible flow.
560.title: Fluid Dynamics (ENVR 452, GEOL 560, PHYS 660) (3)

561.description: Prerequisite, MATH 233. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Three components: statistics and probability, time series analysis, and spatial data analysis. Harmonic analysis, nonparametric spectral estimation, filtering, objective analysis, empirical orthogonal functions.
561.title: Time Series and Spatial Data Analysis (3)

562.description: Prerequisite, MASC 506 or 560. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Turbulence and transport in near-bottom boundary regions. Turbulence and mixing theory in boundary layers. Field deployment and recovery of turbulence measuring instruments. Data analysis from turbulence measurements.
562.title: Turbulent Boundary Layers (3)

563.description: Prerequisite, MASC 506. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Observed structure of the large-scale and mesoscale ocean circulation and its variability, based on modern observations. In-situ and remote sensing techniques, hydrographic structure, circulation patterns, ocean-atmosphere interactions.
563.title: Descriptive Physical Oceanography (GEOL 563) (3)

57.description: Students will develop the conceptual framework necessary to understand waves of any kind, starting from laboratory observations.
57.title: First-Year Seminar: From “The Sound of Music” to “The Perfect Storm” (MATH 63) (3)

58.description: This course explores the natural history of several inlets, impact of human intervention, and political/policy challenges faced; includes several group projects/ presentations and a field trip to a coastal inlet.
58.title: First-Year Seminar: Connections to the Sea: Challenges Faced by Using and Living near Coastal Inlets (3)

705.description: discussion of methods and strategies for giving effective technical presentations. topics will include seminar structure, use of visual aids, personal and professional presentation, and responding to questions.
705.title: How to Give a Seminar (1)

706.description: discussion of theories and contemporary research in ocean systems. topics stress interactions between physical, chemical, geological, and biological processes in the sea. for graduate students in marine sciences. students who enroll must present an interdisciplinary seminar.
706.title: Seminar in Oceanography (1)

741.description: discussion of selected literature in the field of marine biology, ecology, and evolution.
741.title: Seminar in Marine Biology (2)

742.description: Prerequisite, biol 471. Permission of the instructor. Hands-on training, experience, and discussion of the application of molecular genetic tools to questions of ecology, evolution, systematics, and conservation.
742.title: Molecular Population Biology (BIOL 758) (4)

750.description: Prerequisite, MAsC 480. Permission of the instructor. An introduction to the theory and application of modeling biogeochemical processes in sediments. diagenetic theory, numerical techniques, and examples of recently developed sediment models. Three lecture hours a week.
750.title: Modeling Diagenetic Processes (3)

761.description: Prerequisite, MAsC 560 or MAtH 528. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Momentum equations in a rotating reference frame, vorticity, potential vorticity, circulation, the shallow water model, rossby and Kelvin waves, the ekman layer. Three lecture hours a week.
761.title: Geophysical Fluid Dynamics (3)

762.description: Prerequisite, MAsC 506 or 560, or MAtH 529, Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Theories, models of large-scale dynamics of ocean circulation. Potential vorticity, quasi-geostrophy, instabilities.
762.title: Ocean Circulation Theory (3)

763.description: Prerequisite, MAsC 506 or 560, or MAtH 529. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. dynamics of the coastal ocean. shallow water equations, boundary layer and long wave theory, wind driven circulation, fronts, estuaries.
763.title: Coastal Circulation (3)

764.description: Prerequisite, MAsC 506 or MAtH 529. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Computational methods used in modeling oceanic circulation. numerical solution of equations governing mass, momentum, and energy equations.
764.title: Ocean Circulation Modeling (3)

765.description: Prerequisites, MAsC 506 and 560. Physics of sub-mesoscale processes in the ocean. nonequilibrium thermodynamics. Air-sea interaction. Mixing in the ocean boundary layer, convection, double diffusion. near-inertial and high frequency internal waves. Three lecture hours a week.
765.title: Small-Scale Physics of the Ocean (3)

89.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
89.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

110.description: Placement by achievement test. Provides a onesemester review of the basics of algebra. Basic algebraic expressions, functions, exponents, and logarithms are included, with an emphasis on problem solving. This course should not be taken by those with a suitable score on the achievement test.
110.title: Algebra (3)

116.description: Provides an introduction in as nontechnical a setting as possible to the basic concepts of calculus. The course is intended for the nonscience major. A student may not receive credit for this course after receiving credit for MATH 152, 231, or 241.
116.title: Intuitive Calculus (3)

117.description: Introduction to basic concepts of finite mathematics, including topics such as counting methods, finite probability problems, and networks. The course is intended for the nonscience major.
117.title: Aspects of Finite Mathematics (3)

118.description: Introduction to mathematical topics of current interest in society and science, such as the mathematics of choice, growth, finance, and shape. The course is intended for the nonscience major.
118.title: Aspects of Modern Mathematics (3)

119.description: Provides an introduction to the use of mathematics for modeling real-world phenomena in a nontechnical setting. Models use algebraic, graphical, and numerical properties of elementary functions to interpret data. This course is intended for the nonscience major.
119.title: Introduction to Mathematical Modeling (3)

130.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. Covers the basic mathematical skills needed for learning calculus. Topics are calculating and working with functions and data, introduction to trigonometry, parametric equations, and the conic sections. A student may not receive credit for this course after receiving credit for MATH 231.
130.title: Precalculus Mathematics (3)

152.description: Prerequisite, MATH 110. An introductory survey of differential and integral calculus with emphasis on techniques and applications of interest for business and the social sciences. This is a terminal course and not adequate preparation for MATH 232. A student cannot receive credit for this course after receiving credit for MATH 231 or 241.
152.title: Calculus for Business and Social Sciences (3)

190.description: An undergraduate seminar course that is designed to be a participatory intellectual adventure on an advanced, emergent, and stimulating topic within a selected discipline in mathematics. This course does not count as credit towards the mathematics major.
190.title: Special Topics in Mathematics (3)

231.description: Prerequisites, MATH 110 and 130. Requires a grade of Cor better in MATH 130 or placement by the department. Limits, derivatives, and integrals of functions of one variable. Students may not receive credit for both MATH 231 and MATH 241.
231.title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable I (3)

232.description: Requires a grade of Cor better in MATH 231 or 241 or placement by the department. Calculus of the elementary transcendental functions, techniques of integration, indeterminate forms, Taylor’s formula, infinite series.
232.title: Calculus of Functions of One Variable II (3)

233.description: Prerequisite, MATH 232 or 283. Vector algebra, solid analytic geometry, partial derivatives, multiple integrals.
233.title: Calculus of Functions of Several Variables (3)

241.description: Requires a grade of Cor better in MATH 130 or placement by the department. Limits, derivatives, and integrals of functions of one variable, motivated by and applied to discrete-time dynamical systems used to model various biological processes.
241.title: BioCalculus I (3)

283.description: Requires a grade of Cor better in either MATH 231 or 241, or placement by the department. Techniques of integration, indeterminate forms, Taylor’s series; introductionto linear algebra, motivated by and applied to ordinary differential equations; systems of ordinary differential equations used to model various biological processes. A student cannot receive credit for this course after receiving credit for MATH 383.
283.title: BioCalculus II (3)

290.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Experimentation or deeper investigation under the supervision of a faculty member of topics in mathematics that may be, but need not be, connected with an existing course. No one may receive more than seven semester hours of credit for this course.
290.title: Directed Exploration in Mathematics (0–3)

294.description: Permission of the instructor. A seminar on a chosen topic in mathematics in which the students participate more actively than in usual courses.
294.title: Undergraduate Seminar in Mathematics (0–3)

307.description: Central to teaching precollege mathematics is the need for an in-depth understanding of real numbers and algebra. This course explores this content, emphasizing problem solving and mathematical reasoning.
307.title: Revisiting Real Numbers and Algebra (3)

381.description: Prerequisite, MATH 232 or 283. This course serves as a transition from computational to more theoretical mathematics. Topics are from the foundations of mathematics: logic, set theory, relations and functions, induction, permutations and combinations, recurrence.
381.title: Discrete Mathematics (3)

383.description: Prerequisite, MATH 233. Introductory ordinary differential equations, firstand second-order differential equations with applications, higher-order linear equations, systems of first-order linear equations (introducing linear algebra as needed).
383.title: First Course in Differential Equations (3)

396.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. This course is intended mainly for students working on honors projects. No one may receive more than three semester hours credit for this course.
396.title: Undergraduate Reading and Research in Mathematics (1– 3)

401.description: Mathematical theories of proportion, perspective (projective invariants and the mathematics of visual perception), symmetry, and aesthetics will be expounded and illustrated by examples from painting, architecture, and sculpture.
401.title: Mathematical Concepts in Art (3)

406.description: Prerequisite, MATH 232. Special mathematical techniques in the theory and methods of biostatistics as related to the life sciences and public health. Includes brief review of calculus, selected topics from intermediate calculus, and introductory matrix theory for applications in biostatistics.
406.title: Mathematical Methods in Biostatistics (1)

410.description: Study of how people learn and understand mathematics, based on research in mathematics, mathematics education, psychology, and cognitive science. This course is designed to prepare undergraduate mathematics majors to become excellent high school mathematics teachers. It involves fieldwork in both the high school and college environments.
410.title: Teaching and Learning Mathematics (4)

411.description: Permission of the instructor. An investigation of various ways elementary concepts in mathematics can be developed. Applications of the mathematics developed will be considered.
411.title: Developing Mathematical Concepts (3)

418.description: Prerequisites, MATH 233 and 381. An examination of high school mathematics from an advanced perspective, including number systems and the behavior of functions and equations. Designed primarily for prospective or practicing high school teachers.
418.title: Basic Concepts of Analysis for High School Teachers (3)

452.title: Mathematical and Computational Models in Biology (BIOL 452) (4)

50.description: This seminar will examine the ways in which some types of behavior of random systems cannot only be predicted, but also applied to practical problems.
50.title: First-Year Seminar: The Predictability of Chance and Its Applications in Applied Mathematics (3)

51.description: This seminar allows students to have hands-on exposure to a class of physical and computer experiments designed to challenge intuition on how motion is achieved in nature.
51.title: First-Year Seminar: “Fish Gotta Swim, Birds Gotta Fly”: Mathematics and Mechanics of Moving Things (3)

515.description: Prerequisite, MATH 381. A general survey of the history of mathematics with emphasis on elementary mathematics. Some special problems will be treated in depth.
515.title: History of Mathematics (3)

52.description: Many natural objects have complex, infinitely detailed shapes in which smaller versions of the whole shape are seen appearing throughout. Such a shape is a fractal, the topic of study.
52.title: First-Year Seminar: Fractals: The Geometry of Nature (3)

521.description: Prerequisites, MATH 233 and 381. The real numbers, continuity and differentiability of functions of one variable, infinite series, integration.
521.title: Advanced Calculus I (3)

522.description: Prerequisites, MATH 383 and 521. Functions of several variables, the derivative as a linear transformation, inverse and implicit function theorems, multiple integration.
522.title: Advanced Calculus II (3)

523.description: Prerequisite, MATH 383. The algebra of complex numbers, elementary functions and their mapping properties, complex limits, power series, analytic functions, contour integrals, Cauchy’s theorem and formulae, Laurent series and residue calculus, elementary conformal mapping and boundary value problems, Poisson integral formula for the disk and the half plane.
523.title: Functions of a Complex Variable with Applications (3)

524.description: Prerequisite, MATH 383. Linear differential equations, power series solutions, Laplace transforms, numerical methods.
524.title: Elementary Differential Equations (3)

528.description: Prerequisites, MATH 383; and PHYS 104 and 105, or PHYS 114 and 115, or PHYS 116 and 117, or PHYS 118 and 119. Theory and applications of Laplace transform, Fourier series and transform, SturmLiouville problems. Students will be expected to do some numerical calculations on either a programmable calculator or a computer. This course has an optional computer laboratory component: MATH 528L.
528.title: Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences I (3)

529.description: Prerequisites, PHYS 104 or 114, PHYS 105 or 115, and one of MATH 521, 524, or 528. Introduction to boundary value problems for the diffusion, Laplace and wave partial differential equations. Bessel functions and Legendre functions. Introduction to complex variables including the calculus of residues. This course has an optional computer laboratory component: MATH 529L.
529.title: Mathematical Methods for the Physical Sciences II (3)

53.description: Through projects using software programs, Web sites, and readings, students will discover the geometric structure of tilings, learn to design their own patterns, and explore the many interdisciplinary connections.
53.title: First-Year Seminar: Symmetry and Tilings (3)

533.description: Prerequisite, MATH 381. Divisibility, Euclidean algorithm, congruences, residue classes, Euler’s function, primitive roots, Chinese remainder theorem, quadratic residues, number-theoretic functions, Farey and continued fractions, Gaussian integers.
533.title: Elementary Theory of Numbers (3)

534.description: Prerequisite, MATH 381. Binary operations, groups, subgroups, cosets, quotient groups, rings, polynomials.
534.title: Elements of Modern Algebra (3)

54.description: Seminar will cover the history and philosophy of probability, evidence, and conjecture, consider the development of the field of probability, and look at current and future uses of probability.
54.title: First-Year Seminar: The Science of Conjecture: Its Math, Philosophy, and History (3)

547.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 233 or 283. Algebra of matrices with applications: determinants, solution of linear systems by Gaussian elimination, Gram-schmidt procedure, eigenvalues. MAtH 416 may not be taken for credit after credit has been granted for MAtH 547.
547.title: Linear Algebra for Applications (3)

548.description: Prerequisite, MATH 381. Topics chosen from generating functions, Polya’s theory of counting, partial orderings and incidence algebras, principle of inclusion-exclusion, Moebius inversion, combinatorial problems in physics and other branches of science.
548.title: Combinatorial Mathematics (3)

55.description: The nature of space imposes striking constraints on organic and inorganic objects. This seminar examines such constraints on both biological organisms and regular solids in geometry.
55.title: First-Year Seminar: Geometry and Symmetry in Nature (3)

550.description: Prerequisites, MATH 233 and 381; corequisite, MATH 383. Introduction to topics in topology, particularly surface topology, including classification of compact surfaces, Euler characteristic, orientability, vector fields on surfaces, tessellations, and fundamental group.
550.title: Topology (3)

551.description: Prerequisite, MATH 381. Critical study of basic notions and models of Euclidean and non-Euclidean geometries: order, congruence, and distance.
551.title: Euclidean and Non-Euclidean Geometries (3)

555.description: Prerequisite, MATH 383. Topics will vary and may include iteration of maps, orbits, periodic points, attractors, symbolic dynamics, bifurcations, fractal sets, chaotic systems, systems arising from differential equations, iterated function systems, and applications.
555.title: Introduction to Dynamics (3)

56.description: With the growth of available information on almost anything, can it be reliably compressed, protected, and transmitted over a noisy channel? Students will take a mathematical view of cryptography throughout history and information handling in modern life.
56.title: First-Year Seminar: Information and Coding (3)

564.description: Prerequisite, MATH 283 or 383. Requires some knowledge of computer programming. Model validation and numerical simulations using differential equations, probability, and iterated maps. Applications may include conservation laws, dynamics, mixing, geophysical flows and climate change, fluid motion, epidemics, ecological models, population biology, cell biology, and neuron dynamics.
564.title: Mathematical Modeling (3)

565.description: Prerequisite, MATH 383. Personal computer as tool in solving a variety of mathematical problems, e.g., finding roots of equations and approximate solutions to differential equations. Introduction to appropriate programming language; emphasis on graphics.
565.title: Computer-Assisted Mathematical Problem Solving (3)

566.description: Prerequisite, MATH 383. Requires some knowledge of computer programming. Iterative methods, interpolation, polynomial and spline approximations, numerical differentiation and integration, numerical solution of ordinary and partial differential equations.
566.title: Introduction to Numerical Analysis (3)

57.description: The idea of a fourth dimension has a rich and varied history. This seminar explores the concept of fourth (and higher) dimensions both mathematically and more widely in human thought.
57.title: First-Year Seminar: The Fourth Dimension (3)

577.description: Prerequisites, MATH 381 and 383. Vector spaces, linear transformations, duality, diagonalization, primary and cyclic decomposition, Jordan canonical form, inner product spaces, orthogonal reduction of symmetric matrices, spectral theorem, bilinear forms, multilinear functions. A much more abstract course than MATH 416 or 547.
577.title: Linear Algebra (3)

578.description: Prerequisite, MATH 547 or 577. Permutation groups, matrix groups, groups of linear transformations, symmetry groups; finite abelian groups. Residue class rings, algebra of matrices, linear maps, and polynomials. Real and complex numbers, rational functions, quadratic fields, finite fields.
578.title: Algebraic Structures (3)

58.description: Students will explore the relevance of mathematical ideas to fields typically perceived as “nonmathematical” (e.g., art, music, film, literature) and how these “nonmathematical” fields influence mathematical thought.
58.title: First-Year Seminar: Math, Art, and the Human Experience (3)

59.description: Problems arising from the arithmetic of ordinary counting numbers have for centuries fascinated both mathematicians and nonmathematicians. This seminar will consider some of these problems (both solved and unsolved).
59.title: First-Year Seminar: The Mystery and Majesty of Ordinary Numbers (3)

590.description: Permission of the instructor. Topics may focus on matrix theory, analysis, algebra, geometry, or applied and computational mathematics.
590.title: Topics in Mathematics (3)

60.description: This seminar introduces students to the thought process that goes into developing computational models of biological systems. It will also expose students to techniques for simulating and analyzing these models.
60.title: First-Year Seminar: Simulated Life (3)

61.description: This course will consider mathematics to be the science of patterns and will discuss some of the different kinds of patterns that give rise to different branches of mathematics.
61.title: First-Year Seminar: The Language of Mathematics: Making the Invisible Visible (3)

62.description: Students will discuss combinatorics’ deep roots in history, its connections with the theory of numbers, and its fundamental role for natural science, as well as various applications, including cryptography and the stock market.
62.title: First-Year Seminar: Combinatorics (3)

63.title: First-Year Seminar: From “The Sound of Music” to “The Perfect Storm” (MASC 57) (3)

64.description: Why is the Gulf Stream so strong, why does it flow clockwise, and why does it separate from the United States coast at Cape Hatteras? Students will study the circulation of the ocean and its influence on coastal environments through readings and by examining satellite and on-site observations.
64.title: First-Year Seminar: A View of the Sea: The Circulation of the Ocean and Its Impact on Coastal Water (3)

641.description: Prerequisite, MATH 578. Basic counting; partitions; recursions and generating functions; signed enumeration; counting with respect to symmetry, plane partitions, and tableaux.
641.title: Enumerative Combinatorics (3)

643.description: Prerequisite, MATH 578. Graph theory, matchings, Ramsey theory, extremal set theory, network flows, lattices, Moebius inversion, q-analogs, combinatorial and projective geometries, codes, and designs.
643.title: Combinatorial Structures (3)

65.description: Students will follow the intellectual journey of the atomic hypothesis from Leucippus and Democritus to the modern era, combining the history, the applications to science, and the mathematics developed to study particles and their interactions.
65.title: First-Year Seminar: Colliding Balls and Springs: The Microstructure of How Materials Behave (3)

653.description: Requires knowledge of advanced calculus. Elementary metric space topology, continuous functions, differentiation of vector-valued functions, implicit and inverse function theorems. Topics from Weierstrass theorem, existence and uniqueness theorems for differential equations, series of functions.
653.title: Introductory Analysis (3)

656.description: Prerequisite, MATH 653. A rigorous treatment of complex integration, including the Cauchy theory. Elementary special functions, power series, local behavior of analytic functions.
656.title: Complex Analysis (3)

657.description: Prerequisite, MATH 653. Requires knowledge of linear algebra. Existence and uniqueness theorems, linear and nonlinear systems, differential equations in the plane and on surfaces, Poincare-Bendixson theory, Lyapunov stability and structural stability, critical point analysis.
657.title: Qualitative Theory of Differential Equations (3)

66.description: The seminar will investigate non-Euclidean geometry (hyperbolic and spherical) from historical, mathematical, and practical perspectives. The approach will be largely algebraic, in contrast to the traditional axiomatic method.
66.title: First-Year Seminar: Non-Euclidean Geometry in Nature and History (3)

661.description: Requires some programming experience and basic numerical analysis. Error in computation, solutions of nonlinear equations, interpolation, approximation of functions, Fourier methods, numerical integration and differentiation, introduction to numerical solution of ODEs, Gaussian elimination.
661.title: Scientific Computation I (ENVR 661) (3)

662.description: Prerequisite, MATH 661. Theory and practical issues arising in linear algebra problems derived from physical applications, e.g., discretization of ODEs and PDEs. Linear systems, linear least squares, eigenvalue problems, singular value decomposition.
662.title: Scientific Computation II (COMP 662, ENVR 662) (3)

668.description: Requires an undergraduate course in differential equations. Contour integration, asymptotic expansions, steepest descent/stationary phase methods, special functions arising in physical applications, elliptic and theta functions, elementary bifurcation theory.
668.title: Methods of Applied Mathematics I (ENVR 668) (3)

669.description: Prerequisite, MATH 668. Perturbation methods for ODEs and PDEs, WKBJ method, averaging and modulation theory for linear and nonlinear wave equations, long-time asymptotics of Fourier integral representations of PDEs, Green’s functions, dynamical systems tools.
669.title: Methods of Applied Mathematics II (ENVR 669) (3)

67.description: Is the earth warming? Predictions are based largely on mathematical models. We shall consider the limitations of models in relation to making predictions. Examples of chaotic behavior will be presented.
67.title: First-Year Seminar: The Mathematics of Climate Change: Can We Predict the Future of Our Planet? (3)

676.description: Modules over rings, canonical forms for linear operators and bilinear forms, multilinear algebra, groups and group actions.
676.title: Modules, Linear Algebra, and Groups (3)

677.description: Internal structure of groups, Sylow theorems, generators and relations, group representations, fields, Galois theory, category theory.
677.title: Groups, Representations, and Fields (3)

680.description: Requires advanced calculus. Topics include (curves) Frenet formulas, isoperimetric inequality, theorems of Crofton, Fenchel, Fary-Milnor; (surfaces) fundamental forms, Gaussian and mean curvature, special surfaces, geodesics, Gauss-Bonnet theorem.
680.title: Geometry of Curves and Surfaces (3)

681.description: Prerequisites, MATH 653 and 680. Topological spaces, connectedness, separation axioms, product spaces, extension theorems. Classification of surfaces, fundamental group, covering spaces.
681.title: Introductory Topology (3)

751.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 653. basic methods in partial differential equations. topics may include: Cauchy-Kowalewski Theorem, Holmgren’s Uniqueness Theorem, laplace’s equation, Maximum Principle, dirichlet problem, harmonic functions, wave equation, heat equation.
751.title: Introduction to Partial Differential Equations (3)

753.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 653. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. lebesgue and abstract measure and integration, convergence theorems, differentiation, radon-nikodym theorem, product measures, fubini theorem, lebesgue spaces, invariance under transformations, Haar measure and convolution.
753.title: Measure and Integration (3)

755.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 656. laurent series; Mittag-leffler and weierstrass Theorems; riemann mapping theorem; runge’s theorem; additional topics chosen from: harmonic, elliptic, univalent, entire, meromorphic functions; dirichlet problem; riemann surfaces.
755.title: Advanced Complex Analysis (3)

756.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 656. elementary theory, the Cousin problems, domains of holomorphy, runge domains and polynomial approximation, local theory, complex analytic structures, coherent analytic sheaves and stein manifolds, Cartan’s theorems.
756.title: Several Complex Variables (3)

761.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 661 and 662. single, multistep methods for odes: stability regions, the root condition; stiff systems, backward difference formulas; two-point bvPs; stability theory; finite difference methods for linear advection diffusion equations.
761.title: Numerical ODE/PDE, I (ENVR 761, MASC 781) (3)

762.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 761. elliptic equation methods (finite differences, elements, integral equations); hyperbolic conservation law methods (lax-fiedrich, characteristics, entropy condition, shock tracking/ capturing); spectral, pseudo-spectral methods; particle methods, fast summation, fast multipole/vortex methods.
762.title: Numerical ODE/PDE, II (ENVR 762, MASC 782) (3)

768.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 668, 669, 661, and 662. nondimensionalization and identification of leading order physical effects with respect to relevant scales and phenomena; derivation of classical models of fluid mechanics (lubrication, slender filament, thin films, stokes flow); derivation of weakly nonlinear envelope equations.
768.title: Mathematical Modeling I (ENVR 763, MASC 783) (3)

769.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 668, 669, 661, and 662. Current modelsin science and technology: topics ranging from material science applications (e.g., flow of polymers and lCPs); geophysical applications (e.g., ocean circulation, quasi-geostrophic models, atmospheric vortices).
769.title: Mathematical Modeling II (ENVR 764, MASC 784) (3)

771.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 677. field extensions, integral ring extensions, nullstellensatz and normalization theorem, derivations and separability, local rings, valuations, completions, filtrations and graded rings, dimension theory.
771.title: Commutative Algebra (3)

773.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 676 and 781. lie groups, closed subgroups, lie algebra of a lie group, exponential map, compact groups, Haar measure, orthogonality relations, Peter-weyl theorem, maximal torus, representations, weyl character formula, homogeneous spaces.
773.title: Lie Groups (3)

774.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 676. nilpotent, solvable, and semisimple lie algebras, structure theorems, root systems, weyl groups, weights, classification of semisimple lie algebras and their finite dimensional representations, character formulas.
774.title: Lie Algebras (3)

775.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 771. topics may include: algebraic varieties, algebraic functions, abelian varieties, projective and complete varieties, algebraic groups, schemes and the Grothendieck theory, riemann-roch theorem.
775.title: Algebraic Geometry (3)

776.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 681 and 676. Homotopy and homology; simplicial complexes and singular homology; other topics may include cohomology, universal coefficient theorems, higher homotopy groups, fibre spaces.
776.title: Algebraic Topology (3)

781.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 681, 676, and 653. Calculus on manifolds, vector bundles, vector fields and differential equations, lie groups, connections, de rham cohomology.
781.title: Differentiable Manifolds (3)

782.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 781. riemannian geometry, first and second variation of area and applications, effectof curvature on homology and homotopy, Chern-weil theory of characteristic classes, Chern-Gauss-bonnet theorem.
782.title: Differential Geometry (3)

854.description: Permission of the instructor. subjects may include operator theory on Hilbert space, operators on banach spaces, locally convex spaces, vector measures, banach algebras.
854.title: Advanced Functional Analysis (3)

857.description: Permission of the instructor. topics may include: ergodic theory, topological dynamics, stability theory of differential equations, classical dynamical systems, differentiable dynamics.
857.title: Theory of Dynamical Systems (3)

89.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
89.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

891.description: Advance topics in current research in statistics and operations research.
891.title: Special Topics (1–3)

892.description: Prerequisites, MAtH 661 and 662. topics may include: finite element method; numerical methods for hyperbolic conservation laws, infinite dimensional optimization problems, variational inequalities, inverse problems.
892.title: Topics in Computational Mathematics (3)

893.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 677. topics from the theory of rings, theory of bialgebras, homological algebra, algebraic number theory, categories and functions.
893.title: Topics in Algebra (3)

894.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 642. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. topics may include: combinatorial geometries, coloring and the critical problem, the bracket algebra, reduced incidence algebras and generating functions, binomial enumeration, designs, valuation module of a lattice, lattice theory.
894.title: Topics in Combinatorial Mathematics (3)

895.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 781. topics may include elliptic operators, complex manifolds, exterior differential systems, homogeneous spaces, integral geometry, submanifolds of euclidean space, geometrical aspects of mathematical physics.
895.title: Special Topics in Geometry (3)

896.description: Prerequisite, MAtH 776. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. topics primarily from algebraic or differential topology, such as cohomology operations, homotopy groups, fibre bundles, spectral sequences, K-theory, cobordism, Morse Theory, surgery, topology of singularities.
896.title: Topics in Algebraic Topology (3)

925.description: required preparation, passed Ph.d. written comprehensive exam. An opportunity for the practical training of a graduate student interested in mathematics is identified. typically this opportunity is expected to take the form of a summer internship.
925.title: Practical Training Course in Mathematics (3–5)

993.description: This should not be taken by studentselecting non-thesis master’s projects.
993.title: Master’s Thesis (3–6)

251.description: Required preparation, one semester of a basic undergraduate science class. An introductory course in microbiology that focuses on the structure, biology, and genetics of microbes in relation to human disease and the immune system. For students planning careers in pharmacy, nursing, dental hygiene, and related fields. A laboratory is required.
251.title: Introductory Medical Microbiology (4)

255.description: Required preparation, one semester of a basic undergraduate science class. An introductory course in microbiology that focuses on the structure, biology, and genetics of microbes in relation to human disease and the immune system. For students planning careers in pharmacy, nursing, dental hygiene, and related fields. A laboratory is required.
255.title: Elementary Pathogenic Microbiology (4)

50.description: Selected aspects of microorganisms that cause infectious diseases, how new infectious diseases emerge, what bioterrorism is and how we are trying to counteract it in the United States, and how changes in the food supply have presented new infectious disease challenges.
50.title: First-Year Seminar: Infectious Disease in Society (3)

515.description: Open only to dental students. A course covering basic aspects of microbiology and immunology including sterilization, action of antimicrobial chemotherapeutic agents, concepts of infection and immunity, and the study of certain selected infectious agents.
515.title: Introduction to Microbiology (4)

614.description: A strong background in molecular biology, eukaryotic genetics, and biochemistry is required. Advanced survey course with topics that include molecular recognition, genetic mechanisms of host resistance, development of cells and cell interactions; hypersensitivity, autoimmunity, and resistance to infection. Course material from textbook and primary literature.
614.title: Immunobiology (3)

630.description: Required preparation, coursework in molecular biology and cell biology. Current concepts of the chemistry, structure, replication, genetics, and the natural history of animal viruses and their host cells.
630.title: Virology (3)

631.title: Advanced Molecular Biology I (BIOC 631, BIOL 631, GNET 631) (3)

632.title: Advanced Molecular Biology II (BIOC 632, BIOL 632, GNET 632) (3)

635.description: Permission of the instructor. Required preparation, coursework in molecular biology and genetics. Topics will include aspects of basic bacteriology as well as bacterial and fungal pathogens and mechanisms of disease.
635.title: Microbial Pathogenesis I (3)

640.description: Permission of the instructor or a fundamental understanding of molecular virology and immunology. Molecular pathogenesis, with a primary focus on viral pathogens. Additional topics include vaccines and genetics of host-pathogen interactions.
640.title: Microbial Pathogenesis II (3)

643.title: Cell Structure, Function, and Growth Control I (BIOC 643, CBIO 643, PHCO 643, PHYI 643) (3)

644.title: Cell Structure, Function, and Growth Control II (BIOC 644, CBIO 644, PHCO 644, PHYI 644) (3)

701.description: faculty and student seminars on current research in microbiology and immunology..
701.title: Seminar in Microbiology and Immunology (1)

702.description: seminar on selected topics in microbiology.
702.title: Seminar in Microbiology (1)

711.description: one or two faculty and a small number of students consider current research of importance in depth. emphasis is on current literature, invited speakers, etc., rather than textbooks.
711.title: Seminar/Tutorial in Animal Virology (1–21)

712.description: one or two faculty and a small number of students consider current research of importance in depth. emphasis is on current literature, invited speakers, etc., rather than textbooks.
712.title: Seminar/Tutorial in Immunology (1–21)

791.description: Permission of the instructoror one prior virology course. directed readings in virology under the direction of a member of the graduate faculty. May be repeated for credit.
791.title: Directed Readings in Virology (1)

792.description: Permission of the instructor or one prior immunology course. directed readings in immunology under the direction of a member of the graduate faculty. May be repeated for credit.
792.title: Directed Readings in Immunology (1)

795.description: Permission of the instructor. This course will provide multiple opportunities for the student to write partsof hypothesis-based proposals, receive substantial feedback, and to rewrite the text. There will be approximately twelve single-page writing assignments.
795.title: Research Concepts (2)

901.description: Permission of the department. designed to introduce the student to research methods and special techniques. short-term problems are conducted with the advice and guidance of the staff. May be repeated for credit.
901.title: Research in Microbiology or Immunology (1–21)

605.description: This survey course will briefly cover the principal topics in this broad field of knowledge, including domestic and global issues.
605.title: Survey Course on Breastfeeding and Public Health (3)

610.description: Permission of the instructor. for students outside the department of MCH who desire a survey of current issues and programs in maternal and child health. Three lecture hours per week.
610.title: Issues in Maternal and Child Health (3)

625.description: Preor corequisite, ePid 600. This course considers the causes and consequences of traumatic injury and dilemmas in injury research and prevention. This one-credit course consists of 10 class sessions of 75 minutes each over the first five weeks of the semester.
625.title: Injury as a Public Health Problem (1)

626.description: Corequisite, MHCH 625. This one-credit course considers the causes and consequences of intentional injury and dilemmas in injury research and prevention. The course meets once a week for 75 minutes starting the sixth week of the semester. students may enroll concurrently in MHCH 627.
626.title: Intentional Injury as a Public Health Problem (1)

665.title: Introduction to Racial and Ethnic Health Disparities (1)

680.description: featuring international experts from UnC-Chapel Hill and triangle-based nongovernmental organizations, this course will offer a series of lectures, panel discussions, and debates to inform students’ critical thinking on key public health issues in global sexual and reproductive health.
680.title: Global Sexual and Reproductive Health (1)

700.description: (PUbH 700). see PUbH 700 for description.
700.title: MHCH Planning and Evaluation (3)

701.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. This course introduces the major issues affecting the health and well-being of women during the reproductive years, infants, children, and adolescents in domestic and international settings. first semester of a two-semester course.
701.title: Foundations of Maternal and Child Health (4)

702.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. second part of a two-part course that introduces the major issues affecting the health and well-being of women duringthe reproductive years, infants, children and adolescents in domestic and international settings. second semester of a two-semester course.
702.title: Foundations of Maternal and Child Health (4)

704.description: This independent study will include selection of a research area that would allow preparation of a coauthored paper for peer-review publication on an approved subject related to infant and young child feeding and care and associated maternal health and nutrition issues.
704.title: Critical Review of an Infant Feeding Issue (3)

705.description: required preparation, graduate study in MHCH. Permission of the instructor. Analysis of the family planning movement, its policies, operations and research, with emphasis on developing countries. Three lecture hours a week.
705.title: International Family Planning (3)

712.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. offers an opportunity for students to explore in greater depth a selected MCH practice topic. students will learn how to provide consultation about a selected program activity.
712.title: Program Assessment in Maternal and Child Health (3)

713.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. The art and science of MCH research, with an emphasis on applied survey research. student groups will design and carry out a small survey, and present their findings in a poster presentation. focuses on assessment of MCH population characteristics, secondary data analysis, and the evaluation of MCH programs. A practicum-based course. Three lecture hours per week.
713.title: Research Methods in Maternal and Child Health (3)

713L.description: Corequisite, MHCH 713. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. The MHCH 713 lab, which is a companion course to MHCH 713, introduces students to statistical analysis using sPss-PC and microcomputers. two lab hours per week.
713L.title: Research and Evaluation Methods in Maternal and Child Health Lab (1)

715.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. students become familiar with organizational processes, management principles and tools required for effective management of health programs and facilities. A variety of learning techniques will be used. Three lecture hours a week.
715.title: Maternal and Child Health Management (3)

717.description: A facultysupervised field experience in maternal and child health research, community practice, program planning, and evaluation. studentsare supervised on-site by department-approved field instructor. An additional field fee of $350 is assessed. Minimum of six weeks.
717.title: Field Training in Maternal and Child Health (2–8)

720.description: Permission of the instructor. This course focuses on the design, organization, and delivery of services for children with special needs and their families, and examines current program development and public policies. Participants analyze the range of services needed by these children.
720.title: Services for Children with Chronic Conditions (3)

722.description: This course covers the main causes of maternal and under-five morbidity and mortality in developing countries and also the interventions, policies, and research which address these causes. emphasis is placed on both distal and proximate determinants, measurement and indicators, and conceptual frameworks.
722.title: Global Maternal and Child Health (3)

723.description: This course provides the students with the basic concepts and methodologies needed to monitor and evaluate programs in maternal and child health both domestically and internationally.
723.title: Introduction to Monitoring and Evaluation of MCH Programs (3)

725.title: Injury as a Public Health Problem (EPID 783, HBEH 725) (3)

735.description: required preparation, students must have a masters or clinical four-year degree, or be in such a degree program to be enrolled in this course. This clinical course is structured to provide supervised breastfeeding support education in the context of clinical lactation services and public health practice.
735.title: Clinical Support for Breastfeeding (3)

740.description: Prerequisites to be arranged with departmental faculty in each individual case. two to six hours a week.
740.title: Problems in Maternal and Child Health (1–3)

753.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. violence against women is examined as a public health problem. Areas investigated include definitional issues, prevalence of the problem, risk factors and outcomes, and community and medical interventions.
753.title: Violence Against Women (3)

756.description: (PUBH 756) (3). disparities in morbidity/mortality in subpopulations continue compared to other U.s. populations. explore contributors to inequalities and identify strategies to counterbalance contributors to correct inequalities using public health resources. Three lecture hours per week.
756.title: Understanding and Addressing Health Inequalities in the U

757.description: Course focuses on two populations that warrant special attention. by examining these populations in one course, students are exposed to a range of contemporary issues that cut across childhood development.
757.title: Special Child Populations (3)

765.description: Masters or clinical fouryear degree required. This two-semester clinical course is structured to provide supervised breastfeeding support education in the context of clinical lactation services and public health practice.
765.title: Clinical Support for Breastfeeding (3)

790.description: intensive retreat program that introduces students to leadership theory as applied to MCH-public health issues. Course will focus on understanding self and others, building organizational culture, and applying leadership theory to MCH issues, among other issues.
790.title: The Leadership Assessment Workshop (2)

801.description: Prerequisites, MHCH 701 and 702. This seminar explores the origins of and developments in major maternal and child health policies and programs in order to understand their effects on the health of mothers and children.
801.title: Doctoral Seminar in Maternal and Child Health (3)

802.description: The goal of this 1-credit hour seminar is for participants to examine and apply the strategies and concepts underlying effective teaching in small groups and the lecture hall. doctoral students will consider the characteristics of effective teaching and explore how to incorporate these characteristics into their own pedagogy.
802.title: Doctoral Teaching Skills Seminar (1)

803.description: enrollment in the MCH doctoral program or permission of the instructor for nonmajors and master’s students. This seminar is the second semester of a oneyear research skills colloquium for all new doctoral students. The course addresses research, problem definition, proposal design, and development. one-hour seminar a week.
803.title: Doctoral Research Skills Colloquium (1)
