840.description: enrollment in MCH doctoral program required. MCH internship to enhance doctoral training in areas of section 1: teaching; section 2: Practice; and section 3: research.
840.title: Maternal and Child Health Doctoral Internship (1)

853.title: Advanced Topics in Perinatal and Pediatric Epidemiology (EPID 853) (2)

859.description: Permission of the instructor. doctoral students only. PA survey of theoretical models used in MCH research and program development, and how those models are used to guide the formulation of questions, hypothesis testing, and evaluation.
859.title: Theoretical Perspectives on Maternal and Child Health (3)

860.description: Prerequisite, MHCH 859. Permission of the instructor for nonmajors and master’s students. The course follows the research process from the formulation of a research question and the design of a research methodology to the addressing of the question through the design of an appropriate analysis strategy. Three lecture hours a week.
860.title: Conceptualization, Design, and Measurement (3)

862.description: Knowledge of stata or similar statistical package required. Analytic skills seminaron the theory and practice of program impact evaluation. topics: what is impact evaluation; key issues to consider when evaluating program impact; selectivity and other problems when evaluating program impact; research designs and estimation strategies; interpretation of results.
862.title: Maternal and Child Health Program Evaluation (3)

885.description: An introduction to basic research methods central to maternal and child health policy, including an introduction to basic components of the research process such as developing research questions and conceptual models, and overviews of research designs, quantitative and qualitative analytical methods, primary data collection, and secondary data analysis.
885.title: Health Services/Health Policy Research Methods II (3)

886.description: Prerequisites, MHCH 884 and 885. A modular course covering applications of selected methods covered in 885. illustrative applications include implementation science, comparative effectiveness research, issues in mixed-method research, feasibility studies, and the translation of research to policy and practice. Applications are framed in terms of issues related to the MCH population.
886.title: Health Services/Health Policy Research Methods III (3)

890.description: special topics in Maternal and Child Health for graduate students only. Content will vary semester to semester.
890.title: Special Topics in Maternal and Child Health (1-3)

330.title: Economic History of the United States (ECON 330) (3)

410.description: See SOCI 410 for description.
410.title: Formal Organizations and Bureaucracy (SOCI 410) (3)

691H.description: Directed independent research under the supervision of a faculty advisor.
691H.title: Honors Fall Course (3)

692H.description: Prerequisite, MNGT 691H. Preparation of an honors thesis and an oral examination on the thesis.
692H.title: Honors Spring Course (3)

472.description: see PHys 472 for description.
472.title: Chemistry and Physics of Electronic Materials Processing (APPL 472, CHEM 472, PHYS 472) (3)

473.title: Chemistry and Physics of Surfaces (APPL 473, CHEM 473) (3)

715.description: see CoMP 715 for description.
715.title: Visualization in Science (COMP 715, PHYS 715) (3)

720.description: Permission of the department. introduction to materials fabrication techniques. includes single crystal growth, thin film deposition, synthesis of quantum dots and nanotubes/ nanowires, dielectric and electron emissive materials, nanocomposites, bioceramics, and energy storage materials.
720.title: Materials Fabrication (3)

730.description: Permission of the instructor. Theory of ensembles and interactions in statistical mechanics. Classical and quantum statistics. Applications to simple systems: ideal gas, heat capacity of solids, blackbody radiation, phase transitions.
730.title: Statistical Thermodynamics (3)

735.description: Permission of the department. lecture and laboratory in materials analysis techniques, including optical microscopy, scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction, fluorescence, nuclear magnetic resonance, raman spectroscopy, thermal analysis, XPs, channeling and rbs.
735.title: Techniques in Materials Science (3)

740.description: see bMMe 740 for description.
740.title: Advanced Biomaterials (BMME 740) (3)

750.title: Kinetics, Diffusion, and Phase Transitions of Materials (3)

810.description: Prerequisites, APPl 470 or PHys 573, MtsC 615, and 730. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites.
810.title: Device Physics and Electronic Properties of Solids (3)

820.description: Prerequisites, APPl 470 or PHys 573, and PHys 415. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. reflection, waveguides, nonlinear optics, optical switching, photorefraction, optical storage. optical coupling to electronic states, device applications, optical computing.
820.title: Optical Properties of Solids (3)

830.description: Prerequisite, APPl 470 or PHys 573. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. interatomic potentials, range distribution, radiation damage, annealing, secondary defects, analytical techniques, silicon-based devices, implantation in compound semiconductors, and buried layer synthesis. ion implantation in metals, ceramics, polymers, and biomaterials.
830.title: Ion–Solid Interactions (3)

840.description: Prerequisites, APPl 470 or PHys 573, MtsC 615, and 730. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. survey of novel and emerging device technologies. resonant tunneling transistors, HeMt, opto-electronic devices and optical communication and computation, low-temperature electronic, hybrid superconductor devices.
840.title: New Technologies and Device Architecture (3)

891.description: Permission of the department. Current topics in materials science, including electronic and optical materials, polymers, and biomaterials.
891.title: Special Topics in Material Science (1–3)

100.description: Individual lessons in piano, organ, or harpsichord. Sections by instructor.
100.title: Individual Keyboard Lessons (0

102.description: Sections by instructor.
102.title: Individual Voice Lessons (0

104.description: Individual lessons in flute, oboe, clarinet, saxophone, bassoon, or recorder. Sections by instructor.
104.title: Individual Woodwind Lessons (0

105.description: Individual lessons in horn, trumpet, trombone, tuba, or euphonium. Sections by instructor.
105.title: Individual Brass Lessons (0

107.description: Group or individual instruction in a specified instrument offered by the department. Sections by instructor.
107.title: Applied Instruction (0

110.description: Sections by instructor. 111 Group Lessons in Voice (1). Sections by instructor.
110.title: Group Lessons in Piano (1)

112.description: Group lessons in violin, viola, cello, string bass, or guitar. Sections by instructor.
112.title: Group Lessons in Strings (1)

113.description: Group lessons in flute, oboe, clarinet, saxophone, bassoon, or recorder. Sections by instructor.
113.title: Group Lessons in Woodwinds (1)

114.description: Group lessons in horn, trumpet, trombone, tuba, or euphonium. Sections by instructor.
114.title: Group Lessons in Brass (1)

120.description: An introduction to concepts and methods fundamental to the study, practice, and performance of music. The course provides a foundation for undergraduate students interested in the study of music. Students will gain an appreciation for music’s significance across repertories and develop the aptitude to think about music in different ways.
120.title: Foundations in Music (3)

121.description: Notational and theoretical materials of music, with musicianship skills developed. Intended for the nonmajor who wishes to learn to express musical ideas in clear, correct notational form.
121.title: Fundamentals of Music I (3)

122.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 121. A continuation of MUSC 121 with the addition of basic instrumentation and arranging.
122.title: Fundamentals of Music II (3)

123.description: Corequisite, MUSC 202. Basic principles of diction for singers in English/Italian presented through the use of the International Phonetic Alphabet.
123.title: Diction for Singers I (English/Italian) (1)

124.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 123. Basic principles of diction for singers in French.
124.title: Diction for Singers II (French) (1)

125.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 123. Basic principles of diction for singers in German.
125.title: Diction for Singers III (German) (1)

130.description: Corequisite, MUSC 131 or 131H. Basic musicianship skills, including music notation, basic composition, score analysis, keyboard, sight singing, and ear training.
130.title: Musicianship Skills I (1)

131.description: Enrollment subject to a placement test. An introduction to music theory and analysis for students who intend to pursue a music degree. Course covers basic principles of melody, counterpoint, rhythm, and meter.
131.title: Theory I (3)

132.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 131. Prerequisite requires a grade of C or better. A continuation of MUSC 131, covering more advanced topics of melody, harmony, counterpoint, rhythm, meter, and form.
132.title: Theory II (3)

133.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 130, and 131 or 131H; corequisite, MUSC 132. A continuation of MUSC 130, with emphasis on intermediate-level musicianship skills.
133.title: Musicianship Skills II (1)

135.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 131 or 131H. An introduction to the musical materials of jazz, including chord/scale relationships, functional keyboard skills, and harmonic analysis.
135.title: Jazz Theory (3)

136.description: Application of music theory to keyboard techniques in playing harmonic progressions, in harmonizing melodies, and in realizing figured bass.
136.title: Keyboard Skills I (1)

141.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. A chronological survey of the history of Western art music from roughly 1500 to the present.
141.title: Survey of Western Music History (3)

142.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. The study of selected works from the Western art tradition, with an emphasis on critical understanding.
142.title: Great Musical Works (3)

143.description: A survey of rock music styles, focusing primarily on the period 1955 to 1990. Music by Elvis Presley, The Beatles, Led Zeppelin, Police, Madonna, and others.
143.title: Introduction to Rock Music (3)

144.description: A survey and investigation of country music from 1920 to the present. Music of Jimmie Rodgers, Hank Williams, Willie Nelson, Patsy Cline, Garth Brooks, and others.
144.title: Introduction to Country Music (3)

145.description: A survey of jazz music from its origins to the present. The course builds skills in critical listening and blends discussion of musical materials and historical and cultural contexts.
145.title: Introduction to Jazz (3)

146.description: The study of music in and as culture. Topics may include the performance cultures of Native America, south Asia, Australia, Africa, east Asia, Southeast Asia, Europe, and the Americas.
146.title: Introduction to World Musics (3)

147.description: An introduction to contemporary Latin(o) American popular music, focusing on how musicians have negotiated an increasingly global popular culture industry.
147.title: Introduction to Latin(o) American Music (3)

148.description: An introduction to black musical cultures with a focus on understanding how music is made within social, geographical, and political contexts. The course includes experiential learning, live concert attendance, and conversations with practicing musicians in various musical traditions.
148.title: Introduction to Black Music (3)

155.description: An exploration of the important, often misunderstood role of the DJ in modern musical life, with particular attention to the ways in which DJing challenges traditional notions of music, musicianship, and musical instruments. Guest lectures, demonstrations, and tutorials by visiting DJs form a significant component of the course.
155.title: The Art and Culture of the DJ (3)

156.description: An introductory hands-on study of the composition of electronic instrumental tracks for hip-hop and dance music. Students make beats, learn about the history and culture of the art form, and examine beat making as a case study in entrepreneurship.
156.title: Beat Making Lab (3)

157.description: A hands-on study of the art of emceeing. Students engage in a rigorous lyricism curriculum, developing the skills to write, recite, and improvise lyrics in live and recorded settings. Students also explore the history of hip-hop culture and analyze the aesthetics of emcees from around the world.
157.title: Rap Lab (3)

158.description: An introduction to issues of performance practice in rock music and related styles and genres including, but not limited to, soul, funk, new wave, and punk. Through intensive coaching and rehearsal students learn performance, transcription, arranging, and improvisation.
158.title: Rock Lab (3)

163.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 135. An introductory course in the development of improvisational skills for thejazz idiom. The primary focus is the introduction of nomenclature, the development of basic jazz vocabulary, and the application of this knowledge using basic jazz tune types.
163.title: Jazz Improvisation I (3)

166.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 130, and 131 or 131H. The study of compositional techniques and the development of individual creative styles through imitative and original writing.
166.title: Introduction to Composition (3)

167.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 131 or 131H. Practical exercises in scoring and arranging for various combinations from single instrumental choirs to full concert orchestra, with trial group performances.
167.title: Instrumentation (3)

168.description: Basic conducting techniques, score reading, and music performance evaluation for choral and instrumental groups.
168.title: Basic Conducting (3)

170.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 132 or 132H. Focus is twofold: 1) fundamentals of piano teaching; 2) survey of piano literature.
170.title: Piano Pedagogy/Literature I (3)

171.description: Intended primarily for B.Mus. students who have taken MUSC 200 for at least four semesters. Problems, materials, and methods in teaching piano to older students of high school and early college age.
171.title: Piano Pedagogy II (3)

188.description: The role of women in performance, composition, patronage, and the music business across a wide range of repertories.
188.title: Introduction to Women and Music (WMST 188) (3)

200.description: Advanced individual lessons in piano, organ, or harpsichord. Sections by instructor.
200.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Keyboard (2)

203.description: Advanced individual lessons in violin, viola, cello, string bass, harp, or guitar. Sections by instructor.
203.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Strings (2)

204.description: Advanced individual lessons in flute, oboe, clarinet, saxophone, or bassoon. Sections by instructor.
204.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Woodwinds (2)

205.description: Advanced individual lessons in horn, trumpet, trombone, tuba or euphonium. Sections by instructor.
205.title: Advanced Individual Lessons in Brass (2)

207.description: Advanced instruction in a specified instrument offered by the department. Sections by instructor.
207.title: Advanced Applied Instruction (2)

211.description: Sections by ensemble: Symphony Orchestra, Band, Carolina Choir, Chamber Singers, Men’s Glee Club, Women’s Glee Club, Piano Ensemble I, Piano Ensemble II, Collaborative Piano, Guitar Ensemble, Jazz Band.
211.title: Ensemble I (1)

212.description: Sections include Opera Workshop, Percussion Ensemble, Gamelan, Charanga Carolina, Global Rhythms.
212.title: Ensemble II (1)

214.description: Sections by ensemble: University Chamber Players, String Chamber Ensembles, Woodwind Chamber Ensembles, Brass Chamber Ensembles, Jazz Combos, Viol Consort, New Music Ensemble, Charanga Carolina.
214.title: Chamber Music (1)

223.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 100 or 200. Survey of keyboard literature from the Baroque era to the present.
223.title: Piano Literature (1)

224.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 100 or 200. Problems, materials, and methods of teaching piano to students of all ages.
224.title: Piano Pedagogy (3)

225.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 102 or 202. Practical methodology for teaching voice to students of all experience levels. Topics covered include anatomy, historical pedagogy, national vocal teaching styles, and current trends in voice science.
225.title: Vocal Pedagogy (3)

226.description: Primarily for students pursing teacher licensure. An introduction to basic performance skills on representative woodwind, brass, percussion, and string instruments.
226.title: Woodwinds, Brass, Percussion, and Strings Techniques (3)

227.description: Primarily for students pursuing teacher licensure. An introduction to basic performance skills in voice and piano, and approaches to teaching elementary music.
227.title: Keyboard, Vocal, and Elementary Music Techniques (3)

228.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 226 and 227. A continuation of MUSC 226 and 227, allowing students the opportunity to develop further performance skills and pedagogical techniques in music education. Offered in sections: instrumental, vocal, strings.
228.title: Principles of Teaching Music (3)

230.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 or 132H, and 133; corequisite, MUSC 232. A continuation of MUSC 133, with emphasis on intermediateto advanced-level musicianship skills.
230.title: Musicianship Skills III (1)

232.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 132. Prerequisite requires a grade of C or better. A continuation of MUSC 132, covering topics including chromatic harmony and form.
232.title: Theory III (3)

233.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 252. The study of vocal and instrumental performances practices in specific periods and repertories.
233.title: Studies in Performance Practices (3)

234.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 120 and 131. Through the use of various ethnomusicological methodologies, students explore a range of non-Western musical systems in their cultural contexts. Topics of study may include aesthetic theories, cultural meaning, and conflict.
234.title: World Musics in Theory and Practice (3)

236.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 136. Continues the development of keyboard skills established in MUSC 136.
236.title: Keyboard Skills II (1)

239.description: A practical study of selected aspects of computerized music technology, including one or more of music-notation software, MIDI sequencing, digital sound production and storage, and computer composition.
239.title: Introduction to Music Technology (3)

245.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 146. This course is concerned with the performance and interpretation of Indonesian dance. It covers three areas of study: practical learning of traditional Indonesian dance repertoire, theoretical analyses and interpretation, and learning the music accompanying the dance.
245.title: Dance in Indonesia (3)

248.description: An examination and exploration of women’s changing roles and influence, onstage and behind the scenes, in the history of opera.
248.title: Women in Opera (WMST 248) (3)

251.description: The study of music in its historical and cultural contexts in the medieval and early modern eras.
251.title: Studies in Medieval and Early Modern Music (3)

252.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 or 132H, and 133. Music in its historical context from the mid-17th century through the mid-19th century.
252.title: Studies in Music History, 1650–1850 (3)

253.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 230, 232 or 232H, and 252. Music in its historical context since the mid-19th century.
253.title: Studies in Music History since 1850 (3)

254.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 131. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. A survey of music’s development from antiquity to 1750, in its stylistic, geographical, political, social, and cultural contexts.
254.title: Studies in Music History I, Antiquity to 1750 (3)

255.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 and 254. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. A continuation of MUSC 254, surveying music of the period since 1750 in its stylistic, geographical, political, social, and cultural contexts.
255.title: Studies in Music History II, 1750 to the Present (3)

258.description: The musical results of migrations of all types, voluntary or forced, by way of case studies drawn from historical and/or contemporary musics of Africa, the Americas, Asia, and Europe.
258.title: Musical Movements: Migration, Exile, and Diaspora (3)

263.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 163. Continuation of MUSC 163, examining more advanced improvisational techniques, harmonic materials, and compositional tune types.
263.title: Jazz Improvisation II (3)

265.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 135 and 163. Composing and arranging for smalland large-group jazz ensembles.
265.title: Jazz Composition and Arranging (3)

266.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 166. May be repeated for credit. Original compositions in various forms.
266.title: Composition (3)

267.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 167. Practical orchestral scoring with emphasis on understanding and imitating historical styles from Mozart through Ravel.
267.title: Orchestration (3)

269.description: Connecting academic inquiry in community music with an experiential project in the making, organization, or documentation of music locally.
269.title: Music in the Community (3)

280.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. Musical, historical, cultural, and social issues in jazz studied through the examination of innovative and influential jazz artists.
280.title: Jazz Innovators (3)

281.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. The relationship between popular song and culture in American society is explored by focusing on an important historical repertoire or interpretive theme.
281.title: Popular Song in American Culture (3)

282.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. The culmination of baroque music, emphasizing Bach’s cantatas, concertos, organ music, and instrumental music, and Handel’s oratorios and operas, all in their cultural contexts.
282.title: Bach and Handel (3)

283.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. The high point in Viennese music of the late 18th century, emphasizing Haydn’s symphonies and quartets, and Mozart’s operas and piano concertos.
283.title: Haydn and Mozart (3)

284.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. Beethoven’s music will be studied in the context of social structures and concepts about artists during his lifetime.
284.title: Beethoven and His Era (3)

285.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. A study of the work of diverse composers characteristic of music since ca. 1880 viewed in their broader artistic and other contexts.
285.title: Musical Modernism (3)

286.description: May be repeated for credit if on a different topic. May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. Music in the framework of its social, political, economic, and cultural contexts.
286.title: Music as Culture (3)

287.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. An introduction to music as related to drama, especially the development of opera and related genres. Study of selected works from different periods and styles.
287.title: Opera as Drama (3)

288.description: May not count for music or general elective credit for music majors. Study of the symphony orchestra, its instruments, and its historical development from the mid-18th century to the present, and the music it plays, including selected works in a variety of styles.
288.title: The Orchestra and Its Music (3)

291.description: The relationship between music and politics studied through a global range of historical and geographical contexts. The course covers specific musical and political manifestations as well as theoretical approaches to the issue.
291.title: Music and Politics (3)

296.description: Available only to music majors by permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Intensive study on a particular topic under faculty supervision.
296.title: Special Studies for Undergraduates (1–3)

300.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 200. Advanced individual keyboard lessons leading to a public recital.
300.title: Advanced Keyboard Lessons and Recital (3)

302.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 202. Advanced individual voice lessons leading to a public recital.
302.title: Advanced Voice Lessons and Recital (3)

303.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 203. Advanced individual string lessons leading to a public recital.
303.title: Advanced String Lessons and Recital (3)

304.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 204. Advanced individual woodwind lessons leading to a public recital.
304.title: Advanced Woodwind Lessons and Recital (3)

305.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 205. Advanced individual brass lessons leading to a public recital.
305.title: Advanced Brass Lessons and Recital (3)

306.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 206. Advanced individual percussion lessons leading to a public recital.
306.title: Advanced Percussion Lessons and Recital (3)

307.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 266. This course is conceived as a culminating project that showcases a student’s original musical compositions.
307.title: Advanced Composition/Recital (3)

308.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 168. Intermediate conducting for instrumental or vocal ensembles.
308.title: Intermediate Lessons in Conducting (3)

309.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 308. May be repeated for up to six hours of credit. Advanced conducting for instrumental or choral ensembles.
309.title: Advanced Lessons in Conducting (3)

331.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 and 232. The study of analytical techniques as applied to significant works of the period.
331.title: Musical Form and Analysis (3)

332.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 and 232. The study of two-, three-, and four-voice counterpoint, for example in the style of Palestrina, Bach, or 20th-century idioms.
332.title: Counterpoint (3)

333.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 and 232. Analysis and transcription of blues, rock, ballads, and jazz, with an emphasis on rock music since 1955.
333.title: Analysis of Popular Music (3)

338.description: Prerequisites, MUSC 132 and 232. The study of analytical techniques as applied to significant works of the period.
338.title: Analysis of Music since 1900 (3)

355.description: Prerequisite, MUSC 254. Course will address a particular genre, composer, compositional issue, or repertoire, including non-Western and popular musics. Subject matter will vary with the instructor. May be repeated for credit if on a different topic.
355.title: History and Culture of Music (3)

363.description: May be repeated for credit if on a different topic. Advanced study on a selected topic in jazz. Topics will vary and may address a particular genre, composer, performance practice, compositional issue, or repertoire.
363.title: Studies in Jazz (3)

364.description: Lectures on theory and improvisation, small ensemble coaching, and instrument specific master classes in a classroom/lecture format. Intensive listening component through required attendance at four evening concerts. Final public student concert for a community audience. Can be repeated for credit.
364.title: The Summer Jazz Program (3)

390H.description: Detailed investigation of a specific musical topic from historical and/or theoretical perspectives.
390H.title: Honors Seminar in Music (3)

471.description: Advanced study of selected performance issues. Maybe repeated for credit.
471.title: Instrumental Performance Repertory (3)

493.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Internship directly related to the study, practice, or the business of music. Students must complete at least 100 hours and submit a journal and report upon completion of the internship.
493.title: Music Internship (3)

52.description: Oklahoma!, Carousel, and South Pacific in their political, social, and cultural contexts.
52.title: First-Year Seminar: Building a Nation: The Stage Musicals of Rodgers and Hammerstein, 1942–1949 (3)

53.description: A sociomusical study of rock ’n’ roll in its first decades.
53.title: First-Year Seminar: Rock ’n’ Roll: The First Wave, 1955–1964 (3)

54.description: The perceived and actual relationships between music and magic in a range of historical periods.
54.title: First-Year Seminar: Music and Magic (3)

56.description: Music and spectacle in the late medieval, Renaissance, and baroque courts of Europe.
56.title: First-Year Seminar: Early-Modern Court Spectacle (3)

57.description: Textual and musical analysis of Verdi’s operas (libretto and score) in their sociohistorical contexts.
57.title: First-Year Seminar: Music and Drama: Verdi’s Operas and Italian Romanticism (3)

58.description: A sociological analysis of the repertorial and performative aspects of dance hall/disco.
58.title: First-Year Seminar: Music in Motion: American Popular Music and Dance (3)

59.description: The relationship between music and the visual arts in the modernist and postmodernist periods viewed in their historical contexts.
59.title: First-Year Seminar: 20th-Century Music and Visual Art (3)

60H.description: Music in, and musical settings of, American literature of the Romantic, modern, and postmodern periods.
60H.title: First-Year Seminar: American Literature and Its Music (3)

61H.description: Musical crossovers in world musics and societies.
61H.title: First-Year Seminar: Reverberations (3)

62H.description: Vienna in the early 1900s as a locus for modernism.
62H.title: First-Year Seminar: Vienna: City of Dreams (3)

63.description: Offers tools and techniques for understanding multimedia, staged musical works like opera, musical theater, and film. The goal of the seminar is to develop students’ analytical skills in verbal and nonverbal media and to encourage their visualization of the potential and implications of artistic forms and structures.
63.title: First-Year Seminar: Music on Stage and Screen (3)

64.description: Musical aesthetics, musical works, and the nature of musical art.
64.title: First-Year Seminar: What Is a Work of Art? Listening to Music (3)

691H.description: Admission by permission of the honors advisor. Independent study by a student who has been designated a candidate for undergraduate honors in music.
691H.title: Senior Honors Thesis in Music I (3)

750.description: introduction to the field of musicology, including its scope, methodology, and bibliography. taught in three-week modules, each directed by a different member of the academic faculty. individual modules will include music history, music theory, ethnomusicology, music aesthetics, and cultural studies.
750.title: Resources and Methods of Musicology I (3)

751.description: when offered, continuation of MUsC 750.
751.title: Resources and Methods of Musicology II (3)

89.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
89.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

991.description: Co-requisite, MUsC 994. forum for group discussion of on-going dissertation work and professional development.
991.title: Dissertation Colloquium (1

101.description: Fundamental orientation to the naval service emphasizing the mission, organization, regulations, customs and traditions, broad warfare components, and major challenges facing Navy/Marine Corps officers.
101.title: Introduction to Naval Science (1)

190.description: Permission of the department. Seminar of topics regarding the United States Navy.
190.title: Seminar in Topics of Naval Science (1–12)

201.description: A study of organizational principles, management theory, and leadership styles, with emphasis on applications in the Navy and Department of Defense.
201.title: Naval Leadership and Management (3)

202.description: Corequisite, NAVS 202L. A comprehensive study of the theory, principles, and procedures of ship navigation, movements, and employment. Course includes spherical trigonometry, mathematics, analysis, study and practices of navigation, sextants, navigation publications, and report logs. Covers rules of the road, lights, signals, navigational aids, and electronic and mechanical positioning devices.
202.title: Navigation (3)

202L.description: Corequisite, NAVS 202. Practical application of the theories and principles of navigation as presented in the lecture series.
202L.title: Navigation Laboratory (1)

211.description: One laboratory hour per week designed to introduce topics and activities relevant to the professional development of the prospective Marine Corps officer. Required for Marine Option 2/C.
211.title: Marine Option Naval Science Laboratory (0)

301.description: An introductory course and survey of ship design, characteristics, propulsion (including nuclear power) and control systems, and the principles of ship stability.
301.title: Naval Ships Engineering Systems (3)

302.description: A descriptive survey course in engineering aspects of ships weapons guidance, control, and propulsion systems and characteristics of ships weapons systems.
302.title: Naval Weapons Systems (3)

311.description: Survey of the evolution of warfare through the study of selected campaigns and classic battles, with special emphasis on the principles of war, the military impact of leadership, and the evolution of tactics and weaponry.
311.title: Evolution of Warfare (3)

401.description: A study of the maneuvering of ships in formation, and the operations in which naval vessels engage daily.
401.title: Naval Operations (4)

402.description: Capstone leadership course in NROTC curriculum, emphasizing leadership skills and the ethical implications of decision making for the competent commissioned officer.
402.title: Naval Leadership and Ethics (3)

411.description: A survey of the projection of sea power ashore, with special emphasis on the evolution of amphibious warfare in the 20th century, through the study of historical amphibious landings and campaigns.
411.title: Amphibious Warfare (3)

401.description: see PsyC 401 for description. 402 Advanced Biopsychology (PSYC 402) (3). see PsyC 402 fordescription.
401.title: Animal Behavior (PSYC 401) (3)

411.description: Permission of the department. A laboratory-tutorial course to acquaint the student with methods used in several areas of neurobiology.
411.title: Neurobiology Laboratory Apprenticeship (1–21)

412.description: Permission of the department. A laboratory-tutorial course to acquaint the student with methods used in several areas of neurobiology.
412.title: Neurobiology Laboratory Apprenticeship (1–21)

703.description: see PsyC 703 for description.
703.title: Advanced Biological Psychology: Central Nervous System (PSYC 703) (3)

704.description: see PsyC 704 for description.
704.title: Applications of Experimental Psychology to Health Research (PSYC 704) (3)

705.description: see PsyC 705 for description.
705.title: Behavioral Pharmacology (PSYC 705, PHCO 705) (3)

708.title: Seminar in the Biological Foundations of Psychology (PSYC 708) (3)

710.description: see PHyi 710 for description.
710.title: Medical Neurobiology (PHYI 710) (3)

725.description: Permission of the instructor. six or more laboratory hours a week.
725.title: Experimental Neurophysiology (3)

727.description: introduces new neuroimaging techniques and their application to the study of neural correlates of cognitive and behavioral impairments in brain disorders. reviews the theories and research methodologies that investigate how brain functions support and give rise to mental operations such as attention, memory, emotions, social cognition in the healthy brain.
727.title: Translational Seminar in Cognitive and Clinical Neuroscience (2)

728.description: Prerequisites, nbio 201, or 222 and 223. explores the basic neurobiology and the clinical aspects of a range of diseases of the nervous system, including Als, Alzheimer’s, autism, schizophrenia, multiple sclerosis, deafness, epilepsy, pain, brain tumors, stroke, Parkinson’s and other neurodegenerative diseases.
728.title: Diseases of the Nervous System (2)

729.description: Prerequisites, nbio 722 and 733. Additional required preparation, one year of calculus, familiarity with MAtlAb or Python, or permission of the instructor. A discussion/reading seminar covering the fundamentals of nervous system information processing and integration, with examples from sensory systems.
729.title: Sensory Neural Information Processing and Representation (3)

735.description: required preparation, two semesters of biochemistry.
735.title: Seminar in Chemical Neurobiology (2)

800.description: This seminar examines the topics of genetics, neuroanatomy, physiology, and behavioral development to provide a broad-based and integrated background to understand the etiology and potential mechanism underlying neurodevelopmental disorders.
800.title: Gene-Brain-Behavior Interactions in Neurodevelopmental Disorders: Perspectives on Disease Mechanisms (1-5)

801.description: This seminar will review the epidemiology, pathogenesis, diagnosis and treatment of neurodevelopmental syndromes and disorders. topics will range from single gene (e.g. fragile X syndrome and tuberous sclerosis) to complex genetic (e.g., autism, schizophrenia), to environmental disorders with varied phenotypes, pathogenetic mechanisms, and treatments.
801.title: Clinical Syndromes and Neurodevelopmental Disorders (1-5)

850.description: Permission of the department. An intensive consideration of selected topics and problems in neurobiology. The course focuses on the development of presentation and evaluation skills of the trainees. six credit hours required for neurobiology graduates.
850.title: Seminar in Neurobiology (BIOL 850, PHYI 850, PHCO 850) (3)

890.description: special topics in neurobiology. Content will vary from semester to semester.
890.title: Special Topics in Neurobiology (1-5)

892.description: Permission of the instructor. individually arranged in-depth programs of selected topics such as membrane function, transport physiology, renal physiology, etc.
892.title: Special Topics in Physiology (PHYI 712B) (1–5)

951.description: Permission of the department. research in various aspects of neurobiology. six to 24 hours a week.
951.title: Research in Neurobiology (BIOL 951, PHCO 951, PHYI 951) (3–12)

993.description: Course is designed to certify that the students have achieved a high level of knowledge competence in clinical and basic neurosciences, without the rigorous research experience required of a Ph.d.
993.title: Master’s Thesis (3–9)

253.description: Majors only. This course emphasizes a lifespan approach to theories and perspectives on individual growth and development. Content focuses on physical, cognitive, and socioemotional development, and risk factors from birth to death.
253.title: Individual Development across the Lifespan (2)

254.description: Majors only. This course introduces the discipline, profession, and practice of nursing through a study of history, values, culture, legal issues, and education. Critical thinking central to nursing practice is introduced.
254.title: Discipline of Nursing I (1)

261.description: Majors only. This course involves the nursing application of nutritional concepts to the care of individuals, families, groups, and populations across the lifespan.
261.title: Nursing Role in Normal Nutrition (2)

360.description: Majors only. The course focuses on understanding basic nursing concepts. The development of communication, teaching, and psychomotor skills are emphasized in conjunction with nursing process. Research as a basis for practice is recognized.
360.title: Concepts, Processes, and Skills for Evidence-Based Nursing (4)

361.description: Majors only. This course is concerned with alterations involved in disruptions of normal physiology as well as pathophysiological principles underlying therapeutic interventions and outcomes.
361.title: Pathophysiology (3)

362.description: Majors only. Using the science of pharmacology and pharmacologic principles underlying therapeutic interventions, this course focuses on an introduction to nursing responsibilities regarding pharmacologic therapy across the lifespan.
362.title: Pharmacology across the Lifespan (3)

364.description: Prerequisites, NURS 253, 261, 361, and 366. Corequisites, NURS 360 and 362. Majors only. This is the first of two adult health courses in which students apply critical thinking skills to nursing care of adults with major health problems.
364.title: Nursing Care of Adults with Major Health Problems, I (6)

366.description: Majors only. This course addresses concepts and methods of comprehensive health assessment of children, adults, and elders. Emphasis will be on data collection as a basis for initiation of caring and decision making in nursing practice.
366.title: Health Assessment (3)

369.description: Admission to the R.N.–B.S.N. option or permission of the instructor. This course expands the student’s previous knowledge base of the skills and principles of historical, psychological, and physical assessment and identifies these data as the basis for nursing care.
369.title: Physical Assessment (3)

371.description: Preor corequisite, NURS 364. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Students are introduced to key concepts of evidence-based nursing practice, including the research process, protection of human subjects, and retrieval and appraisal of evidence to maintain a scientifically sound practice.
371.title: Nursing Inquiry and Evidence-Based Practice (3)

377.description: Majors only. This course introduces components of the research process with application to the theory and practice of nursing. The course provides the foundation for master’s-level nursing research course.
377.title: Research in Nursing Practice (3)

379.description: Majors only. Students will examine health care organizations from a systems perspective and develop leadership skills necessary in professional practice.
379.title: Leadership in Nursing Practice (3)

382.description: Majors only. This course explores essential competencies in genetics and genomics for registered nurses. The learner gains knowledge about family assessment and the impact of genomic issues on individuals and families.
382.title: Family-Centered Genomic Health Care (1)

456.description: Prerequisites, NURS 254 and at least one of the following: NURS 470, 472, 477, or 479. Majors only. This course emphasizes professional development through exploration of a variety of roles and practice environments. Students analyze personal and professional goals and values to develop a framework for nursing practice.
456.title: Discipline of Nursing II (2)

470.description: Prerequisites, NURS 364 and 371. Corequisites, NURS 472, 477, or 479. Majors only. Students apply public health concepts to community practice to improve health and reduce disparities across the lifespan, emphasizing interventions using partnership strategies at individual/family, organizational, and policy levels.
470.title: Public Health Nursing (5)

472.description: Prerequisite, NURS 364. Majors only. Nursing care of infants, children, and their families is explored. Knowledge from a variety of disciplines is applied through the nursing process to the direct care of infants and children.
472.title: Nursing Care of Infants, Children, and Their Families (5)

477.description: Prerequisites, NURS 253, 361, and 362. Corequisites, NURS 364 and 382. Majors only. Using theories of psychosocial development, psychopathology, therapeutic communication, and psychotherapy, this course requires students to examine the range and complexities of human emotional suffering and methods of effective intervention.
477.title: Psychiatric Mental Health Concepts for Broad Clinical Application in Nursing (5)

479.description: Prerequisite, NURS 364. Majors only. The course focuses on application of caring and critical thinking skills in providing evidence-based nursing care to childbearing families.
479.title: Maternal/Newborn Nursing (5)

487.description: Prerequisites, NURS 254 and 364. Certification as Nurse Aide I and II also required as preor corequisite. Majors only. This course provides the student an opportunity to participate in a work-study experience in participating health care agencies. Students participate in a reflective experience that integrates classroom and experiential learning.
487.title: Practicum in Nursing: Work-Study Experience (3)

488.description: Prerequisites, NURS 254 and 364. Majors only. Certification as a Nurse Aide I and Nurse Aide II are recommended. Practice in health care settings is the course focus. Students participate in a reflective experience that provides the context to integrate classroom and experiential learning into an evolving professional identity.
488.title: Practicum in Nursing: Health Services Improvement Work Experience (3)

489.description: Prerequisites, NURS 254, 364, and two of the following: 470, 472, 477, 479, 591. Majors only. Certifications as a Nurse Aide I and Nurse Aide II are recommended. Practice in global health care settings is the course focus. Students participate in a reflective experience that provides the context to integrate classroom and experiential learning into an evolving professional identity.
489.title: Practicum in Nursing: Global Health Experience (3)

491.description: Majors only. This course emphasizes analysis of clinical problems that affect the nursing care of selected populations. Students also apply the nursing process, therapeutic communication skills, and teaching-learning principles in clinical situations.
491.title: Improving Nursing Practice: Application of Concepts, Theories, and Research (3)

492.description: Majors only. Selected concepts, theories, and models are explored as a basis for making judgments and decisions in nursing practice. Emphasis is on helping students expand and refine the body of knowledge upon which they base practice decisions. Critical thinking skills are developed as an essential component of professional practice.
492.title: Conceptual Bases of Professional Nursing Practice (3)

494.description: Majors only. Prepares R.N. students for population-focused practice in community health nursing. Analyses and applications of selected theories; health promotion/protection and disease prevention strategies are emphasized.
494.title: Community Health Nursing for the Public’s Health (3–6)

496.description: Majors only. The focus of this course is the development of knowledge and experience related to research or service learning and its application to the practice of nursing and health care.
496.title: Advanced Practicum in Nursing (1–3)

586.description: Majors only. The context of professional nursing practice will be analyzed from a social, economic, and policy perspective. Analysis will include projections for the future of the profession.
586.title: Contemporary Issues in Nursing Practice (3)

588.description: Prerequisites, NURS 364, 371, and 487 or 489, and 472 or 477 or 479. Corequisite NURS 488. Majors only. This course explores organizational leadership and management practices and theories. Current social, economic, legal, ethical, and policy issues affecting practice, education, and the profession of nursing are examined.
588.title: Leadership in Health Care Organizations (4)

591.description: Prerequisites, NURS 364 and 371. Corequisite NURS 456. Majors only. This senior-level course focuses on applying critical thinking, clinical decision making, and evidence-based nursing practice to complex health problems of adults. Unique health needs of older adults are addressed.
591.title: Nursing Care of Adults with Major Health Problems, II (8)

600.description: This course provides service-learning opportunities to apply nursing practice within the context of interprofessional care for vulnerable populations by participating with Student Health Action Coalition (SHAC) activities.
600.title: SHAC: Student Health Action Coalition (0)

607I.description: Majors only. This interprofessional course focuses on understanding roles, teamwork, and communication to improve patient safety within the health care environment. National standards and initiatives will be the foundation of the course. Pass/ Fail only.
607I.title: Interprofessional Team Work and Communication: Key to Patient Safety (3)

609.description: Majors only or permission of the instructor. A faculty led experiential learning opportunity focusing on development and knowledge related to research, health care systems, or service learning and its application to nursing and health care.
609.title: Health Care in the Global Context (1)

613I.title: Intermediate Spanish for Health Care I (AHSC 613I, PHCY 613I, PUBH 613I, SOWO 613I) (3)

614I.title: Intermediate Spanish for Health Care II (AHSC 614I, PHCY 614I, PUBH 614I, SOWO 614I) (3)

615I.title: Advanced Spanish for Health Care I (AHSC 615I, DENT 615I, MEDI 615I, PHCY 615I, PUBH 615I, SOWO 615I) (3)

646.description: This course examines health care policy development, impacts, and prospects for change. Content enables nurses to draw implications for nursing practice and advocacy for improving systems.
646.title: Health Care Policy in the United States: Development, Impacts, and Implications for Nurses (3)

671.description: Students anticipating graduate study are introduced to scientific inquiry and principles of evidence-based practice, including theoretical perspectives related to inquiry; ethics; identification of research problems, development of research questions, and appropriate design; data interpretation with emphasis on statistical analysis; and rigorous appraisal of research reports.
671.title: Nursing Inquiry and Evidence-Based Practice for Advanced Scholarship (3)

680.description: Pilot test for new courses in the nursing program.
680.title: Experimental Courses (1–3)

685.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Students from a variety of health sciences-related disciplines gain an understanding of issues in working with dying and bereaved individuals of all ages and their families.
685.title: Care of the Dying and Bereaved throughout the Life Span (3)

686.description: Graduate students only. Focuses on advanced concepts for nursing management of older adults and their families with an emphasis on interdisciplinary care.
686.title: Advanced Concepts in the Clinical Care of Older Adults (2)

687.description: Examination and discussion of major ethical issues arising in the professional practice of nursing in the context of systematic consideration of the nature of ethical choice.
687.title: Ethical Issues in Nursing (2)

689.description: Admission to Adult-Gerontology Nurse Practitioner program or permission of the instructor required. This course focuses on an evidence-based approach for the advanced practice nurse, incorporating pathophysiology; prevention/detection; medical treatment; nursing management; and socioeconomic, ethical, and legal issues related to adult cancer care.
689.title: Advanced Concepts in Oncology Nursing (2)

691H.description: Permission of the program director. Majors only. Preparation of a two-semester honors project under the direction of department advisors.
691H.title: Honors in Nursing, Part I (3)

692H.description: Permission of the program director. Majors only. Preparation of a two-semester honors project under the direction of department advisors.
692H.title: Honors in Nursing, Part II (3)

704.description: focuses on the principles and practice of scientific writing, with emphasis on research proposals, theses, research reports, dissertations and articles for publication.
704.title: Scientific Writing (1)

710.description: This course explores developmental changes in morphological processes and normal and pathologic physiology in humans from conception through adolescence. Physiological differences between infants and children and adults are emphasized.
710.title: Developmental Physiology and Pathophysiology (3)

715.description: This course examines the physiological and pathophysiological responses to injuryeffects on cell function, host defense responses, maintenance of vital functions, and neuro-endocrine-immune responses to stress across the lifespan.
715.title: Pathophysiology for Advanced Nursing Practice (3)

721.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715 and 720. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. The course will examine the principles of pharmacotherapeutic decision making in advanced nursing practice, with application to the clinical management of common health problems specific to pediatrics.
721.title: Pediatric Pharmacology (1)

722.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 726, and 727. Co-requisite, nUrs 720. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the preand corequisites. examines the principles of psychopharmacology and neurobiology for safe and effective psychotherapeutic management of individuals with psychiatric and mental health problems across the lifespan.
722.title: Psychopharmacology in Psychiatric-Mental Health Advanced Practice Nursing (2)

725.description: Preor corequisite, nUrs 710. Course is designed to prepare the advanced practice nurse to comprehensively assess pediatric clients using a diagnostic reasoning process.
725.title: Advanced Health Assessment and Diagnostic Reasoning in Pediatric Nursing (4)

726.description: Preor corequisite, nUrs 715. This course examines the process of diagnostic reasoning as a framework to synthesize comprehensive assessment of patients throughout the lifespan.
726.title: Advanced Health Assessment and Diagnostic Reasoning in Primary Care (4)

727.description: Preor corequisites, nUrs 715 and 726. This course introduces students to the role of the advanced practice psychiatricmental health nurse. Models for assessment, intervention, and evaluation are explored and tested clinically.
727.title: Advanced Diagnostic Process in Psychiatric-Mental Health Nursing (4)

776.description: Graduate standing and successful completion of an undergraduate statistics course required. This course explores approaches to research problems in advanced practice nursing. Theories, methods, designs, measurement, ethical conduct, and skills in critical appraisal are emphasized.
776.title: Research for Advanced Clinical Practice (3)

777.description: Graduate standing required. This course provides an introduction to probability, statistical concepts, and analytical techniques useful in health care research and for interpreting the literature.
777.title: Intermediate Statistical Applications in Health Care (3)

778.description: for nursing students admitted to The Graduate school. focuses on approaches for critical reading of research reports to evaluate the evidence base for practice.
778.title: Interpreting Research Reports (3)

779.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 778. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. focuses on the translation of research evidence to support improved models of care delivery.
779.title: Synthesis and Translation of Evidence (3)

780I.description: This course examines the current issues involved in managing diabetes mellitus in persons over their life span. Contributions of the multidisciplinary team are an important theme throughout this course.
780I.title: Multidisciplinary Perspectives on Managing Diabetes Mellitus (PHCY 608I) (2)

781I.description: This multidisciplinary course offers students the opportunity to gain a basic understanding of human genetics and explore the ethical, legal, and social implications of recent advances in genetics.
781I.title: Genomics and Society (3)

782I.title: Aging and Health (DENT 604I, EPID 620I, HMSC 904I, MEDI 604I, PHCY 604I, PHYT 904I, PSYC 904I, SOCI 824, SOWO 604I) (3)

783I.title: Aging and Public Policy (DENT 607I, FMME 607I, HMSC 951I, HPM 961, MEDI 607I, PSYC 907I, SOWO 607I) (3)

811.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 726, and 810. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Provides the opportunity for an in-depth examination of management strategies with selected health problems in adults. Also examines issues inherent in the management of women and elderly populations.
811.title: Selected Issues in Adult Health (5)

812.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 726, 810, and 811. This capstone course focuses on the management of complex health problems in adult populations for the adult nurse practitioner.
812.title: Management of Complex Health Problems in Adults (6)

815.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 810, 840, or 860. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. examines current advanced practice nursing roles issues, within the context of contemporary healthcare delivery, legal, and sociopolitical systems.
815.title: Advanced Practice Nursing Role (1)

819.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 726, and 810. A precepted practicum in community-based ambulatory care settings that provides experiences in continuity of care in the delivery of personal health services to adult individuals and their families.
819.title: Practicum in Primary Care Management of Adults (2)

820.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 688 and 699. Corequisite, nUrs 821. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the corequisite. focuses on the evidence-based management of common acute, episodic, and chronic health problems in adult cancer patients for the oncology nurse practitioner.
820.title: Clinical Practicum in Advanced Oncology Nursing (2-4)

821.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 688 and 689. Co-requisite, nUrs 820. Permission of instructor for students lacking the corequisite. focuses on evidence-based nursing and medical management issues relevant to the care of patients and their families across the cancer continuum and practice settings.
821.title: Seminar in Advanced Oncology Nursing (0

825.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 726, and 810. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Uses a life span approach to examine principles of primary care management of childbearing couples and sexual reproductive health in women and men. Application is in community-based settings.
825.title: Sexual and Reproductive Health (4)

826.description: This course introduces fundamental concepts and models of population-oriented nursing practice and the central issues affecting that practice. focuses on health disparities and underserved populations.
826.title: Introduction to Population Health and Community-Based Practice (2)

827.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 726, and 810. examines the principles of assessment, management, evaluation, and continuing care of children in primary care settings. developmentally-appropriate, family-centered approaches and management of common medical problems are addressed.
827.title: Child Health Issues in Primary Care (4)

828.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 726, 810, 825, and 827. This course is the capstone practicum for family nurse practitioner students. it emphasizes the comprehensive clinical management of primary health care needs in the context of the individual, the family, and/or the community.
828.title: Advanced Clinical Practicum in Primary Care of Families (4)

833.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 726, 810, and 825. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. focuses on the primary care of women with complex gynecological problems, reproductive complications, and socially derived health care problems. emphasis is placed on assessment, diagnosis, management, and clinical decision making.
833.title: Specialty Care in the Health of Women (4)

835.description: Admission to nursing graduate program. focuses on epidemiologic approaches for studying the impact of social, economic, and cultural inequalities on health and illness patterns at population and clinical levels.
835.title: Population Health and Epidemiology (3)

838.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715,726, 810, 825, and 833. The women’s health care advanced practicum focuses on the synthesis and clinical management of primary health care and specialty health care problems of women.
838.title: Health Care of Women Practicum (1–5)

840.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 710 and nUrs 725. Preor corequisite, nUrs 720. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. This course focuses on advanced practice nursing management of common clinical symptomatology and problems in pediatric primary care.
840.title: Primary Care of Children (5)

841.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 710, 725, and 840. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. focuses on advanced concepts in family-centered health care of selected child and adolescent health problems. students function in an advanced practice role working with children, adolescents, and their families in primary care, acute, and/or chronic illness settings.
841.title: Advanced Concepts in Family-Centered Health Care of Children and Adolescents (4)

842.description: Preor corequisites, nUrs 710, 720, and 840. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the preor corequisites. This course prepares the advanced practice nurse to design, implement, and evaluate a coordinated system of interventions that aim to promote optimal health and maximize outcomes for infants, children, and adolescents with complex conditions.
842.title: Management of Complex Conditions in Advanced Practice Pediatric Nursing (4)

849.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 710 and 725. Corequisites, nUrs 720 and 840. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the preor corequisites. supervised practicum in an advanced practice role in a selected health care setting that provides primary care and/or specialized health care to infants, children, or adolescents.
849.title: Clinical Practicum in Advanced Practice Pediatric Nursing (1–5)

860.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 727. focuses on theories, techniques, and research related to providing individual psychotherapy. Contextual factors affecting the delivery of psychiatric-mental health nursing services are analyzed.
860.title: Psychiatric Nursing Interventions with Individuals (5)

864.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 727 and 860. Permission of the instructorfor students lacking the prerequisites. students will analyze theories, techniques, and research relevant to therapy with groups and families experiencing mental health problems.
864.title: Psychiatric-Mental Nursing Interventions: Families and Groups (4)

865.description: Prerequisites, 715, 720, 722, 726, 727, and 860. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. students will analyze theories, techniques, and research relevant to therapeutic interventions with children experiencing mental health problems.
865.title: Psychiactric-Mental Health Nursing Interventions with Children (2)

868.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 715, 720, 722, 726, 727, 860, 864, and 865. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. This courses focuses on the management of complex psychiatric-mental health problems across the lifespan for the psychiatric-mental health nurse practitioner.
868.title: Management of Complex Psychiatric-Mental Health Problems Across the Lifespan (6)

869.description: Prerequisites, nUrs 727, 860, 863 and 864. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. This is the final advanced clinical course for students to apply knowledge and skills in selected domains of the advanced practice of psychiatric-mental health nursing. supervision, peer evaluation, seminar, and independent readings will enhance the experience.
869.title: Practicum in Psychiatric Mental Health Care for Advanced Practice Nurses (1–3)

870.description: focuses on developing an understanding of the concepts relevant to health care informatics and the use of computerized information systems, as well as the use of computer applications to support clinical and administrative decision making.
870.title: Health Care Informatics (3)

871.description: This course examines health care and nursing practice organizations, and the influence of the external and internal environment on these organizations. roles and functions of nurses at different levels and in different types of health care settings are explored.
871.title: Leadership and Advanced Practice Roles in Health Care Organizations (3)

872.description: explores the knowledge and skills required for effective human resource management. Managerial behaviors that promote and maintain a professional nursing practice environment are emphasized.
872.title: Human Resource Management (3)

873.description: Admission to graduate program. This course examines theoretical underpinnings and financial management concepts that pertain to costs, cost analysis, budgeting, variance analysis, staffing, productivity, and forecasting to prepare nurse leaders for decision-making in complex health care organizations.
873.title: Financing for Valued-Based Care (3)

874.description: Majors only. explores theories and methods for improving the quality, safety, and outcomes of care and patient and organizational levels, with emphasis on the quality and patient safety movement, improvement science, and evidence based practice.
874.title: Improving Quality, Safety, and Outcomes in Healthcare Systems (3)

875.description: Provides students who have had minimal or no teaching experience with the educational principles necessary to teach in nursing programs or health care settings.
875.title: Principles of Teaching Applied to Nursing (3)

876.description: This online course examines foundations of contemporary nursing and health care education, including academic, staff development, patient education programs, and lifelong learning.
876.title: Innovations in Nursing and Health Care Curricula (3)

878.description: required preparation, all required courses for the HCs specialty or concurrent enrollment in final HCs coursework. Course provides students an opportunity to develop, implement, and evaluate advanced practice and leadership strategies in a Health Care systems area of focus.
878.title: Health Care Residency and Integrative Seminar (5)

880.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 715. Permission of the instructor. first of two courses preparing clinical nurse leaders. emphasis is on the use of evidence-based approaches from outcomes/quality, transitional care, and finance to improve nursing care delivery in clinical systems.
880.title: Evidence-Based Care for Clinical Nurse Leaders I (5)

881.description: Preor corequisites, nUrs 715 and 880. Advanced clinical nurse leadership course emphasizing collaboration with key stakeholders to implement evidence-based interventions and improve care delivery in clinical systems.
881.title: Evidence-Based Care for Clinical Nurse Leaders II (6)

882.description: Graduate standing required. Prepares nurses for teaching in clinical settings. focuses on how to develop a clinical course, select clinical settings, work with staff, plan teaching methods and learner activities, and evaluate outcomes.
882.title: Clinical Teaching (3)

889.description: topics directed by an authority in the field.
889.title: Special Topics in Nursing (1–5)

912.description: Critically analyzes historical and current views of knowledge development and scientific development. it examines the underlying ontological and epistemological assumptions of these views and how they influence scientific inquiry. students will learn to critically evaluate extant theories, concepts, and models for use in research, including their testability and utility.
912.title: Theoretical Foundations of Scientific Inquiry (3)

915.title: Nursing, Health Organizations and Policy Making (3)

920.description: Admission to nursing graduate program. focuses on philosophical and theoretical foundations for practice and the utility of these foundations for advanced practice.
920.title: Theoretical Foundations in Advanced Practice (3)

928.description: examines the major theoretical paradigms, perspectives, and issues in organization theory, particularly as applied to organizations providing health care services.
928.title: Organizational Theories (3)

930.description: Applies the developmental science perspective to children at risk for health problems. students examine conceptual models, design, measurement, and ethical issues involved in preventing or ameliorating these health problems.
930.title: Infants and Children at Risk (3)

932.description: explores theoretical, methodological, and ethical issues related to research in families and health across the life span. Content includes family research related to health promotion, risk reduction, vulnerability, and health risk, and the family in the context of acute and chronic illness. Cultural, ethnic, and socioeconomic issues are included.
932.title: Families and Health (3)

933.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 976. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. examines literature on quality of care -effectiveness, safety, efficiency, equity, timeliness, and patient-centeredness. Critically evaluates conceptual frameworks, research designs, sources of data, analytic approaches, and implications for health care policy.
933.title: Health Care Quality and Patient Outcomes: Conceptual and Empirical Approaches (3)

941.description: Admission to nursing graduate program. seminar focused on exploration of resources to guide the practice inquiry project and development of a problem statement.
941.title: Practice Inquiry Seminar I (1)

942.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 941. seminar focused on design and implementation issues related to the practice inquiry project.
942.title: Practice Inquiry Seminar II (1)

950.description: Knowledge, theories, and skills necessary for transition into an academic teaching role in university schools of nursing. Particular emphasis on the teaching-learning process as used in higher education.
950.title: Analysis of the Academic Role in Nursing Education (3)

953.description: focuses on the analysis of contemporary ethical/legal dilemmas in health care and research. examines nurses’ ethical/legal responsibilities, law and the impact of judicial precedent upon clinical practice and research, the interface of law and ethics, and comparative theories/models of ethical reasoning and decision-making.
953.title: Ethics and Law in Health Care and Research (3)

957.description: required preparation, nUrs 912 or graduate level theory course. in-depth exploration of selected programmatic research in nursing and related fields on prevention and management of chronic conditions in order to generate and evaluate treatment theory and intervention protocol.
957.title: From Theory to Intervention (3)

958.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 957. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. examines methodological, ethical, and practical issues in the design and implementation of theory-based intervention studies.
958.title: Designing Intervention Studies (3)

959.description: Course is designed to assist doctoral students and post-docs with preparation of individual national research service Award (nrsA) or other research grant application. All steps in grant writing process will be addressed. student should have solidified research idea prior to course. Mentor must agree to work with student throughout course.
959.title: Research Grant Writing (3)

960.description: Proseminars are offered for one, two, or three credits. topics differ each semester.
960.title: Proseminar in Nursing (1–3)

962.title: Conducting Systematic Reviews and Writing Specific Aims (4)

963.description: in this course, students apply principles and practices of writing to the preparation of manuscripts for publication.
963.title: Writing for Publication (3)

965.description: This course is designed to enhance the student’s knowledge of relevant issues researchers face when planning, designing, and implementing research with an older adult population.
965.title: Issues in Gerontological Research (3)

972.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 671 or 777. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course will examine principles of bivariate and multiple regression and correlation, as well as univariate AnovA, multiple AnovA, AnCovA, and repeated measures AnovA. emphasis is on application of these techniques in the analysis of nursing and health-related data.
972.title: Statistical Models for Health Research (4)

976.description: systematic and critical analysis of quantitative research designs including experimental, quasiexperimental, longitudinal, comparative, correlational, and descriptive. examines sampling frameworks, types of samples, sampling errors and biases, and advantages and disadvantages of these designs for the study of nursing and healthcare issues.
976.title: Issues in Sampling and Design (3)

978.description: required preparation, graduate level statistics course in the previous three years. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the required preparation. examination of measurement and techniques for assessing validity, reliability, and structure of data collection instruments. instrument construction and procedures for critical evaluation of instruments are included.
978.title: Principles of Measurement (3)

979.description: required preparation, doctoral level qualitative methods course or nUrs 977. emphasizes the workof analysis and interpretation. students apply relevant qualitative techniques to their own data.
979.title: Qualitative Analysis (3)

980.description: explores quantitative observational research techniques. strategies for developing coding systems, determining reliability and validity, and analyzing data are included.
980.title: Observational Methods (3)

981.description: Prerequisite, nUrs 972. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. examines longitudinal research methods, including conceptualization, design, and analysis. Assumptions and limitations of longitudinal statistics, relationship between design and analyses, and strategies to maintain scientific integrity are covered.
981.title: Longitudinal Methods and Analysis (3)

985.description: directs students to develop research skills related to the dissertation and to their future research.
985.title: Research Seminar and Practicum: Guided Individual Research Experience (1–5)

986.description: Clinical residency focused on the synthesis of knowledge related to advanced practice, leadership, and practice-based inquiry.
986.title: Doctor of Nursing Practice Residency (3-5)

240.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101/101L and CHEM 102/102L. Relationships of human nutrition to health and disease. Integration of biology, chemistry, and social sciences as related to human function. Nutrient composition of foods and safety of the food supply.
240.title: Introduction to Human Nutrition (3)

245.description: Examines the intersection of local foods and public health with respect to nutrition and environmental, economic, and community issues. Students explore impacts and potential solutions of the increasingly industrialized and centralized food system, while assisting community partners to increase opportunities for farmers, local food marketers, distributors, and entrepreneurs.
245.title: Sustainable Local Food Systems: Intersection of Local Foods and Public Health (3)

295.description: Permission of the instructor. For undergraduates enrolled in the department’s baccalaureate degree program. Directed readings or laboratory study on a selected topic. May be taken more than once for credit.
295.title: Undergraduate Research Experience in Nutrition (3)

400.description: Prerequisites, BIOL 101, CHEM 101 and 102, and NUTR 240. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Function of the human body focusing on nutrient interaction. Review of structure and function of cells and organs. For advanced undergraduates and graduate students needing to enhance background prior to NUTR 600.
400.title: Introduction to Nutritional Biochemistry (3)

600.description: Prerequisite, NUTR 400. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Cell biochemistry and physiology emphasizing integration of proteins, carbohydrates, and lipids in whole-body metabolism; regulation of energy expenditure, food intake, metabolic adaptations, and gene expression; and macronutrient-related diseases (atherosclerosis, obesity).
600.title: Human Metabolism: Macronutrients (3)

611.description: Prerequisite, NUTR 400. This course covers nutrition during the life cycle. Units include women during preconception, pregnancy, and lactation; infancy; childhood; adolescence; and older adults (65+). Nutrient and energy needs, assessment of nutritional status, and cultural and socioeconomic barriers are discussed for each phase.
611.title: Nutrition across the Life Cycle (MHCH 611) (3)

615.description: Prerequisite, nUtr 400. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. special dietary and nutritional needs and conditions of the elderly. includes overview of biology and demography of aging, discussion of nutritional requirements, and assessment of the elderly as well as nutrition in health and various disease states of the elderly.
615.title: Nutrition in the Elderly (1)

620.description: Prerequisites, NUTR 400 and 600. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Cell biochemistry and physiology emphasizing metabolism of vitamins and minerals including antioxidant protection, immune function, nutrient control of gene expression, and disease states induced by deficiencies (e.g., iron-deficient anemia).
620.title: Human Metabolism: Micronutrients (3)

630.description: Prerequisite, NUTR 240. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Functions of a nutritionist working with individuals, emphasizing interviewing, assessment, nutrition care planning, counseling, and service documentation in prevention and therapeutic situations. Practice in the use of current dietary analysis software programs and development of educational materials included.
630.title: Nutrition Assessment and Counseling Skills (3)

640.description: Prerequisite, NUTR 630. Course designed to examine the rationale and implementation of diet therapy and nutrition support in the prevention or treatment of chronic disease.
640.title: Medical Nutrition Therapy I: Chronic Disease Management (3)

642.description: Prerequisite, NUTR 640. Course designed to examine the rationale and implementation of diet therapy and nutrition support in the prevention or treatment of acute diseases.
