672.title: Radiographic Imaging II (4)

681.description: Majors only. The course covers issues related to healthcare systems, medicolegal ethics, and practice and quality assurance. Three lecture hours per week.
681.title: Trends in Medical Imaging Practices Issues in the Radiology Practice Environment (3)

686.description: Majors only. Students complete a research project involving a major clinical or policy issue in radiologic science. This course is an expansion of the fall semester research culminating in both a paper and presentation.
686.title: Research in Radiologic Science II (2)

694.description: Majors only. This course involves the pharmacology of common radiology medications and advanced patient assessment techniques. With the additional knowledge and skills, students can make informed decisions regarding patient care. Three lecture hours.
694.title: Clinical Decisions in Radiology (3)

310.description: Implications of the relationship between women and leisure from a lifestyle perspective and an analysis of the changing role of women and changing leisure concepts from a feminist perspective.
310.title: Women, Work, and Leisure (WMST 310) (3)

311.description: An introduction to leisure studies and its various elements developed from historical, philosophical, and theoretical perspectives with a focus on the meanings of leisure in individual and community life.
311.title: Recreation and Leisure in Society (3)

370.description: An analysis of the issues that affect recreation programming for persons across the lifespan. Constraints associated with age, economics, and disabling conditions will be explored.
370.title: Recreation Services across the Lifespan (3)

390.description: Current issues, techniques, and research of a topical short-term nature are the focus of these seminars.
390.title: Selected Issues Seminar (1–12)

396.description: Individual readings, research, and/or field study of a recreation issue, problem, service system, or activity pattern. The course may take the form of an independent study or seminar depending upon students’ interests and enrollment.
396.title: Independent Studies in RECR (1–12)

420.description: This experiential course covers the concepts and skills used in program planning. Students apply their program planning skills to real-life situations and implement a recreation program for a community agency.
420.title: Program Planning in Recreation Services (3)

430.description: An analysis of the techniques, methods, and motives of group and community leaders. Special attention is focused upon the roles of organizational structure, personnel policies, and in-service training programs.
430.title: Introduction to Leadership and Group Dynamics (3)

440.description: A survey course taught from a psychosocial perspective addressing the roles of public and private agencies in meeting increased demand for outdoor recreation. Emphasizes the implications of environmental awareness on outdoor recreation.
440.title: Outdoor Recreation and Environmental Issues (3)

470.description: An analysis of aspects that affect recreation and leisure behavior from birth to death, with a focus on issues associated with race, class, gender, sexual identity, and disabling conditions.
470.title: Recreation and Leisure across the Lifespan (3)

475.description: An examination of disability from a cultural perspective with the application of theoretical and scientific knowledge to provide recreation interventions that facilitate participation in life by individuals with disabilities.
475.title: Disability, Culture, and Therapeutic Recreation (3)

50.description: The seminar is designed to enable firstyear students to work closely with senior professors in classes that enroll 20 students or fewer. See the directory of classes for specific offerings.
50.title: First-Year Seminar (3)

676.description: Development of helping skills for the practice of therapeutic recreation emphasizing rationale, techniques, and role responsibilities of therapeutic recreation in the area of leisure education. A 20-hour practicum is required.
676.title: Clinical Skills in Therapeutic Recreation (3)

677.description: Prerequisites, RECR 475 and 676. Instruction in the relationship between various disabling conditions and the practice of therapeutic recreation. A 24-hour practicum is required.
677.title: Disabling Conditions and the Practice of Therapeutic Recreation (3)

691H.description: Special studies for undergraduates. Intensive study on a particular topic under the supervision of a qualified member of the staff. For RECR majors, with special permission of the faculty members involved and the director of undergraduate studies.
691H.title: Honors in RECR (3)

692H.description: Honors project in recreation. The completion of a special project, approved by the department, by a student who has been designated a candidate for undergraduate honors. The second of a two-course honors sequence.
692H.title: Honors in RECR (3)

710.description: An analysis of the scope of leisure research, recreation services, the evolution of leisure and of individual recreation behavior.
710.title: Leisure and Organized Recreation in the United States (3)

770.description: emphasis on information specific to the administration of therapeutic recreation such as fiscal management, quality assurance, evaluation, marketing of therapeutic recreation, and other general administrative topics.
770.title: Administration of Therapeutic Recreation Services (3)

775.description: A study of the existing practices and principles of therapeutic recreation. An in-depth treatment of assessment/evaluation, goal setting and individualized planning, documentation, leisure counseling, and clinical skills.
775.title: Principles and Procedures in Therapeutic Recreation (3)

790.description: Permission of the department. May be repeated for credit.
790.title: Independent Field Study (3)

830.description: This course addresses organizational behavior and theory to promote insight into micro and macro issues confronting professionals in organized recreation services.
830.title: Managing Organizational Behavior in Recreation Services (3)

865.description: A seminar to involve graduate recreation students in in-depth analyses of selected topics, issues, and problems relevant to the recreation management in public and not-for-profit leisure service organizations.
865.title: Issues and Trends in Recreation Management (3)

876.description: An analysis of selected issues, problems and concerns in the provision of therapeutic recreation and inclusive recreation services.
876.title: Issues and Trends in Therapeutic Recreation (3)

880.description: Participation in full-time, practical on-the-job experience in a recreational agency of the student’s choice.
880.title: Internship in Recreation Administration (2)

890.description: A survey of contemporary views of society and their structures and functions, as they relate to concepts of leisure and recreation behaviors.
890.title: Seminar in Leisure Studies (3)

950.description: An appraisal of current recreation and leisure research design using both quantitative and qualitative data. students complete and deliver a formal research proposal.
950.title: Recreation Research Design and Methods I (3)

951.description: Prerequisite, reCr 950. required preparation, any statistics course. students analyze quantitative and qualitative data and apply their work to theory and practice. students complete the research proposed in reCr 950.
951.title: Recreation Research Design and Methods II (3)

101.description: An introduction to the academic study of religion that considers approaches to the interpretation of religion and includes study of several religious traditions.
101.title: Introduction to Religious Studies (3)

102.description: This course examines forms of religious expression as embodied in several important religious traditions. It investigates religious experience; myth and ritual; teachings and scripture; historical, social, and artistic aspects of religion; and the nature and function of religion in society, with a special focus on ethics and values.
102.title: World Religions (3)

103.description: This course introduces students to the various books of the Hebrew Bible and to the history and culture of ancient Israel, focusing on the formation of national identity, ancient conceptualizations of divinity, ritual practice, and modes of social regulation, all of which are set against the background of the ancient Near East.
103.title: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament Literature (JWST 103) (3)

104.description: This course introduces students to New Testament literature and to the faith of the early Christian communities, focusing on Jewish and Greco-Roman background, the development of the gospel traditions, the life and ministry of Jesus, the ministry of Paul, the post-Pauline era, and the literature of the Johannine circle.
104.title: Introduction to New Testament Literature (3)

105.description: An introduction to religions and the religious life of the ancient world (1000 BCE–300 CE) in various cultural settings: Greek cities, cosmopolitan Hellenistic kingdoms in Egypt and Syria, and the Roman Empire.
105.title: Religions of the Greco-Roman World (3)

106.description: This course surveys Jewish history and religion during the Second Temple and Rabbinic periods, from the destruction of the First Jewish Temple (Solomon’s Temple) in 586 BCE to the Muslim conquest of Palestine (640 CE).
106.title: Introduction to Early Judaism (JWST 106) (3)

107.description: The course offers a comprehensive understanding of the development of Judaism from the late Middle Ages to contemporary times.
107.title: Introduction to Modern Judaism (JWST 107) (3)

108.description: This course will explore Jewish literary works that are considered “fundamental,” “classic,” “traditional” (often, all of the above), including the Hebrew Bible, the Mishnah, the Babylonian Talmud, midrashic collections, works by Maimonides, major codes of Jewish law, major kabbalistic, philosophic, poetic, and ethical works, hassidic compositions, and more.
108.title: Classic Jewish Texts: From Bible and Dead Sea Scrolls to Kabbalah and Hassidism (3)

109.description: An examination extending from Hebrew origins to the Babylonian exile and including political history as well as social and religious institutions.
109.title: History and Culture of Ancient Israel (3)

110.description: This course surveys the archaeology of Palestine (modern Israel and Jordan) from the Persian period (ca. 586 BCE) to the Muslim conquest (640 CE).
110.title: The Archaeology of Palestine in the New Testament Period (CLAR 110, JWST 110) (3)

117.description: (3). An overview of the history and culture of the ancient Near East, from the birth of writing through the first millennium BCE, covering the regions of Mesopotamia, Egypt, Anatolia, and Syria-Palestine.
117.title: Culture of the Ancient Near East

121.description: An introductory course that explores relations between religion and culture through the examination of social theory and the analysis of case studies. The case studies focus on such issues as visual culture, ritual, media, gender, and politics.
121.title: Introduction to Religion and Culture (3)

122.description: An introduction to philosophical approaches to the study of religion, exploring such topics as religious language and experience, the problem of evil, the relation between religious belief and practice, and issues of religious diversity.
122.title: Introduction to Philosophical Approaches to Religion (3)

123.description: An introduction to the broad scope of Jewish history, culture, and identity, from biblical times to the 21st century and from the Middle East to the New World.
123.title: Introduction to Jewish Studies (JWST 100) (3)

127.description: The proposition that God exists is treated as a scientific hypothesis. Evidence for and against the hypothesis. The status of other minds and free will in science and religion. Conflicting views about creation, revelation, miracles, and prayers.
127.title: The Claims of Science and Religion (3)

134.description: A study of the nature, methods, and aims of ethics as seen in exemplary persons and actions with emphasis on religious and social context and contemporary problems.
134.title: Introduction to Religious Ethics (3)

135.description: Problems in the study of ethics in the new worlds of information technology.
135.title: Technology, the Self, and Ethical Problems (3)

138.description: This course explores the development of religious liberty and freedom of conscience in Western culture byexamining both the historical emergence of these concepts and important contemporary controversies.
138.title: Religious Freedom (3)

140.description: An introduction to the history, themes, and issues in American religion from the precolonial period to the present.
140.title: Religion in America (3)

141.description: Survey of the historical development of various African American religious traditions, with emphasis on folk spirituality, gender issues, black nationalism, and the role of the church in the black community.
141.title: African American Religions (3)

142.description: An introduction to Roman Catholicism in the United States.
142.title: Catholicism in America (3)

143.description: An examination of Judaism in its two major centers, demonstrating how different social and cultural environments shape very different interpretations and practices of the Jewish tradition.
143.title: Judaism in Our Time (JWST 143) (3)

151.description: This course surveys the history of Latin American religious traditions from precontact to the present. It explores the contributions of African, indigenous, and European traditions as well as the extraordinary combinations that resulted from their interaction.
151.title: Religion in Latin America (3)

161.description: Analysis of continuities and innovations in the history of Western Christian traditions in the West and globally.
161.title: Introduction to the History of Christian Traditions (3)

162.description: This course provides students with a first glimpse and insight into the Catholic tradition, past, present, and future: its beliefs, structure, aims, successes, and failures.
162.title: Introduction to Catholicism (3)

163.description: A consideration of major questions within and about religious thought.
163.title: Critical Issues in Western Religious Thought (3)

164.description: During the Middle Ages and the early modern era, various inquisitions used legal inquiry and torture to determine the boundaries of heresy. This course surveys the influence of these regimes on the doctrine, practices, and morality of heretics, mystics, witches, Jews, and Muslims, in the interest of delimiting “orthodox” Catholicism.
164.title: Heresy and Inquisition: Religion, Ethics, Marginalization (3)

165.description: Comparative study of mysticism in several religious traditions, Eastern and Western.
165.title: Mysticism (3)

166.description: Permission of the instructor. A religious studies approach to the rituals, cultures, and disciplines of the university, assessing the ways in which explanatory ideals are embedded, changed, and promoted.
166.title: Ideals, Cultures, and Rituals of the University (3)

180.description: A broad, comprehensive, and interdisciplinary introduction to the traditional civilization of the Muslim world.
180.title: Introduction to Islamic Civilization (ASIA 180) (3)

181.description: Surveys important developments in modern Islamic civilizations, from 1453 to today. Among the topics covered are the Ottoman Empire; the rise of Islamic modernism, reformism, and fundamentalism; the Palestinian/Israeli controversy; the Islamic Revolution in Iran; the Taliban; 9/11 and Muslim responses.
181.title: Later Islamic Civilization and Modern Muslim Cultures (ASIA 181) (3)

184.description: This course surveys East Asian religions and their relationship with the natural world. It provides an East Asian religious perspective on environmental thought and an environmental perspective on East Asian religions. We will explore parallels and divergences, and how each can enrich and critique the other.
184.title: East Asian Religions: The Religions of East Asia and the Environment (3)

185.description: A survey of gender roles in Muslim societies from the advent of Islam to the present. It explores how Muslims have interpreted the Qur’an to determine discourses on gender and sexuality and emphasizes the role of religious authority as well as historical/geographical contexts for Muslim women’s lives.
185.title: Women/Gender/Islam (3)

196.description: Permission of the instructor. Subject matter will vary with instructor but will always be focused on a particular problem or issue.
196.title: Independent Study (3)

201.description: The course looks at the origins of biblical interpretation, how the Hebrew Bible was interpreted around the turn of the Common Era, the key formative period for early Christianity and rabbinic Judaism. We consider the nature of interpretation as an endeavor, as well as how the Bible came to be viewed as Scripture.
201.title: Ancient Biblical Interpretation (3)

206.description: An examination of prophecy and divination in the Israelite-Jewish traditions and in their environments, including an analysis of the major biblical prophets.
206.title: Prophecy and Divination in Ancient Israel and Judah (JWST 206) (3)

207.description: An analysis of the variety of traditions used in the first two centuries to portray Jesus, focusing on the reasons for this variety and the historical and literary problems it presents.
207.title: Jesus in Myth, Tradition, and History, 30–200 CE (3)

208.description: An analysis of the origin of the Christian church and its early expansion, with particular emphasis on the problems evident in the shift from a Jewish to a Gentile framework. Paul’s role in defining and resolving the issues is considered in detail and evaluated in the light of subsequent events.
208.title: The Birth of Christianity (3)

209.description: A study of various forms of Christianity in the second and third centuries (e.g., Gnosticism, Marcionism, Montanism), focusing on their polemical relationship to orthodox Christianity.
209.title: Varieties of Early Christianity (3)

211.description: An introduction to the culture and history of ancient Israel through an exploration of the language of the Hebrew Bible. Students will learn the essentials for basic engagement with biblical Hebrew, then consider what this linguistic evidence reveals about the historical and cultural background of the Hebrew Bible.
211.title: Classical Hebrew I: A Linguistic Introduction to the Hebrew Bible (3)

212.description: Prerequisite, RELI 211. This course explores the linguistic background of the Hebrew Bible, giving special attention to the literary aspect of biblical interpretation. Specific topics include the forms of the Hebrew verb, prose and poetic genres in the Hebrew Bible, wordplay and repetition, narration and dialogue.
212.title: Classical Hebrew II: A Linguistic Introduction to the Hebrew Bible (3)

218.title: Christianity and Islam in the Middle Ages (GERM 218) (3)

222.description: Prerequisite, PHIL 134 or RELI 122, 126, 140, 161, or 163. Representative themes and approaches in the work of modern Western religious thinkers.
222.title: Modern Western Religious Thought (3)

225.description: This course explores the range of cultural manifestation of Christianity in the modern world, focusing particularly on differences of race, ethnicity, gender, geography, and class.
225.title: Christian Cultures (3)

232.description: An introduction to the study of shrines and pilgrimage in multiple cultural contexts.
232.title: Shrines and Pilgrimages (3)

235.description: A consideration of the attitudes toward place and space as they are expressed in religious ritual and artifact.
235.title: Place, Space, and Religion (3)

236.description: An introduction to religion and visual culture in the United States. The course focuses on painting, ritual objects, and architecture.
236.title: Religious Things (3)

239.title: German Culture and the Jewish Question (CMPL 270, GERM 270, JWST 239) (3)

240.description: A study of religious ideas and cultural forms in America through an examination of a variety of genres including novels, poetry, essays, and sermons.
240.title: Religion, Literature, and the Arts in America (3)

242.description: An introduction to new religious movements in the United States, with emphasis on the nature of conversion and the role of founders.
242.title: New Religious Movements in America (3)

243.description: Course provides a comprehensive introduction to American Judaism, its various movements, institutions, theological, and liturgical characteristics, as well as its standing within the larger framework of religious life in America.
243.title: Introduction to American Judaism (JWST 243) (3)

244.description: An examination of the development of teachings on issues of gender and sexuality through the history of Western Christianity, with particular focus on contemporary controversies.
244.title: Gender and Sexuality in Western Christianity (WMST 244) (3)

245.description: The goal of this course is to orient students to the great diversity of Latina and Latino religious formations in the United States today. Focusing on Indigenous, African, and Catholic Creole “inspirations,” this course will focus students on the emergence of a distinctly United States Latina/o religious experience.
245.title: Creolization and Latina/o Religious Transformation in the United States (3)

246.description: This course examines accounts of supernatural beings such as zombies and vampires and aims to understand them as popular ways of making sense of the world in the context of uneven and frequently unsettling processes of modernization, neoliberalism, and globalization.
246.title: Supernatural Encounters: Zombies, Vampires, Demons, and the Occult in the Americas (3)

248.description: This course surveys Muslim communities in North America in their religious, historical, political, social, and cultural dimensions. Discussion frames include methods for the study of American Muslims, the role of public and media representations of Islam and Muslims, and the place of American Muslims within the larger American religious landscape.
248.title: Introduction to American Islam (3)

282.description: Today Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., is celebrated as a national icon. Yet most people know little about Dr. King beyond the “I Have a Dream” speech. This course proposes that the very iconization of Dr. King has obfuscated the very real challenge that Dr. King posed to American society.
282.title: Martin Luther King and the Prophetic Tradition (3)

283.description: Examines the diverse beliefs, practices, and cultures associated with Buddhism in the Himalayan regions of India, Nepal, and Tibet. Topics include Buddhism’s development and spread, the cultural dynamics of Himalayan societies, monasticism, folk religion, revivalism, tourism, gender, globalization, and the role of the state in shaping Buddhist life and culture.
283.title: The Buddhist Tradition: India, Nepal, and Tibet (ASIA 300) (3)

284.description: An examination of the development of Buddhism after its importation to East Asia.
284.title: The Buddhist Tradition: East Asia (ASIA 284) (3)

285.description: This course explores the Theravada school of Buddhism and themes in the social, cultural, and political lives of the Theravada Buddhist countries of Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka.
285.title: The Buddhist Tradition: Southeast Asia and Sri Lanka (ASIA 285) (3)

286.description: Historical survey of the major premodern religious traditions in Japan: Shinto, Buddhism, Shugendo, and Christianity.
286.title: Premodern Japanese Religions (ASIA 301) (3)

287.description: Survey of the major religious traditions in modern and contemporary Japan: Shinto, Buddhism, and the New Religions.
287.title: Modern Japanese Religions (ASIA 302) (3)

288.description: Historical introduction to Chinese religions: Confucianism, Daoism, Buddhism, and folk religion.
288.title: Chinese Religions (ASIA 303) (3)

289.description: An introduction the life and significance of the Prophet Muhammad and the sacred scripture of Islam, the Qur’an. It offers discussion of textual sources for Muhammad’s biography; his emulation and veneration in Muslim societies, and the nature, compilation, reception history, and range of interpretations of the Qur’an.
289.title: Muhammad and the Qur’an (3)

322.description: This course addresses terms such as “the sacred,” “the dead,” “divinity,” and “possession” to explore the limitations and new potentials of religious studies for describing human experience.
322.title: Theories of Religion (3)

323.description: Introduction to basic thinking about cultural difference (race, gender, nationality, religion, etc.). The course encourages students to examine the ways paradigms shape how we act, think, and imagine as members of diverse cultures in the United States.
323.title: Social Theory and Cultural Diversity (3)

325.description: Critical exploration of the ways in which religion, magic, and science have been constructed as distinct domains of knowledge in the West since the late 19th century.
325.title: Religion, Magic, and Science (3)

332.description: The course comes to provide students with historical and theological knowledge and conceptual tools that will enable them to understand the very rich and diverse Protestant tradition.
332.title: The Protestant Tradition (3)

338.description: An exploration of the position of religion in American legal and social theory, with particular focus on jurisprudence under the First Amendment.
338.title: Religion in American Law (3)

340.description: An examination of the growth of liberal theological expressions, such as rationalism, romanticism, and modernism, from the early 18th century to the present.
340.title: Liberal Tradition in American Religion (3)

342.description: Permission of the instructor. An introduction to the diversity of African American beliefs, experiences, and expressions from the colonial era to the present. Exploration will be both historical and thematic.
342.title: African American Religious Experience (ANTH 342, FOLK 342) (3)

343.description: Examines the major religious groups that operate in the state of Israel and influence its social and cultural development; analyzes the relationship among religion, state, and society in Israel.
343.title: Religion in Modern Israel (JWST 343) (3)

345.description: This course is an introduction to Black Atlantic discourses from ethnographic and religious studies perspectives. Readings will privilege African-inspired performance and aesthetic forms as these are produced in religious practice.
345.title: Black Atlantic Religions (3)

362.description: In certain eras, Mary has been more central to Catholic devotion than Christ. This course explores doctrine, liturgy, and popular devotion centering on the Virgin in medieval European Christianity, her impact on colonial religion in the New World, and her roles in Protestantism, Eastern Orthodoxy, and Islam.
362.title: Mary in the Christian Tradition (WMST 362) (3)

365.description: Permission of the instructor. An investigation of one writer or school in the history of Christian theology as an example of typical methods, positions, and problems within the tradition.
365.title: Studies in Christian Theologies and Theologians (3)

366.description: Permission of the instructor. Restricted to students with a reading knowledge of Latin. Readings in one or two major texts in Latin that permit close study of several issues in the development of Christian life and thought during the Middle Ages.
366.title: Medieval Religious Texts (3)

367.description: Prerequisites, RELI 161 and 163. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. This course examines creative expression at the service of religious belief from 1000 to 1700. Poetry, drama, art, architecture, and music will be the texts to understand the religious culture of this rich period.
367.title: The Art of Devotion in Medieval and Early Modern Europe (3)

371.description: An investigation of the forms, characteristics, and variety of the mystical experiences of women.
371.title: Women Mystics (WMST 371) (3)

375.description: This course examines the archaeological context of Greek religion, cults, and associated rituals from the Bronze Age until the Hellenistic period with emphasis on urban, rural, and panhellenic sanctuaries, and methods of approaching ancient religion and analyzing cult practices.
375.title: The Archaeology of Cult: The Material Culture of Greek Religion (CLAR 375) (3)

381.description: Exploration of the major religious traditions of South Asia. Focuses on the beliefs and practices associated with different traditions, and the ways that these relate to one another and to broader political, historical, and cultural formations. Also addresses questions of modernization, reform, communal violence, and other transformations of religious life.
381.title: Religions of South Asia (3)

385.description: This course introduces students to the multifaceted ways in which Muslims in the modern and contemporary periods have approached, experienced, and interpreted the Qur’an, including discussions of accessibility, hermeneutical methods, and exegetical themes.
385.title: Modern Muslims and the Qur’an (3)

390.description: Permission of the instructor. Subject matter will vary with instructor but will always be focused on a particular problem or issue.
390.title: Topics in the Study of Religion (3)

401.description: The first part of a twosemester introduction to the grammar of biblical Hebrew.
401.title: Introductory Biblical Hebrew I (3)

402.description: Prerequisite, RELI 401. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. The second part of a two-semester introduction to the grammar of biblical Hebrew.
402.title: Introductory Biblical Hebrew II (3)

403.description: Prerequisite, RELI 402. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. A consolidation of the fundamentals of classical Hebrew grammar via readings of biblical texts of various genres (including both prose and poetry).
403.title: Intermediate Classical Hebrew I (3)

404.description: Prerequisite, RELI 403. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Further readings of classical Hebrew texts, focusing on biblical poetry as well as early postbiblical material (e.g., nonbiblical texts from Qumran, Mishnah/Tosefta).
404.title: Intermediate Classical Hebrew II (3)

409.description: Prerequisite, GREK 222. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.
409.title: Greek New Testament (GREK 409) (3)

410.description: Prerequisites, RELI 403 and 404. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisites. Reading texts in rabbinic Hebrew or in biblical and/or talmudic Aramaic, with appropriate grammatical instruction.
410.title: Aramaic/Rabbinic Hebrew (3)

411.description: Prerequisites, RELI 403 and 404. Readings in literary, epistolary, and juridical texts.
411.title: Advanced Akkadian (3)

412.description: Prerequisites, RELI 403 and 404. Readings in the alphabetic texts of Ras Shamra and a study of the elements of Ugaritic grammar.
412.title: Ugaritic (3)

413.description: Coptic, the last stage of Egyptian, a living language in the Roman and Byzantine period. Thorough grounding in the grammar of the Sahidic dialect as a basis for reading biblical monastic and Gnostic texts.
413.title: Biblical Coptic and Early Egyptian Monasticism (3)

421.description: This course explores the complex relation between religion and science in the modern world. Public disputes over teaching evolution in American schools serve as a central case study of this.
421.title: Religion and Science (3)

423.description: Prerequisite, RELI 140. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. A theoretical inquiry into ethnicity, race, and religion as constituents of personal and communal identity. Emphasis on global migrations, colonial and postcolonial relations, diasporic communities, and issues of religious pluralism.
423.title: Ethnicity, Race, and Religion in America (3)

424.description: An examination of contemporary gender theory, with particular focus on its application to the study of religion.
424.title: Gender Theory and the Study of Religion (WMST 424) (3)

425.description: A critical exploration of the concept of religious experience as defined by such authors as William James and Sigmund Freud.
425.title: Psychology of Religion (3)

438.description: A seminar on concepts of nature within religions and a variety of world-wide spiritual traditions. Emphasis on sacred space, place, and pilgrimage as a vital intersection of religion and nature.
438.title: Religion, Nature, and Environment (3)

441.description: An examination of primary sources in the history of American religion from the precolonial era to the Civil War.
441.title: History of Religion in America to 1865 (3)

442.description: An examination of primary sources in the history of American religion since the Civil War.
442.title: History of Religion in America since 1865 (3)

443.description: Juniors or seniors only. Examination of evangelicalism and its role in American society, politics, and culture. Exploration of its various subdivisions and its relation to such movements as fundamentalism, pentecostalism, revivalism, and premillennialism.
443.title: Evangelicalism in Contemporary America (3)

444.description: The seminar examines the developments in gender roles and in sexuality in contemporary Judaism.
444.title: Gender and Sexuality in Contemporary Judaism (JWST 444) (3)

445.description: A study of intercultural interaction and interreligious encounter focusing on Asian religions in America, 1784 to the present.
445.title: Asian Religions in America (ASIA 445) (3)

446.description: An exploration of the varied and complex relationships which have developed between Christianity and Judaism, from the first century to the 21st century.
446.title: Christian-Jewish Relations throughout the Ages (3)

450.description: This course deals with various topics related to sexuality and marriage in Jewish tradition and history: sex outside of marriage, wedding ceremonies, regulation of marital sex, menstruation, homosexuality, and more.
450.title: Sexuality and Marriage in Jewish Tradition and History (3)

480.description: Stresses the diversity of modern Islamic experience by examining the works of various Muslim authors. Genres may include travelogues, memoirs, novels, sermons, and treatises, among others.
480.title: Modern Muslim Literatures (3)

481.description: An exploration of explosive combinations of religion and politics in the Iranian revolution, the Palestinian movement, Hindu nationalism in India, and Christian fundamentalism in America.
481.title: Religion, Fundamentalism, and Nationalism (PWAD 481) (3)

485.description: This course approaches questions of sexuality and marriage in Muslim discourse and practice in historical and geographical contexts. It focuses on gender as a category of inquiry and considers issues such as Muslim family law, normative sexuality, marriage practices, and religiously defined family values in their changing interpretations and applications.
485.title: Marriage and Sexuality in Islam (3)

487.description: This course explores the role that mountains and pilgrimage have played in Japanese cosmology and how they relate to methodology of studying place and space.
487.title: Mountains, Pilgrimage, and Sacred Places in Japan (ASIA 487) (3)

488.description: This course discusses the development of Shinto in Japanese history and covers themes such as myths, syncretism, sacred sites, iconography, nativism, religion and the state, and historiography.
488.title: Shinto in Japanese History (ASIA 488) (3)

489.description: Permission of the instructor. This course examines the cultural construction of animals in Japanese myth, folklore, and religion.
489.title: Animals in Japanese Religion (ASIA 489) (3)

502.description: Permission of the instructor. An examination of Babylonian, Canaanite, Egyptian, Hittite, and Sumerian texts from the prebiblical era, focusing on representative myths, epics, sagas, songs, proverbs, prophecies, and hymns.
502.title: Myths and Epics of the Ancient Near East (FOLK 502) (3)

503.description: A comprehensive introduction to the Dead Sea Scrolls and the different Jewish groups connected with them.
503.title: Exploring the Dead Sea Scrolls (JWST 503) (3)

512.description: Prerequisite, RELI 110. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This is a course on ancient synagogues in Palestine and the Diaspora from the Second Temple period to the seventh century CE.
512.title: Ancient Synagogues (CLAR 512, JWST 512) (3)

522.description: Permission of the instructor. An exploration of influential 19th-century critiques of religion, including texts by such thinkers as Feuerbach, Marx, Kierkegaard, Nietzsche, Stanton, Douglass, and Freud.
522.title: 19th-Century Critiques of Religion (3)

524.description: Critical exploration of exemplary contemporary ethnographies of religion focusing on the ways that ethnographic methods and writing styles shape knowledge of religious and cultural life in various traditions and parts of the world. Topics considered include field work, culture, ethics, and the challenges of interpreting and representing religious experience.
524.title: Ethnographic Approaches to Contemporary Religion (3)

528.description: An examination of ritual, allegory, and symbol as modes of religious expression in cultic and literary contexts.
528.title: Rituals and Rhetorics of Religion (3)

530.description: This seminar explores the historical development of “religion” as a concept and object of academic scholarship through the critical study of key texts and foundational debates about religion in Western thought.
530.title: Genealogies of Religion (3)

534.description: Seniors or graduate students only. Examination of religious-ethical dimensions of such issues as the dying patient, organ transplants, abortion, prolongation of life, and experimentation on human beings, drawing on theory from the traditional Western religions and the social sciences.
534.title: Religious Ethics and Issues in Contemporary Medicine (3)

540.description: Prerequisite, RELI 140. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Exploration of the history, beliefs, and practices of Mormons. Will include visits to Latter-Day Saints services, guest speakers, and discussion of race and gender in the contemporary church.
540.title: Mormonism and the American Experience (3)

541.description: The course will examine the evangelical tradition from a global perspective, exploring the tradition from its early rise in Europe to its impact on the Americas, Africa, and Asia.
541.title: Global Evangelicalism (3)

542.description: The course examines the interaction between the values and messages of the counterculture and religious groups, ideas, and practices during the Vietnam War era. It also investigates the impact of countercultural norms and styles on the current American religious scene.
542.title: Religion and the Counterculture (3)

565.description: This course explores the Jewish interpretation of the Bible, focusing on important commentaries from influential medieval Ashkenazi and Sephardic thinkers.
565.title: Medieval Jews and the Bible (3)

566.description: This course explores many aspects of the Halakhah, the Jewish traditional legal system, focusing on issues such as rituals, holidays, religious obligations and prohibitions, and laws regulating sexual activity.
566.title: Jewish Legal Literature (3)

569.description: This seminar explores the topic of intimate relations between people who consider themselves, or are considered by others, to be part of different religious groups. We will explore cases in which such relations achieve the social sanction of marriage and cases in which the relations are of a more temporary nature.
569.title: Interfaith Marriages and Intimacy in World Religions (3)

580.description: An historical examination of African American Islam in the United States. Explores the intellectual, cultural, social, and political roots of black Islam in addition to its diverse doctrinal, ritual, and institutional manifestations.
580.title: African American Islam (3)

581.description: Permission of the instructor. A survey of Islamic mysticism, its sources in the Qur’an and the Prophet Muhammad, and its literary, cultural, and social deployment in Arab, Persian, Indic, and Turkish regions.
581.title: Sufism (ASIA 581) (3)

582.description: A survey of the formation of islamic traditions in the subcontinent from the eighth century to the present, with emphasis on religion and politics, the role of sufism, types of popular religion, and questions of islamic identity.
582.title: Islam and Islamic Art in South Asia (ASIA 582) (3)

583.description: Iran from the rise of the Safavid empire to the Islamic Republic. Topics include Shi’ism, politics, intellectual and sectarian movements, encounters with colonialism, art and architecture, music, literature.
583.title: Religion and Culture in Iran, 1500–Present (ASIA 583) (3)

584.description: A nontheological approach to the Qur’an as a literary text, emphasizing its history, form, style, and interpretation.
584.title: The Qur’an as Literature (ASIA 584) (3)

585.description: This course will cover the history of Turkey from the Byzantine period until contemporary times. Key aspects of Turkish culture (architecture, music, poetry to arts) will be covered.
585.title: Religion and Culture of Turkey (3)

586.description: This seminar explores the roles of women in the religions of Japan (including Buddhism, Shinto, folk religions, pilgrimage, new religions movements, and new spirituality culture) from goddesses, shamans, nuns, and pilgrims to demons, temptresses, and lesser human beings. The course traces these themes across Japanese socioeconomic and religious history.
586.title: Women and Gender in Japanese Religions (3)

590.description: Permission of the instructor. Subject matter will vary with instructor but will always be focused on a particular problem or issue.
590.title: Topics in the Study of Religion (3)

592.title: Religious Conflict and Narrative in India (HNUR 592) (3)

60.description: How does religion become a source of ethnic or racial prejudice among religious practitioners? When does prejudice against religious persons constitute a form of racism? This class explores answers to these questions by examining the connections between religion and racism in modern societies like the United States and South Africa.
60.title: First-Year Seminar: Religion and Racism (3)

602.description: The course traces the past and continued canonical processes that define what the Hebrew Bible/ Old Testament has been and is today, with a focus on the history of biblical interpretation.
602.title: What Is Scripture? Formations of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament Canon (JWST 602) (3)

603.description: This course explores the translation of the Hebrew Bible in the West, with a view toward identifying religious and ideological trends.
603.title: The Bible and Its Translation (3)

607.description: Prerequisite, RELI 104, 207, or 208. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite.
607.title: Problems in Early Christian Literature and History (3)

608.description: Ideas concerning the Messiah and the end of the world held by Jews, Christians, and Muslims. Emphasis on the beginning of the Christian era.
608.title: The Messiah and the Apocalypse (3)

61.description: This course explores the ways in which religion, magic, and science are defined in the modern world and the different forms in which supernaturalism circulates within contemporary culture.
61.title: First-Year Seminar: Religion, Magic, and Science (3)

617.description: Examinations of practices and discourses pertaining to death and the afterlife in the ancient civilizations of Near East, Greece, and Rome.
617.title: Death and Afterlife in the Ancient World (3)

62.description: Christian orthodox beliefs or practices often get formulated expressly to marginalize a viewpoint or community considered too radical. This course examines a variety of Western Christian dissenters and the authorities that opposed them: Gnostics; medieval, Spanish, and Latin American inquisitions; Protestant Anabaptists; witches; Galileo; Mormons; and Pentecostals.
62.title: First-Year Seminar: A History of Heresy: Christian Dissent from the Gnostics to the Pentecostals (3)

63.description: In this seminar students learn about the Dead Sea Scrolls, ancient manuscripts dating to the time of Jesus from caves around the site of Qumran by the Dead Sea. They include early copies of the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament) and sectarian works of the Jewish community that lived in Qumran.
63.title: First-Year Seminar: The Archaeology of Qumran and the Dead Sea Scrolls (3)

64.description: An introduction to the Islamic religious tradition, focusing on major themes of Islamic religious thought and bringing out both traditional spirituality and the critical issues confronting Muslims today.
64.title: First-Year Seminar: Reintroducing Islam (3)

65.description: This course examines the conflicting ways in which ancient myth, science, and philosophy explained creation of the universe, origins of mankind, nature of dreams, and foundations of culture.
65.title: First-Year Seminar: Myth, Philosophy, and Science in the Ancient World (3)

66.description: Introduces students to Buddhism and traces its history in the United States, highlighting the period since 1965. It focuses on immigrants, converts, and the cultural influence of Buddhism in America.
66.title: First-Year Seminar: Buddhism in America: From the Buddha to the Beastie Boys (3)

662.description: Prerequisite, RELI 162. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. This course explores the history of the Second Council of the Vatican (Vatican II, 1962–1965), crucial for understanding contemporary Catholicism.
662.title: Advanced Seminar in Contemporary Catholicism (3)

665.description: Permission of the instructor for nonmajors. Medieval Christians consistently focused on the suffering body as a means of reflecting on Christ’s sacrifice. This course considers how medical theories of cognition, gender, and pain influenced the potential role of the body in medieval mystical experience.
665.title: Body and Suffering in Christian Mysticism (3)

668.description: Strong background in medieval and early modern studies and permission of the instructor required for undergraduates. This course studies Muslims, Christians, and Jews in the medieval Iberian kingdoms, then interreligious discourse in the colonial expansion to Mexico, Peru, and the Philippines, by deploying theories concerning race, gender, sexuality, and postcoloniality.
668.title: Spanish Religions: Peninsular Convivencia and Colonial Encounter (3)

67.description: This course explores how different religious traditions conceive of human nature and cultural personhood, and the ways that these understandings are reflected in diverse forms of personal identity and public life.
67.title: First-Year Seminar: Nature, Culture, and Self-Identity: Religion in the Construction of Social Life (3)

68.description: A comparative examination of prophet, scientist, and poet as critics and creators of the entrepreneurial outlook and sensibility in individuals and organizations with special attention to innovators’ dilemmas.
68.title: First-Year Seminar: Charisma in Religion, Science, Poetry: Studies in the Entrepreneurial Imagination (3)

681.description: Permission of the instructor. Study of selected religious, literary, and historical texts in Arabic, Persian, or Urdu.
681.title: Readings in Islamicate Literatures (ARAB 681, ASIA 681) (3)

688.description: Permission of the instructor. Exercises (including field work) in learning to read the primary modes of public action in religious traditions, e.g., sermons, testimonies, rituals, and prayers.
688.title: Observation and Interpretation of Religious Action (ANTH 688, FOLK 688) (3)

69.description: Taking a global perspective, the course compares the manners in which Jewish communities in America, Israel, Europe, Asia, and Africa have accommodated themselves to the changing norms in gender and sexuality in the last generation.
69.title: First-Year Seminar: Gender and Sexuality in Contemporary Judaism (3)

691H.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Required of all students reading for honors in religious studies.
691H.title: Honors in Religious Studies (3)

692H.description: Permission of the director of undergraduate studies. Required of all students reading for honors in religious studies.
692H.title: Honors in Religious Studies (3)

696.description: Advanced undergraduate or graduate standing and permission of the instructor. Subject matter should be arranged with a specific instructor.
696.title: Independent Study (3)

697.description: Majors only. Concentrating on a different theme each year, this departmental seminar introduces the different areas and approaches in religious studies.
697.title: Capstone: Undergraduate Seminar (3)

70.description: This seminar explores the ways the historical Jesus has been portrayed in the writings of modern scholars and films of the 20th and 21st centuries.
70.title: First-Year Seminar: Jesus in Scholarship and Film (3)

700.description: Graduate standing in religious studies or permission of the instructor. A basic problems and methods course required of all graduate students in religious studies.
700.title: Theory and Method in the Study of Religion (3)

702.description: A study of the religious traditions in ancient israelite literature from the twelfth through the second centuries bCe.
702.title: Religion and Literature of Israel (3)

703.description: exploration of current critical approaches to the study of the Hebrew bible, including those oriented toward a study of its interpretive history.
703.title: Critical Approaches to the Study of the Hebrew Bible andits History of Interpretation (3)

704.description: focusing on the Mediterranean religions before Alexander, the course consists of readings of original documents in translation, illustrating theology and cult, as well as on the major history of religions interpretations.
704.title: Readings in Religions of the Ancient Near East (3)

707.description: Permission ofthe instructor. A critical study of the history and literature of early Christianity from Paul to irenaeus, with texts to be read in the original languages.
707.title: Early Christian History and Literature (3)

71.description: What does it mean to be ethically literate in the age of information technology? Philosophical and historical inquiries into organizational practices and styles of life.
71.title: First-Year Seminar: Ethics and the Spirit of the New Capitalism (3)

712.description: Permission of the instructor. An examination of the main varieties of pre-rabbinic Judaism: Hellenistic Judaism, apocalyptic Judaism, and the Judaism of the dead sea scrolls.
712.title: Early Jewish History and Literature (3)

718.description: Permission of the instructor. opportunity for reading of ancient documents representing the more important religious trends of the Greco-roman world.
718.title: Readings in Greco-Roman Religion (3)

72.description: This course explores the messianic idea in America as well as the messianic movements that have been active in the nation’s history and their interaction with American society and culture.
72.title: First-Year Seminar: Apocalypse Now? Messianic Movements in America (3)

720.title: Critical and Comparative Lineages in Religion and Culture (3)

721.description: Permission of the instructor. studies in early modern, enlightenment and romantic political, philosophical, and literary texts.
721.title: Theories of Religion and Culture (3)

723.description: Graduate standing in religious studies or permission of the instructor. exploration of various forms of contemporary critical thought (including gender theory, critical race theory, and postcolonial studies) in order to assess the value of these critical tools for the study of religion.
723.title: Critical Approaches to Religion and Culture (3)

729.description: Graduate standing in religious studies or permission of the instructor. This course examines the relationships between religion and modernity, both as conceptual categories and through ethnographic studies of religion and/in modern life.
729.title: Religion and Modernity (3)

73.description: This course examines the cultural construction of animals in Japanese myth, folklore, and religion.
73.title: First-Year Seminar: From Dragons to Pokemon: Animals in Japanese Myth, Folklore, and Religion (3)

734.description: Permission of the instructor. selected readings on image production, exhibition, and interpretation, with consideration of different ritual and cultic settings.
734.title: Studies in the Rhetoric of Images (3)

735.description: Permission of the instructor. textual analysis of several theoretical and literary works dealing with selected problems in religion and literature.
735.title: Critical Works in Religion and Literature (3)

74.description: Within the vast field of activity called “religion,” this course examines how people and societies give meaning to the relation between human organisms and the universe in time and space.
74.title: First-Year Seminar: Person, Time, and Religious Conduct (3)

740.description: Graduate standing in religious studies or permission of the instructor. Consideration of methods, theories, and interpretations that have been influential in the study of American religion.
740.title: Approaches to the Study of American Religions (3)

741.description: Graduate standing in religious studies or permission of the instructor. A historical and thematic survey of the religions of African Americans from the precolonial era to the present.
741.title: Themes in African American Religious History (3)

742.description: Graduate standing in religious studies or permission of the instructor. A study of the religious tradition in American literature from the Puritan period to the present.
742.title: Religion and Literature in America (3)

743.description: The course aims at examining the current developments in American Judaism: cultural, spiritual, liturgical, as well as social and institutional.
743.title: Current Trends in American Judaism (3)

744.description: An examination of primary sources in the history of American religion from the precolonial era to the Civil war.
744.title: Readings in American Religion to 1865 (3)

745.description: An examination of primary sources in the history of American religion since the Civil war.
745.title: Readings in American Religion since 1865 (3)

746.description: Course examines the Christian-Jewish encounter in America from the 17th century to the present. Analyzes both theological and social interactions.
746.title: The Christian-Jewish Encounter in America (3)

75.description: This course will consider the questions of debt, loss, and surrender as we explore the problem of sacrifice. Readings will address the associated problems of violence, transgression, and animality.
75.title: First-Year Seminar: Sacrifice and Surrender (3)

77.description: This seminar asks why some people choose to take life (their own or another’s) for religious purposes and how texts, practices, and communities shape these motives. Focuses on martyrological traditions in Western religions, but also tracks idioms of war, sacrifice, and ritualized suffering in other religious contexts and secular discourses.
77.title: First-Year Seminar: Martyrs and Warriors: Religion and the Problem of Violence (3)

780.description: Principal topics will includethe history of islamic studies; problems of anti-islamic bias; use of textbooks, primary sources, novels, films and the internet; teaching the Qur’an; the Muslim presence in europe and America; modern Muslim thinkers; gender studies; and other related subjects. Gateway course.
780.title: Methods in Islamic Studies (3)

782.description: exploration of reformist intellectual movements in modern Muslim societies, paying close attention to the case of post-revolutionary iran and examining the compatibility of islam and human rights, women’s rights, democracy, and fresh hermeneutical approaches to scriptures.
782.title: Islam and Reform (3)

785.description: Permission of the instructor. This seminar is the core course for the graduate certificate in Middle east studies. it is an introduction to critical issues in the study of the Middle east, focusing on classic works of the humanities and social sciences.
785.title: Critical Genealogies of Middle East Studies (3)

807.description: studies in Greek texts drawn from early Christianity, Judaism, and other religions of the Greco-roman world.
807.title: Hellenistic Religious Texts in Greek (3)

808.description: required preparation, proficiency in Greek. Permission of the instructor. A study of selected works of the Apostolic fathers, including barnabas, ignatius, and Polycarp.
808.title: The Apostolic Fathers (3)

809.description: required preparation, proficiency in Greek. Permission of the instructor. reconstruction; application of text-critical principles.
809.title: Textual Criticism of the Greek Bible (3)

810.description: Permission of the instructor. readings from apocalyptic texts in the original languages.
810.title: Readings in Early Jewish and Christian Apocalyptic (3)

812.description: Permission of the instructor for undergraduates. seminar examines the evidence for the ancient Jewish communities of egypt, rome, Asia Minor, and Mesopotamia.
812.title: Diaspora Judaism (CLAR 812) (3)

813.description: Permission of the instructor. An introduction to the study of the babylonian talmud in the original Hebrew and Aramaic, with the traditional commentaries. The emphasis is on understanding talmudic logic.
813.title: Readings in Talmud (3)

814.description: Prerequisite, reli 712. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. examination of the methodological problems of using rabbinic materials as sources for the history of Judaism in the period after 70 Ce.
814.title: Problems in Rabbinic Historiography (3)

821.description: Permission of the instructor. topics vary; consult the department.
821.title: Seminar in Religion and Culture (3)

823.description: Permission of the instructor. An examination of major themes in contemporary postcolonial thought, and the application of this work to the study of religion.
823.title: Postcolonial Approaches to the Study of Religion (3)

835.description: This interdisciplinary graduate seminar focuses on religion, space, and place in the United states.
835.title: Space, Place, and Religion (3)

838.description: This course examines selected themes in legal and social theory relating to the position of religion in contemporary American society.
838.title: Topics in Religion and Law (3)

840.description: topics vary. May be repeated for credit.
840.title: Seminar in American Religion (3)

841.description: Historical analysis of the relationship between religious developments and social issues in America. topics may include economics, politics, and social reform.
841.title: Religion and Social Issues in America (3)

842.description: examination of religion in America through instances of intercultural contact. topics vary.
842.title: Religion and Cultural Contact in America (3)

843.description: A seminar on roman Catholicism in the United states that also considers developments elsewhere in the western hemisphere. focus is on ritual practice and visual culture.
843.title: Roman Catholicism in America (3)

85.description: This course approaches the central role of discourses about sexual norms, marriage, and family in select religious traditions. It asks how religious traditions have defined and negotiated normative models for marriage and family in their connection to larger theological frameworks and religious source texts.
85.title: First-Year Seminar: Sex, Marriage, and Family in Religion (3)

866.description: Permission of the instructor. selected texts which illumine significant aspects of medieval religious culture are read in the original languages.
866.title: Medieval Religious Texts (3)

867.description: Permission of the instructor. selected texts which illumine significant aspects of the Catholic and Protestant reformations are read in the original languages.
867.title: Texts of the Catholic and Protestant Reformations (3)

870.description: Permission of the instructor. exploration of one enduring issue in the history of the western Christian tradition. The instructor selects several case studies that illustrate both the topic and the developments within traditions.
870.title: Methods and Topics in the Study of Western Religious Traditions (3)

88.description: In this seminar we will read several books. Most of them are best-sellers and can be described as “historical novels.” Having these books as a starting point, we will explore religion and society in Europe and the Middle East in the medieval and early modern period.
88.title: First-Year Seminar: Religion and Society in Historical Novels (3)

881.description: required preparation, proficiency in Arabic and/or Persian. Advanced study of major islamic thinkers and topics, based on original language texts and modern scholarly interpretations.
881.title: Islamic Thought (3)

885.title: Buddhist Studies and the Construction of Buddhism (3)

89.description: Special topics course. Content will vary each semester.
89.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

890.description: Graduate standing in religious studies or permission of the instructor. topics vary.
890.title: Topics in the Study of Religion (3–9)

900.description: Permission of the instructor. 990 Preliminary Preparation (1–21).
900.title: Readings and Research (3–9)

229.description: An introduction to literature in the Romance languages. All readings in English translation. Focus and readings will vary.
229.title: Literature in the Romance Languages (3)

280.description: Introduction to basic paradigms of thinking about cultural difference (race, gender, nationality, religion, etc.), shaping how we act, think, and imagine as members of diverse cultures.
280.title: Social Theory and Cultural Diversity (3)

417.description: Continuation of the study of the language and culture of one of the languages of spanish America other than spanish. selection will vary according to term: Mayan, nahuatl, Quechua, Guarani.
417.title: Languages of the Americas II (3)

50.description: Students examine the expressive use of language in oral and written texts. Particular emphasis is placed on the contribution of the cognitive sciences to an understanding of how humans communicate.
50.title: First-Year Seminar: The Art and Science of Language: Orality and Literacy in the Information Age (3)

500.description: Provides training in research methodology either for a B.A. with honors or M.A. thesis. Students will learn to conceptualize an original research project and to identify and assess the current intellectual debates in their chosen areas of research.
500.title: Research Methods in Romance Languages and European Studies (3)

51.description: Explores the development of national identities in the Romance world, focusing on conscious and unconscious attitudes toward language that helped fashion the four major Romance languages.
51.title: First-Year Seminar: National and Cultural Identities in the Romance Areas (3)

52.description: This course explores the cultural challenges for Spanish-speaking immigrants in the United States, particularly the importance of language in culture and identity.
52.title: First-Year Seminar: The Value of Language in Identity: Hispanics in the United States (3)

53.description: Introduces students to procedures for gathering, transcribing, and analyzing oral histories and to issues related to the growing Hispanic population at both the national and local levels.
53.title: First-Year Seminar: Oral Histories of Our Local Hispanic Community (3)

54.description: Studies such issues as national identities and national memory; the impact of colonization, postcolonialism, and globalization; conflicts between tradition and modernity; and the place of women in history.
54.title: First-Year Seminar: Issues in Francophone Literature (3)

55.description: A study of the literary production of Hispanics living in the United States. Examines works by Chicano, Puerto Rican, Nuyorican, Dominican, and Cuban American writers.
55.title: First-Year Seminar: Writing with an Accent: Latino Literature and Culture (3)

56.description: This course explores the concept of harmony in selected Italian writers from Dante to contemporary film directors.
56.title: First-Year Seminar: Italians in Search of Harmony (3)

58.description: Participants read poems, letters, stories, and short novels by Mexican women of the 20th century. Focus on gender and transgression, feminism, identity formation, and marginality. Selections from Elena Poniatowska, Sandra Cisneros, Cristina Rivera Garza, Ana Clavel, and Ángeles Mastretta, among others.
58.title: First-Year Seminar: Mexican Women across Borders and Genres (3)

60.description: Students study Spanish language and Latino cultures through the lens of social entrepreneurship, a process of opportunity recognition, resource gathering, and value creation that brings sustainability to a social mission.
60.title: First-Year Seminar: Spanish and Entrepreneurship: Language, Culture, and North Carolina Communities (3)

600.description: This graduate seminar consists of a series of in-depth studies of several major contemporary approaches to literary theory. Designed primarily as an elective for master’s candidates in Romance languages, this course aims to prepare students for advanced literature and literary theory courses.
600.title: Master’s Workshop on Theory (3)

601.description: for students with no backgroundin spanish or those needing a review of grammatical structures and vocabulary in preparation for the reading knowledge exam for graduate students (flPA).
601.title: Spanish for Reading (3)

61.description: In the United States, 17 percent of children have a developmental disability. How do they learn and use language to communicate, socialize, and achieve goals? How do we improve their language skills? This course examines these and other questions and helps students understand and carry out research with special populations.
61.title: First-Year Seminar: Language in Autism and Developmental Disorders (3)

614.title: Modernist and Contemporary Spanish American Literature (3)

62.description: Analysis of how Latin transformed the linguistic configuration of the world and its lasting impact on culture and science. No previous knowledge of Latin or of any Romance language necessary to enroll.
62.title: First-Year Seminar: What Happened to Latin? (3)

650.description: Interdisciplinary, comparative, and multimedia approach to the question of memory and history in 20th-century Europe. Explores individual memory, collective memory, and commemoration. Survey of interdisciplinary approaches to the field and an examination of historical sites through the narratives of mental illness, fiction, memoir, testimonial literature, photography, and film.
650.title: The Politics of Remembering: Memory, History, and Power in 20th-Century Europe (3)

660.description: Critical examination of 20th-century Latin American cultural history in Brazil and Spanish-speaking countries, including Mexico, Cuba, El Salvador, Peru, Colombia, and Argentina. Course is framed betweenlate 19th-century modernization and the contemporary discussion on globalization.
660.title: Film and Culture in Brazil and Spanish America (3)

680.description: Prerequisite, sPAn 377. why and how do children learn language so easily, and why is it so difficult for adults to learn a second language? This course examines these and related questions in the light of current theories of firstand second-language acquisition, with a focus on spanish.
680.title: Firstand Second-Language Acquisition of Spanish (3)

682.description: Prerequisite, sPAn 376, 377, or 378. interdisciplinary approach to studying the spanish language asa social and cultural phenomenon. explores the relationship between language and culture, communicative competence and pragmatics, social and linguistic factors in language variation and change, attitudes toward language and language choice, linguistic prejudice and language myths, and language and identity.
682.title: Spanish Sociolinguistics (3)

691H.description: required of students reading for honors. Preparation of an essay under the direction of a faculty member. topic to be approved by thesis director in consultation with honors advisor.
691H.title: Honors Thesis (3)

698.title: Seminar in Romance Languages: Capstone Course (3)

700.description: required of all new graduate instructors. exploration of theoretical issues in teaching romance languages with their practical applications, including the integration of technology.
700.title: Theories and Techniques of Teaching (3)

751.description: interdisciplinary course to introduce graduate students to the sources, methods, and approaches of medieval studies.
751.title: Introduction to Medieval Studies (3)

755.description: An introduction to contemporary theoretical positions to acquaint the student with issues posed by formalism, Marxism, feminism, and deconstruction. orientation to romance bibliography and research methods.
755.title: Workshop on Literary Theory and Research Methods (1

820.description: Thoroughstudy of the basic grammar and syntax of classical latin, followed by readings from representative medieval literary texts and a sampling of writings by the italian humanists. restricted to graduate students in the department of romance languages and literatures.
820.title: Introduction to Latin for Romance Studies (3)

824.description: study of the development of medieval romance book hands and diplomatics from their origins to the advent of printing; with practical exercises.
824.title: Romance Paleography (3)

825.description: linguistic analysis of the langue d’oc and investigation of medieval Provençal literature.
825.title: Provençal (3)

830.description: topic determined by instructor and announced in advance.
830.title: Seminar in Romance Languages (3)

870.description: introduction to the historical development of Catalan, rhaeto-romance, and rumanian. readings in period texts.
870.title: Minor Romance Tongues (3)

89.description: Special topics course. Content will vary by each semester.
89.title: First-Year Seminar: Special Topics (3)

700.description: This course will cover topics germane to the history and philosophy of rehabilitation. students will obtain an overview of the field, its consumers, and methods of service delivery.
700.title: Introduction to Rehabilitation Counseling and Psychology (3)

702.description: An introduction to the traditional theories of individual and family counseling. emphasis on application of theories to persons with disabilities, ethics, and multicultural awareness.
702.title: Theories of Counseling Applied to Rehabilitation (3)

704.description: functional, psychological, vocational, familial, social, and sexual aspects of medical disabilities. includes the human body system and medical terminology. focus on assistive technology and functional capacity.
704.title: Medical Aspects of Rehabilitation (3)

706.description: This course is an overview of the selection, administration, and interpretation of major assessment tools. emphasis is on persons with mental illness or developmental disabilities.
706.title: Tests and Measurement in Rehabilitation Counseling Psychology (3)

708.description: This course will cover career development and counseling with emphasis on community integration in vocationaland leisure pursuits of persons with disabilities, particularly those with mental illness and developmental disabilities.
708.title: Community Integration for Individuals with Disabilities: Work, Home and Leisure (3)

710.title: Developmental Counseling Through the Life Span (3)

712.description: Prerequisites, rPsy 700 and 702\. An introduction to diagnosing clients with mental illness and developmental disabilities. focus is on best practice treatment and the vocational, social, and familial implications of living with a dsM disorder.
712.title: Fundamentals of Rehabilitation Counseling and Psychology: Diagnosis and Practice (3)

714.description: strategies and techniques in developing and implementing groups in counseling. Attention to group counseling with persons with disabilities, specifically those with mental illness and developmental disabilities.
714.title: Principles of Group Counseling in Rehabilitation Psychology and Counseling (3)

718.description: introduces occurrence of both psychiatric conditions and substance abuse prevalence examining history including traditional recovery models, contradictory practices, bio-physiological effects, and shift from separate to parallel to integrated treatment approaches.
718.title: Co-Occurring Disorders in Rehabilitation Counseling and Psychology (3)

800.description: Prerequisites, rPsy 700 and 702. research methods, evidence-based practice, and ethical, legal, and cultural issues related to research and evaluation. Covers basic statistics, library research for rehabilitation-related information, proposal development, and grant writing.
800.title: Rehabilitation Counseling and Psychology Research and Program Evaluation (3)

805.description: Prerequisite, rPsy 818. introduces the range of evidence-based practice and new effective models for treating individuals with severe and persistent mental illness demonstrated through levels of evidence empirically.
805.title: Evidence-based Practices in Psychiatric Rehabilitation (3)

806.description: designed to teach foundational counseling skillsthat will enable students to begin counseling. focus on counseling individuals with mental illness and developmental disabilities. includes ethics and multicultural awareness.
806.title: Applied Counseling Skills in Rehabilitation Counseling and Psychology (5)

810.title: Internship in Rehabilitation Counseling and Psychology (5)

814.description: Historical perspective, description, diagnoses, classification, etiology, patterns of functioning, current best practices with focus on rCP service delivery and community support; day-in-thelife component included.
814.title: Introduction to People with Psychiatric and Developmental Disabilities (3)

816.description: Prerequisites, rPsy 700, 702, and 814. Prepares students forrCP practice with persons with developmental disabilities; covers a wide range of intervention and coordination strategies focusing on achievement of a participatory, person-centered, independent, and productive community life.
816.title: Advanced Practice with People with Developmental Disabilities (3)

890.title: Special Topics in Rehabilitation Counseling and Psychology (1–3)

992.description: individual work by a student (supervised by faculty) to explore an area of interest in a research paper, program development, or a professional project.
992.title: Master’s Paper/Project in Rehabilitation Counseling and Psychology (3–6)

469.description: see Poli 469 for description.
469.title: Conflict and Intervention in the Former Yugoslavia (POLI 469, PWAD 469) (3)

690.title: Selected Topics in Russian and East European Studies (3)

710.description: series of follow-up discussions of guest lectures sponsored by the Center for slavic, eurasian, and east european studies. The discussions will be based on bibliographies previously assigned by guest lecturers.
710.title: Core Colloquium (1)

730.description: Capstone course for the master of arts in russian/east european studies. interdisciplinary course focusing on the variety of problems encountered by the societies of east european countries and successor states of the former soviet Union in their transition from communism to democracy.
730.title: Identities and Transitions (POLI 746) (3)

991.description: Allows students to undertake advanced research under the supervision of a faculty member.
991.title: Independent Study in Russian and East European Studies (1–21)

101.description: Introductory course designed to lay the foundation of grammar and to convey basic reading and pronunciation skills.
101.title: Elementary Russian (4)

102.description: Continuation of the introductory course designed to lay the foundation of grammar and to convey basic reading and pronunciation skills.
102.title: Elementary Russian (4)

203.description: Grammar-translation work with increasing proportions of free reading and oral work.
203.title: Intermediate Russian (3)

204.description: Grammar-translation work with increasing proportions of free reading and oral work, continued.
204.title: Intermediate Russian (3)

213.description: Corequisite, RUSS 203. Supplements the grammar presentations in RUSS 203. Basic conversational practice on topics relevant to Russia today.
213.title: Intermediate Russian Conversation (2)

250.description: Prerequisite, RUSS 204. Permission of the instructor for students lacking the prerequisite. Reading and discussion of selected authors in Russian aimed at improving reading skill and preparing the student for higher level work in Russian literature.
250.title: Introduction to Russian Literature (3)

270.description: Introduction to Russian prose fiction of the 19th century with particular consideration of selected writings of Pushkin, Gogol, Turgenev, Dostoevsky, and Tolstoy. Lectures and readings in English.
270.title: Russian Literature of the 19th Century (3)

272.description: Literary situations and authors of 1880 to 1917, with emphasis on Chekhov and the Symbolists. Lectures and readings in English.
272.title: Russian Literature from Chekhov to the Revolution (3)

273.description: Examines the extraordinary diversity of turn-of-the-century Russian culture (1890s to 1917); the proliferation of visual and performance arts; the rise of popular culture; new artistic explorations of gender and sexuality. Lectures and readings in English.
273.title: Russian Culture and Society: 1890–1917 (3)

274.description: Russian writers and literary problems from the Revolution to the present. Lectures and readings in English.
274.title: Russian Literature after 1917 (3)

275.description: An introduction to the Russian fairy tale with attention to its roots in Russian folklore, its influence on Russian culture, and its connections with American folk and popular culture. Lectures and readings in English.
275.title: Russian Fairy Tale (3)
